story:
VAST by Amber Funk Barton

Hello Everyone!

I have been making dances for as long as I can remember.  As an only child, I happily entertained myself for hours this way.  I would make up stories, write them down and then dance them out.  I would put on records and perform for invisible audiences.  The comfort I found in being alone has shaped my practice as a dance artist.

I named my company 'the response.' as a way to evoke how I make dance.  I respond to music I hear and the emotions I feel.  After years of creating everything from group dances to full length productions, I decided to return to how I began my career: alone and making dances for myself.

In 2015, I approached some of my most beloved collaborators with an idea: I wanted to make a work inspired by universal space.  As we began to research ideas, I realized that the work was a solo and that I should be performing it.  The ideas and imagery that we discovered were too personal and vulnerable for me to hand off to someone else to perform. 

This has led to more research and discovery than I have ever experienced as a choreographer.  

“Get Amber Funk on stage and viewers can expect to feel the theatre rumble…Her stuff is physical to the point of explosive, and impossible to forget.”-The Georgia Straight

More about VAST:

"We are a way for the universe to know itself. Some part of our being knows this is where we came from. We long to return. And we can, because the cosmos is also within us. We're made of star stuff." -Carl Sagan

VAST is about a body in space.  Quotes from the scientist Carl Sagan inspired me to create a solo that evokes an otherworldly journey that is both physical and spiritual.  The idea that chemical elements found in stars are also present in the human body is not only poetic but deeply moves me.  I love the idea that there will always be elements of myself, and thus all of us that will exist forever.  I feel that this is a hopeful idea and that it is important to create a work that celebrates the duality of a human life that is both powerless and mighty. 

When I dance VAST, it feels like I am lost in a dream that shifts without my consent, eventually forcing me to surrender to the rhythm of the universe that gives me permission to exist.

The creation of VAST has allowed me to accept a fundamental truth about my identity as a dance artist.  As a choreographer, my strength lies when I am the sole interpreter of my work.  I have choreographed many solos for myself in the past but VAST will be the first time I create a full length solo. It is important for me that VAST is produced by the response. because I founded my company in order to always have a home for my creative works, whatever the form.  

VAST brings together artistry of Andreas Kahre (set design), Mike Inwood (light design), Marc Stewart (sound design and music composition), Jean Okada (costume design), Heather Laura Gray (dramaturge) and Lina Fitzner (rehearsal director) to create a singular performance that I desire to share with as many people as people.  

 

What We Need & What You Get

VAST premieres March 2-3, 2018 at The Dance Centre in Vancouver, BC in a co-presentation with the 2018 Vancouver International Dance Festival.  With this impending premiere, my company is facing a critical situation: I need to raise a minimum of $10 000 to cover the basic production expenses of this solo.  This includes: 

  • materials for our set (we need to create a black frame to lay on a white dance floor for the performance space to appear in the shape of an ellipses.  We also need materials to build of an irregular "satellite"--see photo above!-- that will hang above the dancer in the performance space)
  • lighting equipment rental (we are working with four free standing lights that also act as set pieces)
  • airfare (to ensure our lighting designer can finalize his design and be present in the theatre with us for the premiere

  • artist fees (to ensure all designers of the production are paid a professional honorarium in addition to our technical crew)

After so much work and research with my collaborators it would be truly heartbreaking if we can't share the work with you the way we have intended.  I can guarantee you that not a penny will go to waste! 

the response. (The Response Dance Society) is a non-profit and charitable organization.  Every donation $25+ will receive a tax deductible receipt.  And there's some sweet perks too!  Such as:

  • 1 month of unlimited Yoga & Pilates Mat classes at Full Circle Studio in East Van (good for Yoga, Pilates Mat and Well-Back classes)
  • private mat Pilates sessions with Heather Laura Gray at location of your choice 
  • gift cards to meet your caffeine needs!
  • free tickets to the premiere of VAST!

The Impact

VAST will be a huge milestone for me as a dance artist.  I have choreographed many solos for myself in the past but VAST will be the first time I create a full length solo. 

I have been a professional contemporary dance artist in Vancouver for 17 years and I founded the response. in 2008.  With the response. I have a proven track record of creating, directing and producing my own work.  I have premiered three full length works (RISK, Portraits and Scenes of Female Creatures and The Art of Stealing), several full length productions and multiple shorter works, had my work performed locally, provincially and nationally, run our company's Apprentice Program and have begun an outreach program to teach dance to all dancers and dance lovers, regardless of experience called #dancehappy.  

The creation of VAST has allowed me to accept a fundamental truth about my identity as a dance artist: that the strength of my work is magnified when I am the sole interpreter of my work.  Your generous donation will allow me to share VAST with audiences as I have intended and ensure Canadian artists and designers are paid their professional worth as cultural workers who contribute to the beauty and artistic landscape of Vancouver.  

Risks & Challenges

It has been a challenge to receive funding from organizations for VAST the typical way my company has done in the past.  This has led me to seek out alternative methods to raise money for VAST.  Although we have received much support through residencies, individual donations during our first phase of research and a small amount of project funding from the City of Vancouver and British Columbia Arts Council, it is in no way enough for us to premiere the work.  This situation has already caused me to move my premiere dates twice to accommodate another round of grant applications.

I truly love what I have created with my collaborators and I am determined to share what we have made with all of you. 

The biggest takeaway I have realized in the making of VAST is that we are all connected.  We are all made of the same chemicals found in stars and are intrinsically linked.  All of us play a part in each others lives, great and small.  I understand this now more than ever.  And I am so grateful to have made it this far.  My hope with VAST is that through my performance I can assure people that they are not alone.  That their body is great and small, just like mine, in this universe.  That I see them.  That I appreciate their presence and know that we are all in this life together hoping, looking, asking and wondering what the answers are to all of our questions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even you can't contribute financially, there are so many ways you can help!

  • Spread the word!  Tell as many people about this campaign!  Share the link to this page via your social media and/or personal email.  Have some fun and use the hashtag #VAST or #VASTthepremiere
  • Simply "Like" the response. Facebook page or follow us on Instagram at @response.dance and stay up to date with our campaign and everything we'll share about VAST
  • Request to join our mailing list by emailing us at info@responsedance.com
  • Questions about this campaign or wanting to contribute in a different way?  Email us at vastcampaign2018@gmail.com!
  • Come to our Pay-What-You-Can Class Event on November 28th as part of #GivingTuesday!  Take class with Amber Funk Barton and make your cash donation in person!
  • Come to the show and bring your friends!  Dance is best seen live and with people you love.  And I'd love to see you in the audience!  Take advantage of VIDF's early online sales from November 23rd-December 2nd and save 20%!  You can also call their box office at 604.662.4966 to get your tickets!

From the bottom of my heart, thank you for bringing VAST to life!

story:
The project . . .

The Stones

by Kit Brookman

A chance encounter with an old friend leads recently-unemployed Nick to take a job in the country as a tutor to two young children. The job seems perfect, the family he's working for too good to be true.

But then the stones begin to arrive...

The award winning Australian playwright Kit Brookman has crafted a contemporary gothic mystery in which a splintering present gives way to a murky future. Starring Jeff Burrell (Berlin Station, A Hologram for the King, Nymphomaniac) and directed by Geordie Brookman (Things I Know To Be True - State Theatre Company SA & Frantic Assembly) The Stones will deliver a rare combination of creeping dread and poetry.

‘Shades of Robert Aickman, Shirley Jackson and Henry James' The Turn of the Screw... Consummate storytelling in both the writing and the rendering.’ queerguru.com

directed by Geordie Brookman

with Jeff Burrell

music by Jason Sweeney (Panoptique Electrical)

 

Performed in English.

17 - 20 March, 2021

ACUD Theater, Berlin

 

What We Need . . .

We're staging The Stones independently of any government funding because we believe that the production will connect with English speaking audiences in Berlin and go on to have a significant future life after its debut season at the ACUD Theater. But to get to opening night we have to cover the costs of:

  • Rehearsal space
  • Promotional material
  • Set and costume requirements
  • Technical costs
  • Occasionally buy Geordie and Jeff a sandwich for lunch while they are rehearsing

The wonderful ACUD Theater is supporting us by providing the venue for our initial four performance run for a small share of what will be a limited box office. Any funds raised beyond the immediate hard costs of the production will go towards fees for the artists involved. Currently we are all making the piece 'for the love' of it.

The Impact . . .

The German debut of The Stones will: 

  • see the Berlin debut of writer Kit Brookman, director Geordie Brookman and composer Jason Sweeney.
  • bring a compelling piece of new Australian writing to the Berlin stage.
  • contribute to the development of an English speaking theatre audience in Berlin
  • create a springboard for the future life of a truly spine tingling piece of theatre

Risks & Challenges

2020 was a nightmare of a year for artists everywhere. Starved of an outlet and a connection with the audience it has led to a time of introspection for many of us. The Stones represents a new stylistic step for director Geordie Brookman utilising his ideas about direct storytelling and empathetic audience connection. It's a tough environment to make work of any scale in and we face risks including:

  • Audience limitations and consequential reduction in box office income due to COVID 19
  • Complete theatre closures requiring the development of online versions of the work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you're not able to contribute financially you can help spread the word through your networks either to potential donors or to potential audience members. We appreciate the time and generosity that each and everyone of you bring to this proposal and we couldn't be more determined to bring this compelling piece of theatre to the stage.

story:
BROADWAY

  • I'm Stephanie Lexis: performer, writer, and founder of Broadway Body Positivity Project. I believe that musical theatre actors of ALL shapes, sizes, and abilities deserve to shine on the stage. While the industry's talent pool is more diverse and exciting than ever, casting standards are still quite antiquated: roles like romantic leads, ingenues, and princesses (aka characters who are desirable and worthy of love) are reserved for slim, statuesque women; whereas plus size women are limited to evil villains, stereotypical fat characters, and other characters with unlikeable/undesirable traits.

These casting standards are problematic for several reasons:

              A. It promotes the idea that one must be slim to be considered beautiful and worthy of love

             B.  It insinuates that plus size actresses don't have the talents to play romantic leads,     ingenue roles, simply because they have more body fat.

             C.  We miss out on great storytelling when we cast roles the same way over and over again.

So with that in mind......   

I am producing a nationwide photography & cinematography shoot in which 7 incredibly talented plus size actresses will portray leading ladies, ingenues, and princesses from popular musicals. This shoot will showcase the talent that the theatre industry often overlooks for these roles. Upon completion of the photo and video shoot, the finished product will be presented online (let's go viral!!!), as well as at theatre conferences and conventions.

We are aiming for an online premiere in late January 2020. 

       

What We Need & What You Get

 

  • We are determined to raise at least $16,000 USD, which will all go to good use: each model would receive $2K to cover expenses such as photography (est. $300-1k), cinematography (est. $500-1,500K), hair & makeup (est. $75-250), costumes (est. $75-350), accessories (est. $15-200), recording studio time (est. $100-300). The remaining $2K would go towards advertising, licensing music, reimbursing our creative team for their tireless work.
  • But dont'cha worry, we have AWESOME perks for theatre fans: we have live and online coaching sessions for aspiring artists (1 of those contributors will have a session with a seasoned Broadway actress).
  • Our largest prize includes dinner with a Broadway actor in NYC. 
  • There are also great little prizes at $10, like getting behind the scenes access; $25 for personalized poetry, etc.
  • We will deliver this project, no matter how much is raised. That being said, if too little is raised, we might have to postpone the project's debut date.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot financially contribute, here are other ways to help:

*Share the project far and wide online

* Send this project to the press, blogs, and other media sources

story:
About The Agency

The Agency Theatre Collective is a non-profit theater company whose mission is to produce new and under-produced plays in Chicago. Since 2011, we have produced five world premieres, including the acclaimed I Wish To Apologize To The People of Illinois and the Jeff nominated Truth in Context, along with two unique remounts. 

About The Play

To live in Chagrin Falls, Oklahoma is to be in the killing business. The town's major employers are a cattle slaughterhouse and a penitentiary where lethal injection is administered. Whether they work at the slaughterhouse, play preacher or guard to death row inmates, or merely offer a bed and a hot meal to those visiting the prison, each resident of Chagrin Falls makes their living off of death and captivity.

A week prior to a particular execution, an Asian-American graduate student comes to town - purportedly to do a story on a man who is scheduled to die. As this would-be journalist interviews a cross-section of the population she finds her subjects revealing far more about the complexities of living in Chagrin Falls.

Chagrin Falls won the 2001 American Theatre Critics Association Osborn Award and was a finalist for their Steinberg Award. Chagrin Falls also received Joseph Jefferson and After Dark Awards for Best New Work, as well as a Cincinnati Entertainment Award for Best Production, and First Prize in the Julie Harris Playwriting Competition.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a play of any size is a major undertaking. Your contribution will help in offsetting those costs and allow us to bring the granular realism from the page to stage. Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment, marketing costs, and paying our artists and crew. 

Not only is your donation tax-deductible, we also have some amazing perks from our collaborators. To name a few: a year of acting classes at Green Shirt Studio,  private coaching with either playwright Mia McCullough or director Sommer Austin, a drink with Artistic Director Andrew Gallant, postcards, books, and more!

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
Welcome to Syde-Ide Collaborations!  

 

Our Mission: Syde-Ide Collaborations illuminates the marginalized lens through theatrical performance and visual art to inspire conversation and action.

Syde-Ide Collaborations was created out of a desire to change the paradigm of art. We seek up and coming artists, of all mediums, to create memorable, life-changing experiences for both artists and audiences alike. We are intentional about producing works that shed light on traditionally-marginalized communities. Syde-Ide hopes that the works we produce will bring in new artists and audiences who might feel underrepresented in the community. We want to provide space for Fresh Eyes and New Voices to use art as a means to engage the community and connect on a deeper level. We hope to eliminate the feeling of competition, and move towards a culture of creation and collaboration. We are about beautiful and realistic storytelling, and that starts by representing all spectrum of life. 

 

 

The Clark Doll, Play--February 2018 

 

Syde-Ide Collaborations was founded by two women of color, Tyharra Cozier and Monica Fleetwood. Being two working artists in Portland, Oregon, we found that representation for diversity seemed, surprisingly, very scarce.  We say surprisingly because we would often go to events, auditions, and callbacks and see many people who look like us, but were so rarely put on stage. Accurate and proper representation for diverse people from diverse backgrounds, does not seem to be happening a lot as of late. We would like to change that. Our mission is to "illuminate the marginalized lens", meaning we shine a light onto underrepresented voices. Our first lens being the underrepresented voice of Black Women. Our first production, Liz Morgan's The Clark Doll explores one main question: Are happy endings for Black Women? 

Sharing the same name as the 1940s experiments, Liz Morgan's THE CLARK DOLL explores internalized hatred, and how it "intersects between womanhood and blackness". Following three very different black women, this play focuses on buzzing topics such as identity, appropriation, and representation.  These women must come to terms with their internal conflicts,  resulting in a story that celebrates and uplifts  the Black Woman as well as her ancestral history. 

The Playwright 

LIZ MORGAN is a New York-based playwright, poet and performer. Her written work has appeared in the The Huffington Post, the Long Island City One Act Festival Anthology and the Medium publication, Athena Talks. Liz has developed projects with The Fire This Time Festival, The Lark, Rising Circle Theatre Collective, JACK, NY Madness, and National Black Theatre where she was named a finalist for the I AM SOUL Playwrights’ Residency. Other honors include the Torchbearer for Black Theatre Award, SPACE on Ryder Farm Creative Residency (Finalist), New York New Works Theatre Festival (Finalist), Playwrights Realm Writing Fellowship (Semi-Finalist) and the New Works Lab at Stratford (Semi-Finalist). MFA: Brown University www.LizMorganOnline.com 

Playwright's Note
My play has partly become an homage to Drs. Kenneth and Mamie Clark who started the famous "doll tests." This series of psychological experiments used two dolls, that were identical except for skin and hair color and ultimately showed that both white and African-American children had internalized Eurocentric notions of beauty and anti-blackness. I wasn't surprised to learn that when this test was repeated in the 2000s, the results were the same: young black children who should be playing and dreaming still saw themselves as ugly. My play, The Clark Doll, was written as a way for me to explore my own relationship to internalized hatred at the intersection of my womanhood and my blackness. Why did I often feel sexy but not beautiful; wanted but not desirable; used but not valued? It didn't make sense to me why my features -- tan skin, full lips, round figure -- were mocked on my body but praised on white celebrities. It felt like a maddening conspiracy and I had to figure out how to liberate myself. So The Clark Doll turns to historical narratives, childhood trauma and ancestral knowledge for the answers to the heartbreaking question: Are happy endings for black women? I'm thrilled that Syde-Ide is tackling this piece in Portland. I'm hoping folks that engage with this production will get a chance to look at hot button topics like identity, appropriation, representation in a new way that's visceral, transformative and if they're open to it, healing.

How You Can Support!

Through the generosity of individual donors and grants, we have accrued enough funds to launch successfully and acquire an AMAZING cast and crew for The Clark Doll. HOWEVER, we have only acquired half of what's needed of our actual budget of $20,000.

We're asking for your support!

Your support will aid with: 

  • Securing a Venue and rehearsal space, for The Clark Doll 
  • Compensating our amazing cast and crew 
  • Supporting future projects of Syde-Ide Collaborations 

 

Other Ways to Support 

Besides donating, there are many ways to support! If you love what we're about, please SHARE SHARE SHARE! Like and follow our Facebook, Instagram, and Website! Post about us! Post our event pictures! Tag us! @ us! Tell your friends and family! Keep Word of Mouth going! And ALWAYS feel free to email us. We care about this community, and feedback is always welcomed. 

Facebook: SydeIdeCollaborations 

Website: Sydeidepdx.com 

Email: Syde.Ide@gmail.com 

 

 

"Be passionate and move forward with gusto every single hour of every single day until you reach your goal". 

-Ava Duvernay

story:
The Show

In it's third incarnation, Visceral Abstractions returns April 9th and 18th to the Slipper Room. 

4/9: https://www.slipperroom.com/event/1634962-guest...

4/18: https://www.slipperroom.com/event/1634963-guest...

 

The Team

Juanita is an aerial performer, puppet, costume, and prop designer who convinced some of her most brilliant friends to join her in creating this show and making their collective theatrical dreams come true. 

Dana is a human of the following tendencies: feminist, scientific, designing, technological, acrobatic, performing, absurdist, practical, questionable.

Cheeky Lane is a performer, creator of beautiful objects, puppeteer, cat mom, stripping art school drop out. 

Tamara flies high and dreams big. When not contemplating life in the air, she is bridging gaps as a speech-language pathologist. KEEPS IN ORDER

We are working together to take the show we created further. Now that we have managed to get it together and create a solid work we want to revamp and take some of the things we created to a higher level. This includes making sure that our puppets have the right mechanics, renting more rehearsal space to make sure all the details are considered in the acts, investing in materials to create new props to properly stage scenes etc.

What We Need & What You Get

We love working but until Visceral Abstractions becomes the next hit on Broadway we need a bit of support funding the following,

  • Rehearsal space. We use a combination of dance studios which cost between $10/$15 per hour and aerial studios where its about $26 per rehearsal. 
  • Materials. Fabric/ foam/ wire/ etc adds up! The less we have to panic about how much we spend on them the freer we will be to make objects to blow your mind! 
  • Tech crew. We need to hire a stage hand and a stage manager. If you saw the first version of the show you know why! It was madness!
  • Rigging! We have to rig multiple aerial apparatuses, puppets, a giant shark, etc. we could maybe even hire a rigger... that would be the dream. 

What do you get out of it?

We do not in any way feel entitled to your money but we do hope that we can appeal to your generosity with one of our many perks. Have you ever wanted to learn aerial? We will give you a private lesson! Do you want to learn how to sew? Ill teach you! Do you need a sexy hand made leather fanny pack? I can make you one! Are you a trapeze artist tired of burning your feet? Guess where you can get some fancy hand made chevaliers;)? Are you traveling to Burning Man and need an sequin outfit that can be seen from outer space? I got you. Do you just want to reserve a seat for the show? You can do it here!

We just want to make a bit of magic. Sometimes what's needed is a bit of time to imagine a different world, to enter a space where the mind is momentarily liberated to allow us to keep moving forward. The last two versions of this show created a connection with the audience that reinvigorated our spirits and with your help we will keep pushing that momentum forward.

 

Please share!

If any of this is exciting to you please tell your friends. The more people that know about this the more likely we are to succeed. If you are interested in contributing anything like crafting help or just send us some good vibes to keep going we will be very happy to hear from you,

story:
Summary

Old bones ache before a storm. Within an hour trowel had hit bone, and the moment it did, the thunder rolled in. The archaeologists disturbed something that, frankly, should not have been disturbed.

Poor, poor Richard. Awoken, removed from his resting place, comfortably under concrete, under a council car park. 

Knights, halberds, succession, and horrendous violence. A carpark, yellow hard hats, high vis jackets and archaeologists. 

Dive thoughts, down to my soul… Join us for a fusion of modern and 15th-century slander!

We Need Your Help

Unfortunately putting on a play ain't free, and this is where we need your help. Let me try and explain where all this money will be going! First off I like to say that this budget is just the upfront cost of actually getting the play made.

 

 

As you can see from our lovely pie chart the construction of sets is our biggest expense. Creating a mixture of 15th-century grandeur and a dingy carpark in Leicester is no mean feat. The £700 would mostly be to cover material costs, labour and transporting the sets to the venue. Here are some of our early mockups of the set, just for you.  

Costumes is another big hitter! Richard III has a whole bunch of characters in it and they all need clothes. Have you ever wanted to see the Duchess of York in a high-vis jacket or King Edward with a hard hat crown? no? Well, you might just be about to.

As for props; we need swords, lots of swords.

Lastly is the venue hire. Upstairs at The Gatehouse have kindly agreed to host us, but they want cash! (reasonable) 

 

Who Are We?

You might be asking, "who are you?". Let me explain.

Director

Lata Nobes is  British Indian theatre director from South London. Her work includes Not About Heroes, (Lion and Unicorn, Camden Fringe, 2016) and Amadeus (Oxford Playhouse Burton-Taylor Studio, 2016) and Bed of Roses (Cuckoo-bang, Bits 2017). She was also co-director for Cry-Blueberry, (The Cockpit, 2018) and Assistant Director for Glockenspiel (Tristan-Bates Theatre, 2017). Last year, Lata was chosen as a young emerging director to receive mentoring at the Young Vic as part of their Introduction to Directing course. She is also a drama facilitator, musician, and poet.

 

Producer 

Brad Johnson recently graduated with first-class honours in Digital Film and Video from London South Bank University. Spending 3 years writing, directing, producing and editing a variety of different projects. His film “Chess Club” was chosen as the film of the year by the faculty and nominated for Best Comedy Short at Screentest film festival.

 

Production Designer

George Chaffey is about to graduate from BA Textile Design at the world-renowned Central Saint Martins. In 2014 George was named as Young Fashion Designer of the Year; UK South. His work often revolves around ideas of light, colour, structure and how these elements can work within a space. Having worked on large-scale immersive installations and sets, George has found that his textile work has given him an additional view of how many different elements, materials and techniques can combine to create visual impact. In addition to his 3D work, George has continued his woven textile designs, investigating how these traditional approaches can be integrated with technologies and new materials.

 

Costume Designer 

Hannah Snaith has just finished her second year in the BA Painting course at UAL Camberwell and is taking a year out before she finishes her degree. She has worked as a poster artist on the director Lata's previous plays, and as a costume and prop supervisor for 'Not About Heroes'. Her love of shopping will be very useful in creating the costumes for this play, as they will be sourced from vintage pound sales, charity shops, the high street, actor's wardrobes, and anywhere else she can get her hands on clothing to create the medieval-esque outfits for this Richard III/modern day crossover rendition of Shakespeare's play.

 

Thank you!

Thank you for giving this a read and we really appreciate any contribution, big or small! Tickets go on sale 1st of June via the Camden Fringe.

story:
Short Summary

I am an awareness creator inspired by the words of poet Amiri Baraka who said the social is a catalyst for art.

As a mother of a child with mild autism, I have personally faced the challenges of lack of services and support, having taken the route of obtaining services in the private sector.  I'm lucky that as a family, we could afford to do that; that I could be a stay-at-home mother guiding all aspects of my son's development and growth.  My son has flourished.  But what about all the people who don't have that luxury, people who have children with severe autism?  

I've also been frustrated by a society that is increasingly aware of autism in general but still does not take full steps towards acceptance and inclusion.  I think that while awareness has grown dramatically, the general public still has a lack of understanding of the diversity within the world of autism and lacks a capacity or willingness to truly include people with autism into their lives; their circle of friends; their workplaces.  I'm pushing for a world beyond awareness to truly discovering autistic individuals for who they are and integrating them into daily life beyond family and caretakers.

The Autism Monologues is a play that I wrote with those many ideas in mind.  The play is running at the 2018 St-Ambroise Festival FRINGE de Montreal. 

I need your help to fund the production so that we can do our best to entertain and enlighten the public.  The better the show is, the more it will get talked about, the more we can talk about acceptance and inclusion.  You will be a partner in my endeavour to awaken people to the struggles families face because of lack of governement funding and support, the obstacles autistic people face to true inclusion and integration, and the possibilities of joy and compassion that can make our communities, schools and places of employment more open to neurodiversity. 

Will you join me in this struggle?  I, we, cannot succeed without you.

Visit our website to see who our artists and collaborators are: www.theautismmonologues.com

What We Need & What You Get

  • The total project budget is $5,180.  This includes salaries for 10 artists and collaborators (director, 5 actors, stage manager, set designer, light designer & sound designer.  Discover the team at www.theautismmonologues.com).  It also includes the set design elements and props,  rehearsal space, marketing costs (graphic design, promotional cards and posters, and a show program) and the Fringe Festival participation fee.
  • I am making a personal investment of $3,000 in this production.  A studio residence from Montreal, arts interculturels will save us $675 in rental fees for a rehearsal space. 
  • Because the salaries the team members are receiving are so low - below living wages if measured on an hourly basis and compared to union rates - the revenue from ticket sales will be split evenly between all the members of the team to help boost their income.  The value of the work and the time they put in is important to recognize and to respect.
  • The total amount I need to fundraise as the producer in order to cover the production costs is $1,505.
  • Depending on the amount you donate, you can receive free tickets to the show and/or a copy of the artwork from our poster.
  • Regardless of whether or not we reach our fundraising goal, the production will move forward.  The show must go on!!!

The Impact

  • As with my past play Dreaming in Autism, my goal is to have autism talked about in the media and to have the issues of lack of services and acceptance raised.  With my last show, I was able to have autism talked about on radio in English and French and in newspapers.  
  • The audience members will come away with a new experience about autism and hopefully have new attitudes that lend support to families and autistic people.
  • An important factor about this production is inclusion.  We have an actor who is on the autism spectrum.  We also have artists taking part who are ethnically diverse, Afro- and Asian-Canadians.  Lastly, roughly only a fifth of plays produced are directed or written by women.  In this case, we have a women director and a woman playwright.
  • You must visit www.latigressaproductions.com to see all the work that I've done as a playwright, actor and producer so you can feel confident that your donation is going to a good project.
  • As a mother of a child with autism, I'm passionate about this project and I hope you'll join in this theatrical event.

Risks & Challenges

As with any work of art, evaluation is subjective.  Some may love the show, some may hate it.  That is the reality every artist faces puting their creation out there for the public to see.  What I can promise is that this show is being produced with every care in the world.  It is a personal issue for me.  What I want to do, what all the team members want to do, is to make autism shine

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to our production, there are other ways that you can help.

  • Spread the word about the play and the campaign.
  • You can share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook and Twitter via the sharing tools on this page.

We are ever so greatful for your support of the arts, the cause of autism acceptance and the issue of lack of support for families and those with autism.

The total project budget is $5,180.  This includes salaries for 10 artists and collaborators (director, 5 actors, stage manager, set designer, light designer & sound designer.  Discover the team at www.theautismmonologues.com).  It also includes the set design elements and props,  rehearsal space, marketing costs (graphic design, promotional cards and posters, and a show program) and the Fringe Festival participation fee.
I am making a personal investment of $3,000 in this production.  A studio residence from Montreal, arts interculturels will save us $675 in rental fees for a rehearsal space. 
Because the salaries the team members are receiving are so low - below living wages if measured on an hourly basis and compared to union rates - the revenue from ticket sales will be split evenly between all the members of the team to help boost their income.  The value of the work and the time they put in is important to recognize and to respect.
The total amount I need to fundraise as the producer in order to cover the production costs is $1,505.
Depending on the amount you donate, you can receive free tickets to the show and/or a copy of the artwork from our poster.
Regardless of whether or not we reach our fundraising goal, the production will move forward.  The show must go on!!!


The Impact

As with my past play Dreaming in Autism, my goal is to have autism talked about in the media and to have the issues of lack of services and acceptance raised.  With my last show, I was able to have autism talked about on radio in English and French and in newspapers.  
The audience members will come away with a new experience about autism and hopefully have new attitudes that lend support to families and autistic people.
An important factor about this production is inclusion.  We have an actor who is on the autism spectrum.  We also have artists taking part who are ethnically diverse, Afro- and Asian-Canadians.  Lastly, roughly only a fifth of plays produced are directed or written by women.  In this case, we have a women director and a woman playwright.
You must visit www.latigressaproductions.com to see all the work that I've done as a playwright, actor and producer so you can feel confident that your donation is going to a good project.
As a mother of a child with autism, I'm passionate about this project and I hope you'll join in this theatrical event.


Risks & Challenges
As with any work of art, evaluation is subjective.  Some may love the show, some may hate it.  That is the reality every artist faces puting their creation out there for the public to see.  What I can promise is that this show is being produced with every care in the world.  It is a personal issue for me.  What I want to do, what all the team members want to do, is to make autism shine

Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute to our production, there are other ways that you can help.

Spread the word about the play and the campaign.
You can share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook and Twitter via the sharing tools on this page.

We are ever so greatful for your support of the arts, the cause of autism acceptance and the issue of lack of support for families and those with autism.

story:
On Friday, January 25th, 2019 The DynamitExperience (TDE) will perform its Inaugural Show at The Mark O’Donnell Theatre at The Actors Fund Theatre in Brooklyn, NY. This performance is a huge step for me and the vision I have for TDE.

TDE is creating a platform for artistic excellence, collaboration, conversation, and storytelling and we need your help. 

Our goal is to raise $1,500 to cover the expenses of the artists, collaborators, studio rentals, performance venue, and administrative work; all the factors that go into producing a show and launching a working company.

The DynamitExperience  is a creative collective that serves as a platform for all the artistic endeavors of myself and TDE Team. We seek ways to activate and contribute to the local community with dance at its core on and off the marley. By creating original ballets that reflect the rich history of our people that will serve as the foundation for a dance institution in the future, we will fulfill our purpose of bringing dance back to the community that looks like us on the very rich soil we cultivated.

 

This performance is a small glimpse of the trajectory of TDE; an arch between past, present and future.The past will take the form of three repertory works and we will premiere 3 works illustrating both present growth and the direction of our future. The ballets touch upon loss, identity, barriers, the people of Kansas City, and even the complex relationship between Adam and Eve. What I hope to convey weaving in traditional court dance, partnering, modern technique and a contemporary aesthetic is to create a dialogue that expresses the vulnerability of this collective as we strive to find our place in this world; one that is uniquely inherent to our experience. Relationships are how we navigate the world and I want to explore that with you.

 

My dream is to create a space and body of work that my mom, dad, uncle, and aunts would not only want to experience but can see their stories portrayed and woven into a beautiful artistic tapestry. How can TDE be a conduit that communicates to my people while creating a dialogue that ultimately will inform our work? I want the audience to feel something and in turn spark a conversation with their neighbor.

 

No donation is too small and your contribution can help shape a path for our future in this crucial time.

 

I do hope you join us on this inaugural journey and thank you for considering this request.

story:
The Abstract

Why Drag?

Drag is one of the few art-forms that incorporates all facets of the artistic world. Visual art, performance, music, film, story-telling, dance, fashion, singing, acting, and makeup are all accessible through drag.  It's a wide range of possibility that gives an artist complete creative freedom, making drag one of the most powerful modes of creative expression of our time.

Why Millicent?

Millicent, created by Paul Regan, isn't as much a character as she is a statement against the reigning notion that drag should act as an escape.  While this notion is valid in it's own right, and has undoubtedly helped countless people through horrible circumstances, Millicent believes that there also exists a community of people who find solace, not through escape, but through being challenged to think, challenged to feel, challenged to question and challenged to experience the uncomfortable rawness of vulnerability both in others and within themselves.  Millicent is a means of reaching these people - the shy ones, the insecure ones, the emotionally raw members of the LGTBQ+ community, largely underrepresented and wholly misunderstood - so that they might understand that their voices matter, and that their voices need to be heard.

Why Look Queen?

Millicent's ongoing creative development is thanks largely to Look Queen.  The competition's loose requirements and its emphasis on creative performance allows her the freedom to express her drag in a way that is meaningful to her. Her entry into the competition's finale in August is an extension of this - the expression of her drag on a larger scale - a way to further her growth and expand her platform.

The Concrete

How much money?

$3,000

Why so much?

Visual spectacle is a huge component of drag.  Not only is it an art-form and means of creative expression in and of itself, but it also acts as a visual primer - a hook by which an audience can be immediately transported into the world that the performer is trying to convey.  The downside?  Visuals are outrageously expensive.

What will my money pay for?

Three different costumes (a requirement of the competition) constructed from head to toe by Millicent.

-- (This includes - fabric, trimmings, needles, thread, zippers, Velcro, wigs, shoes, stockings, corsets, pattern drafting supplies/test fabric, hooks & eyes, hot glue, jewelry, costume-lenses, hats and more)

Pay for musicians - Millicent's performance number (the largest component of the competition) requires the help of two live musicians.

-- (Pay for them would include multiple rehearsals, travel expense, food and of course the performance itself)

Equipment - Millicent's performance number also requires the help of sound equipment.

-- (Specifically - An amp, a microphone complete with stand, and extension chords)

Promotion - Visual promotion via a strong online presence is essential to audience building.  While not directly tied to Look Queen, it nonetheless plays a vital role in what Millicent hopes to achieve as a drag performer and as a contestant.

-- (This includes lighting equipment and backdrops)

How will I know that my money is well spent?

Anyone who donates $5 or more will receive a link to a Google Sheet where Millicent will be documenting each and every project-related transaction.  There will be absolutely no doubt as to where your money is going.

And If I can't donate?

You can still help by sharing this campaign with others, by keeping in touch with Millicent through social media and by appearing at the Manhattan Monster Bar on Sunday August 26th to cheer for Millicent until your vocal chords snap.

story:
Fog Beast is a live art collective initiated and driven by Melecio Estrella and Andrew Ward.  Our mission is to research, create, and perform accessible dance based art works that demand spontaneity, connectivity, and engagement with the immediate surroundings and local community.

 We are making our first evening length work!

Move Here

October 19, 20, 27, 28 8pm

 

We have been fortunate to be in artistic residency at Shawl Anderson Dance Center this year.  In our explorations we have been talking to the walls and humans of the space, dancing with doorways, singing songs to the floor, and contemplating the ripples that a 54 year old dance school has sent out into the world.  

We see Shawl Anderson as a living example of a place for dance that gives way to a sense of community. It is a place for different bodies and styles to coexist and cross pollinate. It is welcoming and humble in its appearance while being rigorous and in depth in its dancing. 

Move Here will take place in multiple spaces throughout the dance center.  We have assembled a brilliant cast of creatives to breathe life into our show...

  • Ben Juodvalkis (Musician, Composer)
  • Diana Strong (Musician, Composer
  • Damara Ganley (Choreography, Performance)
  • Caroline Alexander (Choreography, Performance)
  • Jono Brandel (Media, Visuals)

Any amount you can contribute is greatly appreciated!

We are raising funds toward..

  • Artist Fees- Our professional level collaborators are in demand and deserving of a respectful stipend. We aim to pay them as much as our budget allows, to make this show strong, and to make sure we can all continue to create art in the world.
  • Lighting and Sound- Shawl Anderson is a dance school normally, and we are turning it into a multi faceted performance venue. With appropriate equipment rented, we can create an environment that is both comfortable and transporting. 
  • Stage Management/Show Flow Support- Move Here will move audiences through multiple areas of the dance center. Having a stage manager will help the show run smoothly and have all the details tended to. 

Please check out our PERKS, we would love to include you in our Fog Beast community and show our appreciation for your generosity.

Your contributions will help us take grow into this new phase of our dancing lives.  In addition to dancing in others' projects, we are now realizing our own ideas of what a live art event can be.  Your generosity gives Fog Beast its legs, wings, fangs and pulsing heart.

Thanks so much! Please consider sharing this page, talk about our show with friends that might be interested, and COME to Move Here on October 19,20,27,28!!

story:
ReActive Dance Theatre is a product of a creative partnership between Rhanda Jones & Amanda Pye that began during their time in Ryerson University's Dance Program. During their time at school, they had the opportunity to explore what they truly wanted to say as artists, and how they wanted to contribute to the dance community. 

ReActive Dance Theatre is the outcome. 

As a company, we hope to explore many social, political, & humanistic themes. Dancers, artists, everyday people...Join us on our journey through our times. 

We know how we would ReAct, what about you?

https://www.facebook.com/ReActiveDanceTheatre

Support

ReActive Dance Theatre presents our first full-length work, "one".

Join ReActive Dance Theatre as we explore what it truly means to help another human being. 

"I watch from far away, wishing I could know how you feel, how you see, how you hurt... how you hope."

The company is partnering with the foundation L.I.F.E. for Health to create an evening of dance that will support and display the effect of the foundations positive work.

A portion of the tickets sales will be donated directly to L.I.F.E for Health. www.lifeforhealth.org

 

To ensure that there will be a significant contribution towards L.I.F.E. for Health, ReActive Dance Theatre has begun this campaign to raise funds that will go towards supporting the hardworking dance artists involved in the project. 

ReActive Dance Theatre began this rehearsal process in Decemeber. An audition was held, and 4 dancers were cast to take part in the new work. Each dance artist entered with creative and artistic passion for the project, but also towards contrubuting to L.I.F.E. for Health.

It is very imporatnt to ReActive Dance Theatre that these artists are compensated for their passion and commitment to this project. 

Our goal for this campaign is $1000, but any contribution, small or large, will be greatly appreciated!

The Impact

Your contribution will allow for ReActive Dance Theatre to contribute further to the work of L.I.F.E for Health. 

Please take the time to explore their important work: www.lifeforhealth.org

Your contribution will also contribute to the growth of the Toronto arts and dance community. Your support will not only allow ReActive Dance Theatre to share their artistic vision, but will support the importance of the arts within our community. 

Join us!

We would love to see you at our first show!

Join ReActive Dance Theatre on Saturday, February 2nd at 8pm.

Dancemakers Centre for Creation

9 Trinity Street, Studio, Toronto, ON M5A 3C4

Tickets are $15 at the door!

Be sure to join us for complimentary food & drink after the performance!

 

Check us out on Facbook: https://www.facebook.com/ReActiveDanceTheatre

THANK YOU!

story:
Dear friends, family, and supporters of the arts,

I am graduating from the University of Montana this May with my BFA in dance. To complete my degree I am collaborating with other artists to put on a show that will be presented in an art gallery, The Artist Shop, on May 3rd in downtown Missoula, MT. The show is a collaboration between myself and other artists including William Munoz (photographer), Meghan Nolt (photographer), Aaron Minnick (music composer), Claire Christensen (dancer), Allison Herther (dancer), Amelia Hufsmith (dancer), Kaitlin Kinsley (dancer), Morgan Mull-Osborn (dancer), Amanda Pool (dancer) and Ellie Weinman (dancer). 

We are combining our art forms to create an evening of live dance, photography, video projection, and original music composition. The small space of The Artist Shop will offer the audience an intimate experience.  Performance as installation removes the 4th wall of a proscenium stage and the audience is interactive with the dancers.  There’s little distinction between audience and performer.

Why now?  Why me?  Why this project?

This is the first time I am presenting work outside of the University. It is a wonderful opportunity for my artistic growth as an emerging artist in my community. For the past five years I have been investigating my creative voice. I constanly question  myself why I want to create dance. Some of the reasons are to reach people, to question our society or to simply admire a moving body. Dance is my medium to create challenging and hopefully inspiring conversations about our world.

In order for this show to be successful my collaborators and I need help! Your contributions will be greatly appreciated.

What will they go toward?

- Prints of photographs

- Costumes: fabric

- Advertising

We feel very grateful to have the support of the University of Montana dance department for rehearsal space and the use of a projector.

Funds raised over our goal amount will go directly towards the hard work of the dancers, photographers, and music composer.

Stay tuned for updates on the project including photographs and videos! Spread the word, bring your friends, and thank you for the support!

story:
Speak Easy Secrets

This may be the first immersive ballet performance ever!

So take the jitney to the juice joint and go knock knees with all the Hoofers on the East Side.

This is my first large-scale work in London, after many years of successful evenings of dance in NYC. I am collaborating with a team of amazing women to create an interactive performance as we create a new context for ballet that makes it available to a wider public. This performance takes off from my work in NYC as President of Norte Maar (www.nortemaar.org) where collaboration is at the heart of every project. But this is the first time I am doing it in London (with a little long-distance help from Norte Maar).

I always dreamed of working with my strong female friends on a production, offering opportunities to ballet dancers, especially those that have diverse backgrounds (some might say, the dissatisfied ballet dancers). Ballet is a tough career and with new contexts it can be brought into focus in more communities as the relevant, living dance form it can be. 

We will transform the theatre with raised performance area and cabaret seating. The performance will begin for each audience member upon entering the venue, passing through rooms with different scenes, waiters and dancers manipulating the action: some action framed for audience to witness, some involving them. The story revolves around 2 women, 2 men, and their changing relationships – partly performance-framed, partly voyeuristic. Are they ordinary guests? Evelyn's a socialite. She's friends with Geraldine, a bit of a wallflower. They're on a double date with inventor, Clarence and Frank, who doesn't like to say what he does for a living.

 

Why am I asking you to help us fund this production?

Ballet is expensive to produce. We intend to give it a new attitude and provide a few more jobs. There are a large number of graduates who are eager to create and to perform. And there is a demand. Barking (East London) has an eager audience. I intend to create a new life for a ballet that is contemporary in its outlook, accessible in its presentation and joyful. Theatre can be a celebration of wonder as all the parts come together and provide a world of experience.  I have dreamed of creating a theatre in which the audience feels as involved as the dancers, where sitting in the dark is not restrictive and distractions become part of the action. My team and I can make this happen, but the costs are high. 

We need money for people. The people who create the show. They are the show and their commitment is most often unmet by the fees they are paid. I intend to use this money to pay them for their time and their creativity.

  • stage management (this is a complex show and requires multiple management points).
  • designers and their materials.
  • a lighting designer who will be working in a non-traditional dance setting with new angles and opportunities.
  • dancers fees.

And the perks are awesome. A walking tour with Michelle Buckley is the perfect way to discover London. And who knows what kind of Speakeasy "thank you" you might receive during the show!

Tickets available at: http://www.thebroadwaybarking.com/event/speak-e...

And if you can't send money, send some love by sharing this on facebook and recommending us to your friends. 

Thank you for looking,

Julia

We will transform the theatre with raised performance area and cabaret seating. The performance will begin for each audience member upon entering the venue, passing through rooms with different scenes, waiters and dancers manipulating the action: some action framed for audience to witness, some involving them. The story revolves around 2 women, 2 men, and their changing relationships – partly performance-framed, partly voyeuristic. Are they ordinary guests? Evelyn's a socialite. She's friends with Geraldine, a bit of a wallflower. They're on a double date with inventor, Clarence and Frank, who doesn't like to say what he does for a living.
 
Why am I asking you to help us fund this production?
Ballet is expensive to produce. We intend to give it a new attitude and provide a few more jobs. There are a large number of graduates who are eager to create and to perform. And there is a demand. Barking (East London) has an eager audience. I intend to create a new life for a ballet that is contemporary in its outlook, accessible in its presentation and joyful. Theatre can be a celebration of wonder as all the parts come together and provide a world of experience.  I have dreamed of creating a theatre in which the audience feels as involved as the dancers, where sitting in the dark is not restrictive and distractions become part of the action. My team and I can make this happen, but the costs are high. 
We need money for people. The people who create the show. They are the show and their commitment is most often unmet by the fees they are paid. I intend to use this money to pay them for their time and their creativity.

stage management (this is a complex show and requires multiple management points).
designers and their materials.
a lighting designer who will be working in a non-traditional dance setting with new angles and opportunities.
dancers fees.

And the perks are awesome. A walking tour with Michelle Buckley is the perfect way to discover London. And who knows what kind of Speakeasy "thank you" you might receive during the show!


Tickets available at: http://www.thebroadwaybarking.com/event/speak-e...



And if you can't send money, send some love by sharing this on facebook and recommending us to your friends. 
Thank you for looking,
Julia

story:
Short Summary

Owasso High School Drama Department has been selected as one of the top high schools to represent the United States at the American High School Theatre Festival in Edinburgh, Scotland August 2013. As part of the International Fringe Festival (the world's largest arts festival), students will get the chance to perform in front of an international audience and experience art from over 2,000 different companies from around the world. 

You can make a difference! Our school has already raised over $60,000 by completing 34 different fundraisers this year, and we only have $13,000 left to raise by June 14. Please make a difference in these kids lives. If you want the arts to thrive in the US, invest in our youth!

We are developing an original theatre piece that captures the relationship contemporary Oklahomans have with our history. The following is a detailed description of the story:

"On July 5,1870 the Osage Reservation was established and built a house near Pawhuska, Oklahoma: Twin Oaks. The people begin to die at an alarming rate due to the lack of supplies and the unexpectedly cold Oklahoma winters. White Feather, the last of the Osage Spider Guardian needs supernatural help to save her people. 140 years later, a modern day court case looms. A lawyer comes to stay at Twin Oaks, a house with many secrets. Emily, his daughter, simply wants to complete her art portfolio and get out of this po-dunk town as soon as possible, but she feels a connection to the house and its mysteries, especially to a ghost who still protects it. White Feather has come back from the world of the spirits and she needs Emily's help to see her people's memory safe into the next century, and beyond. "

Written by Jennifer Steen Wendorf based on a novel by her mother, The Ghost of Twin Oaks, will be a captivating performance for all ages. This one-act has a running time of 60 minutes and includes creative staging, costumes, and set on a shoe-string budget. Most of our expenses result from travel and boarding. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

As part of the program, each student and chaperone needs to raise $6,445 to cover the cost of airfare, lodging, meals, ground transportation, and production costs. As this is part of the world's largest arts festival, all of those items are at a high value this time of year in Edinburgh. We have 9 students and 4 chaperones scheduled to attend. We a so close to our goal and you can help! In exchange, we have the following gifts for you:

$25 pledge = Special thanks in our international playbill, copy of video, 2 tickets to any performance.

$100= Special thanks in our international playbill, copy of video, signed cast photo, 4 tickets

$300=  ½ page ad in our international program, copy of video, 8 tickets, Signed cast photo

$500= Full page ad in our international program, copy of video, 8 tickets, and a signed cast photo

The good news is that even if we don't reach our goal, the funds still go toward the students' trips. 

The Impact

The entire purpose behind our theatre program is to build empathy in our students. The process of creating a character requires that you imagine a different world than your own, you must step outside of yourself and look at the needs of others. In addition to this, students will be exposed to artists from around the world operating on a shoe-string budget. Every space is cannabalized for art during the Fringe Frestival. They will see how a restaurant, a hallway, and a street corner can all be platforms for artistic expression. They will come home empowered; knowing that they are capable of creating their own artistic opportunities. They will also remember the great gifts that theatre, music, and dance are for the world community. Through those, we begin to see life from another person's perspective. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to our campaign, pass along the link to your friends! Like our facebook page- Owasso High School Expressions!

story:
Doctor and Mister are emissaries from the future of another planet. They are collecting big Earth things to take home. Geography, History, Politics, Ecology, Personality, YouTube Comment Sections, and The Dancing Plague of 1518 — all fit snugly inside the Loaded Capsule.

What, you ask, does this mean?

It means that we, Rick Burkhardt and Eugene Ma, two experimental NYC music- and theater-makers, have put together a collection of our favorite experimental musicians, dramatists, and storytellers, and we want to show them to you!

The performance is just around the corner!

The first installment from the Loaded Capsule takes place

April 4-7, 2013, 8pm at JACK
505 1/2 Waverly Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11238

Between Fulton and Atlantic in Clinton Hill (C or G train to Clinton-Washington)

And boy, are there a lot of performers:

 

Eugene Ma
Jessica Jelliffe
Omar Perez
Brian DeCaluwe
Michael Bauer
Rick Burkhardt
John Murchison
Radical 2 (Levy Lorenzo and Dennis Sullivan)
Cadillac Moon Ensemble (Roberta Michel, Patty Kilroy, Meaghan Burke, Sean Statser)
James Monaco
Jerome Ellis

 

and the Built for Collapse all-stars:

Sanaz Ghajarrahimi
Ben Hobbs
Dan Stearns
Chloe Markewich
Sean Roschman
Kelley Stanley
Jennifer Waxman
Magnolia Santibanez
Susie Williams
with Vincent Santvoord as J. Alfred Prufrock

with songs by Anne Washburn, Kirk Bromley, and Rick Burkhardt

So many musicians, actors, dancers... can we possibly be doing all this for FREE?  Yes — ALMOST!  But there are expenses and oh my god New York is expensive.

Please help us make this amazing show amazinger with whatever you can donate.  Every tiny bit helps.  Web expenses, food expenses (yes, we plan to ply the audience with snacks), publicity expenses...  any tiny amount you donate will help us chip away at the monolith before us.

Thank you!  Come to the Loaded Capsule!!!

story:
Jazz is dead. Jazz lives. Long live Jazz. Premiering at Seattle’s On The Boards in January 2015, The Holler Sessions is a rude, dynamic and desperate love letter to jazz, created and performed by TEAM member Frank Boyd.

From a cramped and cluttered booth in Kansas City, an explosive DJ named Ray broadcasts his love of jazz music with an eccentric passion and total irreverence. The Holler Sessions includes loud music, profanity, poetry, silence, improvisation and a singular devotion to inspiring a more visceral and emotional experience of jazz – and to the belief that it is America’s truest expression of itself.

Why We Need Your Help

Originally conceived of during another TEAM project’s development, The Holler Sessions took on a life of its own when Frank returned to Seattle and continued creating the piece. Green-lit for On The Boards’ 2014-15 season, The Holler Sessions will be the TEAM’s first time working in the Northwest, and the first time we’re co-producing with a member of the company.

Rachel and Matty will fly to Seattle in October for two weeks of final development, and back again in January to open the show, and we need your help to get them there! Your donation will directly underwrite the transportation of our collaborators from one coast to the other, and ensure that everyone gets a paycheck for their work on the show.

Can’t give money? What about airline miles?

Getting everyone back and forth across the country for development and performances is our biggest expense. If you’ve racked up miles that are burning a hole in your pocket, we can certainly put them to use! Email us at hello@theteamplays.org and we’ll figure out what hoops we need to jump through with your miles program.

About the TEAM

The TEAM is a Brooklyn-based ensemble dedicated to creating new work about the experience of living in America today. Once described as “Gertrude Stein meets MTV,” the TEAM’s work crashes American history and mythology into modern stories to illuminate the current moment. We combine aggressive athleticism with emotional performances and intellectual rigor, keeping the brain, eyes and heart of the audience constantly stimulated. Founded in 2004, we have created and toured 9 works (and counting!) nationally and internationally, and will celebrate 10 years together in December. For more information about our company and our work, visit theteamplays.org.

About Frank

Frank is a theater artist based in Seattle. In addition to his work with the TEAM, Frank is a member of NYC's Elevator Repair Service, with whom he performed in Gatz and The Select (The Sun Also Rises). Other recent projects include the world premiers of The Amazing Adventures of Kavalier & Clay (Book-It Rep) and Red Speedo (Studio Theatre).

story:
Columbia University School of the Arts Presents

Mr. E’s Humongous Underground Digital Vaudeville Extravaganza!!!  

Live via video-chat, Mr. E hosts an AMAZING ENTERTAINING DAZZLING DISPLAY OF HETEROGENOUS SPLENDOR.  Only a year after the Edward Snowden leaked NSA documents revealed that we are all being spied on by Uncle Sam, this wily whistleblower surprises us yet again by unveiling a variety show featuring 10 incredible acts that will thrill the senses!  They’ll be songs, sketches, tricks and death defying acts all brought together into one show for your viewing pleasure.

This show is being developed for Anne Bogart's Devised Political Theatre class at Columbia University. Michael Scholar, Jr. is a second-year MFA Directing candidate and is the Artistic Producer of November Theatre. www.novembertheatre.com

Team:

Conceived and Directed by Michael Scholar, Jr.

Co-Created by The Ensemble

Composer: Keith Patchel

Movement Coach: Samantha Sheppard

Stage Manager: Alayna Graziani

Scenic Designer: You-Shin Chen

Lighting Designer: Derek Van Heel

Assistant Lighting Designer: Peter Mitchell

Video Designer: Gianni Carson

General Manager/Producer: Connor Davis

Graphic Designer: Amanda McAllister

Performers:

Michael Bauer*

Jazmine Dinkins

Jack Fellows*

Marlene Ginader

Harrison Greene

Emilie Gruat

and Jeff Moulton as Mr. E

*Member of Actors' Equity Association

Where:

Columbia University

Schapiro Theatre

605 W. 115th Street

October 24-26, 2014

Why we need the funding?

It won’t cost you anything to experience Mr E’s Humongous Underground Digital Vaudeville Extravaganza!!!, but we do need the funds to make the experience a reality. We are looking to raise at least $500 to mount this presentation. Your contribution will help us pay for the following items.

1.  Acquiring and purchasing the physical props, costumes, gear and other items needed to create the world of Mr. E’s Humungous Underground Digital Vaudeville Extravaganza in the Schapiro Studio Theatre.

2.  Our award-winning collaborators deserve to be compensated for the amazing work that we can’t wait to present to you.

story:
The Play

We Were Here was inspired by the true stories of Donna Harvey, Jean Dreckman, Susan Page, and Delena Jensen, who served in the American Defense Industry during WWII. Through interviews and research, playwright Rachell Campbell compiled their stories to create a "friendship play." Before Rachell interviewed Susie, now in her 90's, her daughter Tina said, "I am so glad you are talking to her. This may be the last time she ever tells her story to someone who doesn't already know it." Tina's powerful statement represents the reason for the existence of this play and why Efficacy Theatre Co. is dedicated to its production. We want to preserve the legacy of Rosie the Riveters so that everyone might know they were here. 

-Rachell Campbell is an L.A. playwright with a passion for telling the stories of women. Rachell holds a B.A. in Theatre Arts from Azusa Pacific University and an M.F.A. in Creative Writing for the Performing Arts from UC Riverside. 

The Support

Your support of this project will ensure that the stories of these incredible women will be remembered. By supporting We Were Here, you are not simply investing in a piece of theatre, but additionally sustaining a piece American oral history.

The Money

We are attempting to raise $500 to be able to tell this story to the best of our ability. The cost of our production is relatively low because the following talents, spaces, and supplies have already been donated to our project. 

  • The Space - The Bay Church is allowing us to use their stage for rehearsals and productions for free. (usual facility rental cost per production - $1,200-$3,000)
  • The Script - As a Co-Founder of Efficacy Theatre Co., playwright Rachell Campbell is not requiring payment for the use of her script. (usual royalty fees - $75/performance + the cost of scripts) 
  • The Printing - The Bay Church is generously contributing to all of our printing costs for marketing materials. (usual cost - $200 - $1000 for a small production)
  • The Cast & Crew -Efficacy Theatre Co. was created by a family of artists dedicated to creating excellent work. In the pursuit of this effort, extraordinary artists and craftsmen have donated their time and talent to this project. Our company is comprised entirely of unpaid volunteers. (usual cost of a stage manager alone for a small theatre company - $1,000 rehearsal stipend + $75/performance, this does not include the designers/operators for lighting, set, and sound or the actors) 
  • Total Savings: $2,250+ 
Then this may beg the question, "if you are getting all of that for free, what are you raising money for?" We are incredibly lucky to be able to put on this show at a relatively low-cost, however we still need funds for the following: 

Additional Needs:

  • Sets - we are building four backdrop walls. These cost about $50 a piece plus the cost of grey paint. 
  • Set dressing - the play takes place in an abandoned storage closet. We need to find, restore, or purchase items to create the atmosphere of a 1940's storage closet at an airplane factory. 
  • Props - this play has a lot of props including a whole and edible apple pie which we will need to purchase new before every show. 
  • Costumes - The women will likely be in the same uniform for the whole of the show, but uniform rentals run from $25 - $50 per outfit per character for the run of the show. 
  • Collaborator Compensation - Although our company is comprised entirely of unpaid volunteers, some of them have very long commutes. We are raising funds so that we might be able to chip in for some gas.
  • Postage - Although all of our printing is free, we need to pay for the postage on all mailers, funding request letters, thank you cards, etc...
  • *Of Note: 

    • Our goal is $500 because we wanted to set a goal that we could meet with utter certainty.
    • If we do not raise the full $500, we will take any funds that we have raised and put on the production on a more limited scale.  
    • The actual ideal budget for the production is $1,000. We will make the production on $200 or $2 Million, it will just have some effect on the quality of the design elements. The play itself will be excellent either way. 
    • If we exceed our goal and make more than $1,000, some of what is left will pay the cast, crew, and designers a slightly larger gas stipend and the rest will go toward investing in future productions at Efficacy Theatre Co. 

The Impact

This play has already had a significant impact on audiences. It was once produced at a university and was reviewed by many of the students. Below are some of their comments:

  • “Upon leaving the theatre I felt inspired to use my female ingenuity to make it through the hardships of life. If those women could do it, then why can’t I?”

  • "In all honesty, I thought this play was going to be dull and irrelevant to the present since its setting is WWII, so I thought I would be sitting in another history lecture, but to my surprise this is one of the best plays I have had the privilege to attend.” 

  •  "Susan, Jean, Donna, and Ida have such a beautiful bond, the kind of which is by and large restricted to male friendships in contemporary media. These women are empowered, autonomous, and dynamic characters, and their story is one that inspires not only women, but all people to carry on through adversity.”

  • “We Were Here is one of the most wonderful and perfect plays I have ever seen.”

The Risks & Challenges

Every project will have its ups and downs. This production has been three years in the making. Two of the actors have been with the playwright since the play's inception and we have a solid group of artists who make up the team in its entirety. The biggest difficulty we face is time. Because we are a volunteer-based operation were are attempting to keep time commitments low. This means that we have a shorter rehearsal period than is usually done for shows of this length. It should not be an issue, as our cast and crew are ready for the challenge, but it could be a cause for concern. We are combatting this by doing as much work remotely as possible. The actors will be doing their character work and memorization off-site. Sets, props etc... will be ready upon the first rehearsal so that blocking can begin immediately. We are taking every precaution to make sure that our short timeline will be a blessing and not a deterrent.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need volunteers! We still need a few people to join our team. If you are interested in volunteering with us please e-mail us at efficacyinquires@gmail.com. Thank you!
