Our company is comprised entirely of unpaid volunteers. (usual cost of a stage manager alone for a small theatre company - $1,000 rehearsal stipend + $75/performance, this does not include the designers/operators for lighting, set, and sound or the actors) 

Total Savings: $2,250+ 

Then this may beg the question, "if you are getting all of that for free, what are you raising money for?" We are incredibly lucky to be able to put on this show at a relatively low-cost, however we still need funds for the following: Additional Needs:


Sets - we are building four backdrop walls. These cost about $50 a piece plus the cost of grey paint. 
Set dressing - the play takes place in an abandoned storage closet. We need to find, restore, or purchase items to create the atmosphere of a 1940's storage closet at an airplane factory. 
Props - this play has a lot of props including a whole and edible apple pie which we will need to purchase new before every show. 
Costumes - The women will likely be in the same uniform for the whole of the show, but uniform rentals run from $25 - $50 per outfit per character for the run of the show. 
Collaborator Compensation - Although our company is comprised entirely of unpaid volunteers, some of them have very long commutes. We are raising funds so that we might be able to chip in for some gas.
Postage - Although all of our printing is free, we need to pay for the postage on all mailers, funding request letters, thank you cards, etc...

*Of Note: 

Our goal is $500 because we wanted to set a goal that we could meet with utter certainty.
If we do not raise the full $500, we will take any funds that we have raised and put on the production on a more limited scale.  
The actual ideal budget for the production is $1,000. We will make the production on $200 or $2 Million, it will just have some effect on the quality of the design elements. The play itself will be excellent either way. 

If we exceed our goal and make more than $1,000, some of what is left will pay the cast, crew, and designers a slightly larger gas stipend and the rest will go toward investing in future productions at Efficacy Theatre Co. 


 
The Impact
This play has already had a significant impact on audiences. It was once produced at a university and was reviewed by many of the students. Below are some of their comments: 

“Upon leaving the theatre I felt inspired to use my female ingenuity to make it through the hardships of life. If those women could do it, then why can’t I?”
 
"In all honesty, I thought this play was going to be dull and irrelevant to the present since its setting is WWII, so I thought I would be sitting in another history lecture, but to my surprise this is one of the best plays I have had the privilege to attend.” 




 "Susan, Jean, Donna, and Ida have such a beautiful bond, the kind of which is by and large restricted to male friendships in contemporary media. These women are empowered, autonomous, and dynamic characters, and their story is one that inspires not only women, but all people to carry on through adversity.”
 
“We Were Here is one of the most wonderful and perfect plays I have ever seen.”
 
  The Risks & Challenges  Every project will have its ups and downs. This production has been three years in the making. Two of the actors have been with the playwright since the play's inception and we have a solid group of artists who make up the team in its entirety. The biggest difficulty we face is time. Because we are a volunteer-based operation were are attempting to keep time commitments low. This means that we have a shorter rehearsal period than is usually done for shows of this length. It should not be an issue, as our cast and crew are ready for the challenge, but it could be a cause for concern. We are combatting this by doing as much work remotely as possible. The actors will be doing their character work and memorization off-site. Sets, props etc... will be ready upon the first rehearsal so that blocking can begin immediately. We are taking every precaution to make sure that our short timeline will be a blessing and not a deterrent.
  Other Ways You Can Help We need volunteers! We still need a few people to join our team. If you are interested in volunteering with us please e-mail us at efficacyinquires@gmail.com. Thank you!

story:
Brenda, You Say?! 

Cory and Ashley have been developing this play since Fall 2012. It grew out of our desire to colloborate, and we've nourished it with nearly a year's worth of brainstorms, rewrites, and late-night planning sessions.

The show is set to premiere in the New York International Fringe Festival this August. It's an ambitious project -- a big creative challenge that requires a substantial amount of money for production. That's why we need your help!

BRENDA follows Wallace, who's fled his chaotic Kentucky family and is living a lonely little life in Denver. When a delayed flight makes him miss his mother's funeral, his suppressed guilt begins haunting his body and transforming it in startling ways. Soon, Wallace, his deadbeat roommate, and his reluctant coworker are launched into a desperate cross-country road trip back home. BRENDA is a demented black comedy about what we owe the people who gave us life, and how we face the inevitability of death. 

Ashley is a director/producer/stage manager who has developed shows at Ars Nova, the New York Fringe Festival, and Yale University and has worked at Manhattan Theatre Club, The Public, and on Broadway with Richards/Climan. 

Cory is a playwright whose work has been produced and developed at and by Ars Nova, Theater for the New City, ACT Theater (Seattle), The Brick, and Yale University. He's a member of Youngblood, the playwrights' group at Ensemble Studio Theater. 

Any amount that you contribute will help us get that much closer to producing our show in the Fringe. As young artists in New York, we rarely have opportunities like this to mount not a reading or a workshop but a fully-staged production. Thank you in advance for your help!

What Will I Get For My Money?:

Your contributions will help... 

  • Pay for things you see onstage--sets, props, costumes, etc.
  • Help get the word out about the show so that people (like you!) come to see it
  • Help Cory and Ashley to make the show possible!

Can't Donate? You can still help!

  • Facebook/Tweet about the show and about our campaign!
  • Tell your friends in real life with your real words about the show/campaign!
  • Come see the show in August in the NY Fringe Festival!

Aaaaad....there it is. 

 

BRENDA

Performing at Robert Moss Theater at 440 Studios; 

TUE 8/13 @ 4:45pm
FRI 8/16 @ 2:00pm
SUN 8/18 @ 7:00pm 
FRI 8/23 @ 9:15pm 
SAT 8/24 @ 2:00pm

story:
Summary

ABOUT FOLLOWING SEAS

Following Seas Productions fosters to human-to-sea relationship through dynamic theatrical experiences and artistic advocacy.

ARRRRRR!!! WOULDN'T YOU LOVE TO SEE A LIVE-ACTION ADAPTATION OF TREASURE ISLAND?

We are performing a free-to-the-public, directly-on-the-beach adaptation of Robert Louis Stevenson's pirate classic, TREASURE ISLAND to open at the Belmont Pier Pirate Invasion. The Belmont Pier Pirate Invasion is a free community event that attracted 8,000 people last year and is projected to attracted many more in 2013.

TREASURE ISLAND is a widely-loved, influential classic literary work that is significantly responsible for lasting popular perceptions of pirate culture. Imbued with atmospheric period and nautical slang, TREASURE ISLAND is an action-packed buccaneer’s epic about fortune hunting, daring exploits, and sailing the open seas. Stevenson’s beautifully woven, meaningful sub-context brings attention to paradigms such as equality, trust, coming-of-age, the perils of unrespected nature, and the uncertainty of morality.

Our artistic vision of TREASURE ISLAND is a serialized site-specific presentation of linked, yet viably independent mini-plays performed over the course of a day with acts that appeal to both all-day festival goers interested is taking in the entire story, as well as those that are only able to participate in single play segments. Our adaptation of TREASURE ISLAND stays true to Stevenson’s darkly iconic imagery through period pirate slang, language accuracy, authentic use of nautical song, and carefully crafted action choreography. Set, casting, and costuming are striking, yet efficient to accommodate the extremely busy festival setting. The production is dark, yet suitable for audiences of all ages.

OUR QUALIFICATIONS AND MISSION STATEMENT

Water is common to all of us and to all life. In the most poetic and literal sense, we are all bodies of water! As such, it is the Mission of Following Seas Productions to protect Earth's oceans and foster the human-to-sea connection through the performing arts. Following Seas Productions strives to cultivate sustainable methods of ocean renewal; fund projects that promote ecological health; and conduct coastal community outreach. We honor the inherent sanctity of our seas, oceans, beaches, and all of the creatures that call these places home.

Following Seas Productions is a new Long Beach performing arts venture dedicated to works that highlight the beauty and preservation-plight of our oceans, seas, nautical culture, marine creatures, and coasts. With a staff comprised of experienced adult and children’s theatre directors, multi-talented performers, skilled playwrights, well-versed writers, a passionate community organizer, a hard-working behind-the-scenes production team, and our very own in-house pirate-loving historian, Following Seas Productions is uniquely qualified to present TREASURE ISLAND to a pirate-centric audience at a large community event.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

Contributors will help Following Seas Productions breathe life into TREASURE ISLAND! Unlike most local theatre in Long Beach, CA, our production is free to the public and will reach residents that cannot afford traditional theatre. Children will be exposed to a classic literary work in a palatable, accessible, and engaging live way. Contributions will go directly toward the purchase, construction, or rental of tangible pirate costuming, stage props, and set design elements. These items are crucial for the sucess of the produciton. Your constribution may even provide for a helm, mast, or Long John Silver's wooden leg. The more funds we raise, the better the production will be. 

Your contribution will also support our contribution! Our entire cast and crew is donating their time, energy, and funding without pay to our TREASURE ISLAND project.

What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to raise $1200 to produce an amazing adaptation of TREASURE ISLAND. EVERY DOLLAR we raise will go directly toward obtaining pirate-y set, costuming, and design elements. No contribution is too small and every dollar will have a major impact on the quality of our production. 

As our thanks to you, we will be giving away electronic copies of our script, donor and producer playbill credits, Following Seas Productions gear, dress rehearsal invites, and even a call from Long John Silver!

The Impact

The Followiung Seas Productions adaptation of TREASURE ISLAND brings performing arts to the beach and makes it free and accessible to all people. It will be entertaining as well as educational and artistic. Those in the Long Beach, Los Angeles, Southbay, and Southern California region will be able to easily attend the event themselves to see exactly how their contribution was used! We would love to have our contributors sitting front and center at our performance! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help with a monetary donation, please spread the word about our project and TREASURE ISLAND stage adaption. Make some noise about our campaign on Facebook and Twitter, encourage others to donate, and use the IndieGoGo share tools. We will also be providing progress reports on our new BLOG, FACEBOOK, and TWITTER. Please follow Following Seas Productions!

story:
About Red Letter Jesus

       "Who do people say that I am?  What about you?  Who do you say I am?"

              Some people loved him; others hated him...What do you think?

Red Letter Jesus is a deeply moving new show of Jesus' words from the synoptic gospels (Matthew, Mark, and Luke) performed with an original multimedia presentation, including stunning videography captured throughout Israel and Jordan. 

The show will star Atlanta-based actor Brad Sherrill who devotes eight months of the year to the ongoing U.S. tour of his faith-based theater work. Red Letter Jesus is Sherrill's third live theatrical offering based on biblical texts. He has performed The Gospel of John over 600 times, including a run off-Broadway. Sherrill also recently premiered his original adaptation of Prophets, based on the texts of Isaiah and Jeremiah, at Georgia Shakespeare (Atlanta, 2010).

In 2011 and 2013, Sherrill and his videographer/designer Mark Hickman traveled to Israel and Jordan to gather multimedia for Red Letter Jesus.  The majority of the multimedia for the performance consists of original images and video footage, which Hickman gathered in Israel, the West Bank and Jordan during these time periods.

Hickman’s visual imagery and soundscape is designed not merely to draw us into the era and the geography surrounding Jesus’ ministry, but also to convey some of the Gospel stories which the red letters alone cannot communicate.

What Critics Are Saying

 "Mr. Sherrill is a poised performer with a subtle physical grace.”   

 -THE NEW YORK TIMES

 "Sherrill entertains and cajoles, moves and mesmerizes..."   

  -THE ATLANTA JOURNAL-CONSTITUTION

About Provision Theater

Provision Theater company is a 501(c)3 non-profit devoted to producing works of hope, reconciliation and redemption. We are preparing to open our 10th Anniversary Season and with your support, we can continue to positively impact the community by producing works that challenge us to explore a life meaning and purpose. Collectively, we can make a difference!

The Impact of Your Donation

Our fundraising goal is only a fraction of the production costs for Red Letter Jesus. Your donation will help support multiple aspects of the show, including:

  • Creating the set
  • Facilitating the multimedia presentation of videography captured throughout  Israel and Jordan
  • Compensating all of those involved in the production from the talent to the stage crew and box office staff

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Tell others about the show!
  • Subscribe to our blog
  • Like our Facebook page
  • Follow us on Twitter

www.provisiontheater.org

No matter what, thank you for your support.

story:
www.murmursplay.com
 
 

About me

Hi everyone. My name is Dahn and I'm a playwright, performance artist and visual artist from Brooklyn, NY. I'm also an art instructor, making my living as an adjunct professor of art at various New York area colleges. I've also been a gay rights and AIDS activist for over 25 years, and some of those themes are incorporated into my work. My dream is to have Murmurs and Incantations--a play very close to my heart--produced and shared with a wider audience.

 

About the play
 
Murmurs and Incantations tells the story of an artist with creative block who fatefully travels to Eastern Europe in an attempt to revive his art career, only to be further confounded by the disapproving ghost of his grandfather, a rabbi killed in the Holocaust.

Harrowing, poignant and irreverently funny, Murmurs and Incantations explores the anguish and the responsibility of being an artist. It sharply examines the ways in which identity, family and cultural history and personal baggage affect, impede and shape the creative process. Theatrically, Murmurs and Incantations is groundbreaking in its meaningful incorporation of performance art into both the form and content of the play.

As the play’s action largely takes place in art spaces, Murmurs and Incantations’ site-specific staging in a Chelsea gallery is a natural fit. Audiences are offered an exciting immersive experience, migrating from scene to scene in the real spaces of the art world. In addition to music, played live in the gallery spaces by its composer, the piece includes live video, installation-like sets, and audience participation, making for a richly textured evening of contemporary performance.

I am so very lucky to have an Academy award-winning composer, Yuval Ron, composing original music, Tony Award-nominated director, Eleanor Reissa, as creative consultant, and a wonderful team of very gifted performers.

The play will be performed on Wednesday, August 21 and Thursday, August 22, 2013 at 8pm, at Mixed Greens Gallery, 531 West 26 Street, 1st Floor, NYC 10001.

Please join us!

 

About the funding

Staging the play in New York will cost approximately $10,000.

Here are my expenses:
Actors, in accordance with Actors' Equity rates: $4320
Music: composer, music recordings, licensing, performance, supervision & direction:  $2800
Sound equipment rental: $500
Chair rental: $380
Rehearsal space: $650
Advertising, printing and promotion: $1500
Total:  $10,150
 
If I do not reach my entire fundraising goal, I will still stage the play somehow. I am committed to staging it, even if it takes me a very long time to pay it off. But I would be so grateful if folks find my project worthwhile and worthy of a contribution, however small or large.

 

About donations and rewards
 
Please see the wonderful rewards I have reserved for donors. The rewards are listed to the right. All donations are deeply and kindly appreciated.

 

About other ways to help

If you are unable to donate, you can certainly help us by getting the word out about the play and the campaign, via Facebook, Twitter, email and blogs. You can also use the Indiegogo share tools!

 

Thank you so very much-
 
Dahn

story:
Short Summary

The Bushwick Dance Team has been created to give the opportunity to our students, who come from different socio economic, cultural and ethnic backgrounds, to be a part of a fun school and extracurricular activity. This Team will give the students the opportunity to interact with each other, to help students to build respect, to improve communication skills, to build trust with each other, to develop a sense of responsibility and punctuality, and to develop the skills that are needed to be an integral part of the community.

The dance Team is serving students from all grade levels. Our school is located in an economic disadvantage area of Bushwick serving students and families of this community. With very limited resources it is challenging for our students to find a space in which they can display their creativeness and final productions. The dance Team is essential to our students’ livelihood and academic success providing them with an outlet and the opportunities to be engaged in activities where they can demonstrate and utilize all their skills and talents. The goal is to have established a dance team that fosters multicultural artistic expressions through dance over the next two academic years. With the Dance Team we want to provide the students with a safe environment and to have them interested in participating in an activity they enjoy.

Imagine if you had been given this opportunity for a life-changing experience when you were in high school and were unable to participate for lack of funds. In order for the Bushwick Dance Team  to be able to achieve its goal, we need to equip our students with the necessary attire, which includes dance shoes, dance costumes and accessories, dance instructors and electronics. However, our resources are very limited but, our enthusiasm is immense. We are in need of $5, 000 dollars to be able to get the necessary equipment to continue running our dance team through June and to showcase the dancers at multiple events outside of our campus.

Your support for a part or the entire generous donation would be greatly appreciated. At this time we really need and depend on your help.

The dance Team is essential to our students’ livelihood and academic success providing them with an outlet and the opportunities to be engaged in activities where they can demonstrate and utilize all their skills and talents. The goal is to have established a dance team that fosters multicultural artistic expressions through dance over the next two academic years. With the Dance Team we want to provide the students with a safe environment and to have them interested in participating in an activity they enjoy.
Imagine if you had been given this opportunity for a life-changing experience when you were in high school and were unable to participate for lack of funds. In order for the Bushwick Dance Team  to be able to achieve its goal, we need to equip our students with the necessary attire, which includes dance shoes, dance costumes and accessories, dance instructors and electronics. However, our resources are very limited but, our enthusiasm is immense. We are in need of $5, 000 dollars to be able to get the necessary equipment to continue running our dance team through June and to showcase the dancers at multiple events outside of our campus.
Your support for a part or the entire generous donation would be greatly appreciated. At this time we really need and depend on your help.

story:
Short, Sweet, and to the Point:

Here I am with Seattle's giant piggy bank, Rachel.  She's short, sweet, and to the point, too.
Disguised as the company Cheep Art, I'm a theatre artist committed to creating high-quality, engaging new work and taking it beyond my hometown for more people to experience.
This funding campaign is a bookend to the year-long process of developing THE TWO-STEP. Like the contributors who've met my initial $880 goal (YOU DID IT!), a village-worth of individuals have contributed their time, talent, stories, skills, and more in support of my idea becoming a true theatrical experience. THANK YOU! (WE DID IT!)
And I DID IT! With abundant tears, sweat, and blood (thanks to a park bench injury), I've condensed 40 years of my grandparents' love, wisdom, dancing, traveling, and dreaming into a 52-minute solo play. HOORAY! I've performed it seven times in Winnipeg, five times in Chicago, and four times in Seattle. The Winnipeg Fringe Festival press gave my show 4 stars, and the Seattle Fringe Festival audiences voted THE TWO-STEP as their top pick! The standing ovations and teary-eyed smiles require no explanation. Closing night of my final 2014 festival was in some ways just the beginning; I now know so much about the artistic potential of this show. I'm ready for more!
Praise aside, I'm starting to feel the financial "bumps in the road" as I've invested all my time and earnings into a full-year process. This summer, I toured away from regularly paid work hours for 2+ months, while paying rent, insurance, and all the other daily expenses on top of travel and marketing costs.


MY CAMPAIGN GOAL...as flexible funding STEPS:

THANK YOU! $880 covered the airfare and city transit costs from Winnipeg & Chicago, plus 10% in various fees (Indiegogo, credit card, etc). Whew!

NEW GOALS for the final week: 

$980 - help me pay my volunteer sound designer/operator at least $100!

$1,100 - help me partially pay off the newspaper ad from Winnipeg!

$1,300 - help me partially pay off rehearsal space costs!

$1,500 - help me pay myself $200 for all this work?!


A few of the major Cheep Art Expenses ($5,000), paid by Christine, July 2013 - September 2014:

$1,650 fringe festival application (x10) and participation (x3) fees

$900 director stipend for the one and only Paul Budraitis

$0 sound designer/operator stipend (very generously volunteered)

$200 composer stipend (paid by an unsolicited friendly donation!)

$125 photographer stipend for poster image 

$300 rehearsal space for 3+ months

$240 advertisement in Winnipeg newspaper

$400 transportation/meals/advertising materials during three weeks in Winnipeg

$350 Poster/flyer printing & distribution costs for Winnipeg and Chicago (paid by an unsolicited family donation!)

$650 airfare to/from Chicago & Winnipeg

$150 weekly bus passes & train tickets in Chicago & Winnipeg

(Note: I haven't compensated myself a single cent for this over-time work in the past 395+ days.)


DONOR PERKS! READ THE LIST OVER THERE! -->

THIRTEEN PERKS TO CHOOSE FROM! CLAIM ONE!

I WANT TO GIVE BACK TO YOU!

If you've already visited (and/or donated to) this campaign, read them carefully! I've adjusted some of the price levels and a few of the perks!


Impact.

Your contribution fuels my faith in community, collaboration, and creativity. I've ridden the undulating waves of doubt and exuberance throughout my play's development, and I ultimately believe that this is a show worth experiencing. I'm very proud of my work. Help me keep THE TWO-STEP on the road for its future audiences around the world!

To tell you the truth, the successful 2012 Indiegogo campaign for ROBERTA AND THE MOON provided THE TWO-STEP with a strong start of $1,000. The first thing I did was invest in quality direction from Paul Budraitis. I am ever so grateful that he accepted what I consider a very paltry paycheck (compared to his caliber of work). He offered the richest collaborative experience I ever could have wished for.

Any surplus from this campaign - after paying my debts - will go straight to a savings account for developing my next project. The cycle of generosity keeps moving forward!

    You can help beyond the piggy bank! Tell people about THE TWO-STEP!

    Now that I have the show in production-ready form, I want to produce it as much as possible! If you have connections to a venue in ANY city, let me know!

    Please help me spread the word about my show and this campaign. Make some noise! If ten of your friends can spare a cup of coffee for one day, that really makes a difference!

    THANK YOU, ALL!

story:
KB Productions

KB Productions, the team behind the recent sold-out smash, Southern Baptist Sissies, the hard hitting Mysterious Skin, and the staged reading of the provocative story of FLIT, continues to cement its reputation in the Nashville theater community by presenting edgy, left of center productions that have not previously been seen on Music City stages.  Our newest project is the award winning hit show, EQUUS, directed by the mega-talented Clay Hillwig. 

KB Productions is a grass-roots production that operates as not-for-profit.  We simply have a love of the arts, in particular, live performing arts.  We also believe that audiences need to be exposed to issues that are relevant in today's society by presenting shows that other companies shy away from.

What we need

A production of this magnitude demands that we give it the most professional production that we possibly can.  We have a very talented local artist creating beautiful sculpted horse heads along with one of Nashville's top choreographers to work with the actors portraying the horses with precision movement.  This production also requires some very special lighting effects and we have a very talented designer on our team.  
We also need to reach out to the community at large by utilizing mainstream advertising.
All of these elements come at great cost.  We have been blessed with several local sponsors, but we are still far short of our projected budget.  All of our cast and production crew are volunteer.  We also select a Beneficiary Sponsor each season which gets at least 10% of any "profit" that we receive.  The remaining amount goes into the business account to pay ongoing expenses for storage, web site hosting, phone information line, and insurance.
KB Productions is a labor of love created by L.T. Kirk, Donald Powell, and Justin Burgess.  All of the start up costs and production costs of our first two productions came directly out of our pockets.  We found that there is a burgeoning audience that craves theater experiences that challenge their perceptions of the issues that face our society.

    The Impact

    Teaming up with us, through your generous contribution, will enable us to bring this incredible production to life!

      The biggest challenge that we face is the cost of advertising.  We have identified three of the most effective print and radio advertising outlets and over 80% of our fundraising goal will go directly into the cost of these ads.

        Other Ways You Can Help

        If you are unable to contribute financially there are still ways that you can help!

        1. Go to www.kb-productions.org and purchase tickets to attend the show.

        2. Tell others about this production and about our campaign.

        3. Use your blogs and other social media resources to get the word out about the production and the fundraising campaign.

story:
Our Story

A Century of Women is an evening of words and music about women who have shaped our lives, for better or worse.  Using material from biographies, speeches, letters, public performances and secret diaries, a cast of actors take on the famous, infamous and unsung heroines from around the globe.  From the Iron Lady to the Female Eunuch, celebrate women from all walks of life and find your muse as well as your adversary.


A Century of Women was first performed in London throughout March 2011 to celebrate 100 years of International Women's Day. It met with great critical acclaim and sell out houses in four different fringe venues. 


Audience feedback reported that people came away inspired and fascinated by the wide range of characters before them. Here's what they said:

"I was absorbed throughout. I didn’t want it to end."

"This is an engrossing, uplifting and often surprising piece. Not all are heroic, some are deeply flawed, even vulnerable; but we are left with an inspiring sense of infinite variety."

"Some fascinating material and very good performances."


Inspired by its success, three4all theatre would like to reach out to wider audiences by taking A Century Of Women to the Leicester Square Theatre September 2011.


The Impact

The impact has already been great with our audiences. Here's what the reviewers said:


"It is a splendid tribute to some magnificent women performed by splendid actresses."

Remotegoat


"Debbie Yearsley was outstanding and rather uncanny as the young Margaret Thatcher...The change in form and the songs make this production very lively. The cast is excellent...Director Alison Mead hopes that this production will showcase how women have shaped history and spark debate. I think she has succeeded. It definitely touches on many important issues that have not lost its relevance over the years."

UK Theatre Network


Please help us to continue the debate!

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for just $5,000 (that's about £3000) to help mount this production.  This will go towards set design, costumes and printing up our flyers and posters. If we exceed our target we can also cover our venue hire. The rehearsal space has been very kindly donated!


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell all your friends - they don't have to be women!

Like our Facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/pages/Three4All-Theatre...

Follow us on Twitter: http://twitter.com/#!/centuryofwomen

Buy a ticket. Buy ten! http://leicestersquaretheatre.ticketsolve.com/s...

story:
Who (and what) is KTO Productions?

My name is Doug Knoop, I'm a Seattle native with deep roots in the local theater scene. Since my return to Seattle after college I've performed and directed all over the Puget Sound area.  I formed KTO Productions to allow myself and other artists to stretch beyond their "comfort zones" and to create and perform projects they are passionate about.

In the fall of 2011, our inaugural production of Conor McPherson’s “The Weir” was a crowd pleaser and a critical success. In 2012 we presented "'night mother" by Marsha Norman. Talkin' Broadway called it "as gripping a 90 minutes as can be seen on any Seattle stage..." while Jerry Kraft of SeattleActor.com said the show was “absolutely genuine and it left me genuinely moved.” 

Why "Sea Marks"?

Gardner McKay's 1982 drama tells the tale of a romance between an Irish fisherman and woman he's glimpsed only once. The play had been suggested several times by Toni Douglass (director of our production of "The Weir") and this fall seems like the right time to share this drama with Seattle audiences.

Where is the money going?

Our first goal is to cover the rental of rehearsal and performance spaces ($1,500), $750-$1,000 to cover set construction and basic publicity costs. Beyond that we are hoping to cover performance rights, technical needs (set, lighting) and basic publicity costs.

And of course, we would love to pay our actors and stage manager a decent stipend. 

What you get

The perks:

  • $10 - Our heartfelt thanks, plus shout-outs on our Facebook page and Twitter feed.
  • $25 - All of the above, plus mention on our Web site and in our program as a "Donor."
  • $50 - All of the above, plus two tickets to the show and a copy of the program signed by the cast.
  • $75 - All of the above, plus two tickets to our next production in 2014 (title TBA).
  • $100 - All of the above, plus a show poster signed by the cast and director.
  • $250 - All of the above, plus an additional pair of tickets to our 2014 production, and dinner for two with the producer (and schedule permitting, the director and cast) of the show.

Other Ways You Can Help

We'd love it if you can contribute, but we know that times are tough. Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word! Share this link on Facebook, Google+, Twitter or Tumblr. Tell your friends, send a text, make a call, write a letter.
  • We are still seeking a sound designer. Also if you have a special skill or talent you would like to volunteer, let us know.
  • Contact us at ktoproductions@earthlink.net.

Thank you!

Many thanks for helping us bring this project to life. We appreciate your support and generosity.

story:
Welcome!

Having spent years toiling under the umbrella of others, four fresh-faced newly-minted twenty-somethings decided to venture out on their own and start a theatre company!

Introducing us: The Chocolate Moose Theatre Company!

We are a Montreal-based theatre company seeking to make all that good stuff happen on stage: the insipirational, heart-warming, frightening, comic stuff of life. 2014 will mark our first year of productions. In January we will be moosing around on the stage of Theatre Sainte Catherine as we present Edward Albee's "Homelife" and "The Zoo Story".

But given our lack of financial backing, we need your help. We have seen what the Montreal community can do for theatre in the past and we only hope that you will be able to tap into that generosity to give us a helping hand!

What We Need & What You Get

Every dollar collected here will go towards theatre rental and rights (that's $1800 + $400 = $2 200 in total).

Any extra dollars will be put towards rehearsal space, costumes, and paying some of the wonderful people that have helped us put all of this together. 

We know the number on the right hand side of the screen looks a little daunting but we think we can do it! And, of course, we have some pretty great things and stuff and such to send your way in return. 

The Impact

Without your help this road will never get on the show. Nor will this show get on the road. 

No Monayy? Don't Worry About It!

Spreading the word is just as important! Share us with your friends, your great aunt in Antigonish, your brother in North Bay, and your crazy uncle who is currently living on your back porch. 

Want to see the Results?

You have 6 fantastic chances to see the show!

DATES

Thursday, January 9th at 8PM

Friday, January 10th at 8PM

Saturday, January 11th at 8PM

Thursday, January 16th at 8PM

Friday, January 17th at 8PM

Saturday, January 18th at 8PM

TICKETS

$14.00 (+fee) Regular Admission

WHERE

Theatre Sainte Catherine

264 Sainte Catherine Street East

Montreal, QC


From the top of our antlers to the tip of our tails, we send you our sincerest thanks! 

MOOSE LOVE

story:
SHADOW Company

We are a bunch of teens that like to create art. We reflect on our unique experiences and try to tell compelling stories that impact the world around us. We receive training and support from Yes! And... Collaborative Arts, who provide professional artists to train and guide us. We are:

  • Teens, led by teens
  • Funny! (And sometimes serious)
  • Active in our communities

During this next year, we want to focus on three plays we've already written and performed. We think they can be revised and edited into one full-length show but we need YOUR help to do it!

Trials of Paradox, Bullseye!, & Flash

These three plays are our message to the world. They speak to tragedy, getting along, being human, and being a teen. The commonality in these pieces is what we want to explore this coming year.

We have to raise all of our funding for the entire year, and this Indiegogo campaign is just one part of our fundraising. We need the extra money to work with professional playwrights and directors to help us mold and shape this piece we are imagining. Here's where some of that money goes:

  • Just to participate in the Fringe Festival we need $500
  • To hire a professional playwright to do three workshops we need $300
  • Printing up posters is $100 and postcards is $300 (postage is another $250!)
  • Costumes and props can be anywhere from $200-$400
  • We spend $600 to rent a venue (more if we want it in Center City!)
  • Our director transports a lot of us! We like to fill her car with gas!

This is what we want to accomplish:

As teens we have a unique voice in society. We enjoy shining a light into dark places. We believe this show can speak to the community of Philadelphia and beyond if we are successful. Our vision is to be able to take pieces of these shows to schools and community groups to encourage, uplift, and show other teens an alternative through the arts.

You Can Help!

Even if you can't donate right now, please consider sharing this with your friends and family. Also, we are always looking to grow our company, so if you know of teens who are passionate and engaged, please send them our way! Our website is: http://SHADOW.yesandcamp.org/ and we connect via Facebook with each other!

We only have one week!

So hurry please!

SHADOW Company
We are a bunch of teens that like to create art. We reflect on our unique experiences and try to tell compelling stories that impact the world around us. We receive training and support from Yes! And... Collaborative Arts, who provide professional artists to train and guide us. We are:

Teens, led by teens
Funny! (And sometimes serious)
Active in our communities

During this next year, we want to focus on three plays we've already written and performed. We think they can be revised and edited into one full-length show but we need YOUR help to do it!



Trials of Paradox, Bullseye!, & Flash

These three plays are our message to the world. They speak to tragedy, getting along, being human, and being a teen. The commonality in these pieces is what we want to explore this coming year.
We have to raise all of our funding for the entire year, and this Indiegogo campaign is just one part of our fundraising. We need the extra money to work with professional playwrights and directors to help us mold and shape this piece we are imagining. Here's where some of that money goes:



Just to participate in the Fringe Festival we need $500

To hire a professional playwright to do three workshops we need $300
Printing up posters is $100 and postcards is $300 (postage is another $250!)
Costumes and props can be anywhere from $200-$400
We spend $600 to rent a venue (more if we want it in Center City!)
Our director transports a lot of us! We like to fill her car with gas!



This is what we want to accomplish:
As teens we have a unique voice in society. We enjoy shining a light into dark places. We believe this show can speak to the community of Philadelphia and beyond if we are successful. Our vision is to be able to take pieces of these shows to schools and community groups to encourage, uplift, and show other teens an alternative through the arts.


You Can Help!
Even if you can't donate right now, please consider sharing this with your friends and family. Also, we are always looking to grow our company, so if you know of teens who are passionate and engaged, please send them our way! Our website is: http://SHADOW.yesandcamp.org/ and we connect via Facebook with each other!

We only have one week!
So hurry please!

story:
Crawford Jazz Project 

This company is being created for two reasons. First and foremost because we have such a love and respect for jazz dance and want to share that passion. We want to see this classic style of dance continue to thrive in today's market. The company is our way of contributing what we can to preserve this wonderful art. 

The other reason is to get this very special group of dancers together. We all have a strong connection in the way we work. It is hard to put into words, but it's undeniably there when you see these ladies in the studio or on stage with each other. 

We intend to travel to various college campuses, arts festivals, dance studios and other performance venues across the east coast. As often as possible we will be attaching workshop classes to these events so that our audience will not only be entertained but also have the opportunity to learn and put our style on their own body. 

This particular campaign is to help us raise the funds needed to produce our premier event in Greenville, SC on August 6, 2016. Funds will go to travel expenses, space rental, videographers, costumes, promotional materials, performance insurance, and other production costs. This premier event will be a great kickstarter for our company and also serve as a platform to raise more funds for the future of the project! 

Crawford Jazz Project is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization.  Contributions for the charitable purposes of Crawford Jazz Project are payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Who we are:

Hi, I am Kristin Damrow and I am the artistic director of Kristin Damrow & Company, a contemporary dance company in San Francisco, CA. This year we are excited to be presenting a world premiere, entitled Swallow at the Joe Goode Annex on May 13-15. Swallow is an dramatic and action packed contemporary dance that is all about our emotionally dense lives. Love, loss, and discovering who we are as individuals. Not only is this a brand spankin' new dance piece, its also our very first home season! 

Why we are on Indiegogo:

The $5,000 we are asking for on this campaign will go towards:
  • Making our first home season the biggest and best it can be!
  • Paying the dancers for all the time, energy and talent they have poured into this piece.
  • Renting the Joe Goode Annex, a visually stunning warehouse-theater space in the heart of the Mission in San Francisco. 
  • Covering costs of lighting design to make the dance look even more dramatic and awesome on stage
  • Paying for a high quality video recording of Swallow so that we can use it for future grant applications. 

Get something out of donating! 

Along with those warm fuzzy feelings after donating you can also get some great perks! For those of you in the dance community, we have some some amazing teachers have donated classes at ODC, Dance Mission, LINES and City Dance. So give and get your dance one! There is also a chance to grab some private pilates sessions and some free tickets could be in your future. Also bonus perk for ALL donations of any size, I will be sending a link of the full performance of Swallow. 

How far Kristin Damrow & Company has come: 

Over the past year KDC has hit many miles stones. We have presented new works at the D.I.R.T Festival and Summer Performance Festival, auditioned new company members to join us to make a cast of eight, and gained fiscal sponsorship through Dancers' Group, a non-profit organization that supports dance artists. This fiscal sponsorship was a big deal for us! It allows us to apply for grants and accept tax-deducible donations from individual sponsors. We are so thrilled to be awarded our first grant from the Zellerbach Family Foundation. And we have already recieved sponsorship from friends and family members. You all are awesome thank you or believing what we are doing!  

This May, I am so proud to present Swallow as our first home season. The dancers have all stepped up to the challenge and are dancing with so much passion, strength and beauty. Aaron Gold has created an incredible music score that makes Swallow even more of a unique performance. We hope to continue to grow and move on to more elaborate and awesome dances. This is why your help is so important to us and for our future plans with Kristin Damrow & Company. 

Stay connected: 

Its very important to us to know our community, so stay connected with us! 

  • Follow our YouTube channel. We create vlogs (short video documentaries) that give you a personal look into how we create work. 
  • Like us on Facebook! 
  • For more info & tickets to Swallow, check out our performance website 
Thanks again for taking the time to consider donating, we hope to see you at the Joe Goode Annex May 13-15th! 
-Kristin

story:
Short Summary

Hello.

Thank for reading this campaign.

I formed First Draft Theatre in 2010 as an opportunity for like-minded people to present original works on the stages of the London Fringe. To date we have produced four festivals featuring short plays and over twenty individual productions.

One of these new works, and the one that had by far the most impact on our audiences, was Alexander Moschos' play Brainville at Night, which was inspired by his experiences of caring for a lady with frontotemporal dementia. In my role as producer, I was very keen for the play to help promote awareness of the work of The Alzheimer's Society and so I invited their members to contribute to the programme notes as well as taking part in post-performance Q&A sessions with audiences.

I distinctly remember being overwhelmed by the statistics surrounding Alzheimer's; not just the number of those living with dementia in the UK, but of course the thousands who work tirelessly as carers. As my eyes were opened further to the various forms of the disease (not to mention those who go undiagnosed), I knew that I wanted to do something further with First Draft to bring new productions of professional theatre to those in care centres outside London with little to no access to such entertainment.

At around the same time, my nan, Dot, was suffering with chronic arthritis and depression. Her anxiety meant that she could no longer be cared for at home and needed to live in an environment in which she could receive 24 hour care. Trying to find a suitable place for her was not an easy task; she was desperately unhappy about being unable to live the life she had known so well and to enjoy the social benefits of being around her family and friends.

Though she was not diagnosed with dementia, she displayed similar traits. Physical frailties, hallucinations and an inability to communicate her most basic needs were commonplace. I was determined to do something that might help to stimulate her mind and those of her fellow residents. Whenever I visited her during this time, we were both reminded of the first play I had ever put on: a spectacular one-woman show in my garden, when I was aged just 7, and with a ticket price of 2p! Ever since that time, she followed my career as an actress and producer avidly, and now here she was asking me what I was working on, and "will you sing that song you used to sing?"

In September 2015, I asked my nan that if I were to bring a production to Sussex for her, what it was that she would want to see. Her reply was "a bit of everything please - just like what you do in London". And so, in December 2015, we toured our first production, The Snow Queen, to 10 care homes in East Sussex. Sadly, my nan passed away just one week before we visited her, yet the tour was an intensely humbling and rewarding experience for everyone involved and we were delighted that the care providers saw such positive reactions from their clients, and they emphasised the need and demand for this work to continue.

This is why I am now investing my time into developing our work with the hope of expanding it further across the UK in the near future. Our new charity will take professional theatre into care environments, with the hope that we can offer alternative stimulation and the experience of live theatre that is (hopefully!) entertaining for all, but also accessible to those living with dementia, learning difficulties and frailties. I am determined that these productions should be of little to no cost for the care centres and that they should look to be as adaptable as possible. We want to transform the everyday spaces of the residents – whether it be a living/dining room, garden or reception area – in the hope that they can enjoy professional theatre in a pop-up venue with the same level of production values that I would expect for any London theatre show I produce.

A new charity will be fully established by the end of September under the name ‘The Dot Collective’ and we hope that completing these formalities will make funding applications a little easier from then on. Unfortunately, we failed to receive any funding from The Arts Council, but that will not stop us from bringing our new show, A Midsummer Night's Dream to care centres across the South East this September. It will feature a specially adapted version of the Shakespeare text, with live music, dancing and interaction with the audience.

To make the tour possible we need to raise £8,000. This cost covers the set, stage, lighting, sound, five actors, van hire, petrol, three nights accommodation in Sussex, rehearsal room hire in London, a director, stage manager, producer, insurance, costume, instrument hire and props.

The Chalk Cliff Trust has generously donated £5,000 to our project, but obviously we still have a way to go. Any help towards achieving our goal will be hugely appreciated and, more importantly, will mean we can give the care homes the experience we know that they deserve.

Please spread the word of this campaign far and wide and don't hesitate to be in touch if you want any further information. I am determined that our tour this September will be the beginning of a long relationship with care providers and residents across the country and I thank you in advance for helping us to expand and bring this work to as many places as possible in the future.

Follow us on Facebook and  Twitter @firstdrafttheat

 

Care centres we are visiting so far:

(East Sussex County council)

Milton Grange, Eastbourne

Sandbanks centre, Hailsham

Beacongate, Crowborough

(CareUK)

Bowes house, Hailsham

Darlington court, Littlehampton

(Sussex community Development Association)

Isabel Blackman centre, Hastings

Charter Centre, Bexhill

Phoenix Centre, Lewes

The Priory at St.Wilfrids, Arundel

 

The Impact

Praise from our previous tour of The Snow Queen:

‘What an absolutely brilliant experience.  Clearly a lot of thought and effort went into the staging of the production and the set layout in order to ensure all residents, regardless of their mobility level could fully enjoy the play.  What was most noticeable for me was not only seeing the very evident enjoyment and animation on the faces of the residents, but also the fact that this is a production that was a real family affair - something that can sometimes be difficult to achieve for those with very limited mobility.  The cast not only acted the play out superbly, but I particularly noticed how wonderfully sensitive and caring they were in their interactions with the residents whilst setting up.
A great play, brilliantly acted.  I hope this can be a more regular event!’

Fildema Harris – Audience member Bowes House Care UK

‘Thoroughly enjoyed by all and was being discussed for quite some time after hoping that a further production was going to be arranged’
Tracy Fears - (Warwick House, Seaford Care centre)

‘Despite the clients having a diagnosis of Dementia and some with limited communication, they loved the performance and in particular the singing and lighting effects. It was also interactive and the clients and staff were able to participate. The feedback overall was really positive and a real treat for the clients over the festive period’
Andrea Januszewka (Phoenix centre, Lewes)

‘The cast enabled all clients to engage whatever their abilities were as our clients have either physical frailties or dementia’
Tracy Fears - (Warwick House, Seaford Care centre)

A Midsummer Night's Dream will be able to extend our current connections to a wider network of care homes which have a low artistic engagement. This collaboration with the care sector allows us to extend our collective skill set, expanding to more audiences for the next production we hope to provide at Christmas.  We plan to form a charity in the future with an aim to tour work biannually around the UK. We would like the care providers and residents to be familiar and look forward to our productions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word of this campaign at help us bring theatre to care homes this September.

If you know anyone that would be interested in this project, please help us spread the word and you can share this campaign on social media - we can be found both on FaceBook and our Twitter is @firstdrafttheat 

Thank you so much for reading,

Laura Harling

story:
The New Mechanics

The New Mechanics are a new theatre collective comprised of three cool cats, Kate: a technician and director, Spencer: a musician and writer, and David: a comedian and actor. Our work is technology and multi-media driven, pulling from our three pools of talent and aesthetic to create a visually crazy show that is 1 part Blue Man Group, 1 part personal narrative, a dash of Werner Herzog and a whole lot of extension cables.

We have been accepted into the Dancing on the Ceiling: and Other Moments of Connection devised theatre festival being performed at 773 and need gear to make our show work. 

Let's Break it Down

Here's the gear we need to make our art happen:

  • Projector - $200
  • Sweet-Ass Suitcase Light Board - $110
  • Various Cables and Lighting fixtures - $180
  • Video Production Console - $90
  • Camera - $70
  • Costumes - $50
  • Baby Powder - $20
  • Transportation - $50
  • Promotional Materials (Stickers) - $25
For those of you that have a degree in maths, you may have noticed that all of this gear adds up to more than the amount that we are shooting for. We know it's a big undertaking and we are willing to put our own money into it as well. But we do need help. The up side is that these costs are a one time thing. For our future performances, we won't need to buy gear again, we will already have a projector and a Sweet-Ass Suitcase Light Board.

See this Video Here?

This one here This is an example of the work we do. But that is one guy with one day of prep and gear he does not own. With your help, all of those things can change. Three people working with equipment we actually own.

Oh, and Come See the Show!

Even if you can't contribute to our gear fund, or if you do and want to see your money put to use, come see the show! 

Our piece is called: 

Applied Force, or: Hubris and Human Impossibilities in Regards to Mountains, Myths, and German Film Directors

We are performing at Stage 773 on July 11th, 18th, 25th and August 1st at 10:30pm.

story:
Sarina has been unable to have orthodontic and dental care since she left her home town in August. 4 schools in 6 months, sleeping in their car or staying at a shelter, it has been anything but easy for this talented young girl who wants to focus on becoming a professional ballerina.

They are struggling to put healthy meals on the table, gas in the car & just everyday care. She has touched my heart and would be so grateful for any help.

They are struggling to put healthy meals on the table, gas in the car & just everyday care. She has touched my heart and would be so grateful for any help.

story:
Short Summary

Common Essence Theater is raising funds for its inaguaral project. We will present a production of Nina Foxx's Just Short of Crazy,  in  partnership with the Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center in Seattle, WA, on February 12, 13th and 14th 2016.

They have provided us with a building grant to make this possible.

  • Nina Foxx is an NAACP Image Award Nominated Writer, Award winning Filmmaker and Playwright. She has authored over 15 works. Just Short of Crazy is her second play and is based on the book of the same name, published by HarperCollins Publishers.
  • This campaign will help us pay the actors a competitive wage and obtain set pieces.

What We Need & What You Get

  • To reach our goal, we need to raise $5000.
  • We have levels of support ranging from $10, to one Presenting Sponsor of $5000.
  • The IndieGoGo Flexible Program allows us to receive the funds even if we do not reach out goal. Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

We often complain about the lack of positive images of people of color and women in the media. Supporting our campaign will help us realize the dream of driving and controlling how we are portrayed on stage and screen and what stories we want to tell.

  • We will be able to successfully employ actors from the community, as well as provide several opportunities for young people interested in the arts to attend and be involved in a professional theater production, where they can learn skills that translate to business well, no matter what their field.
  • Nina Foxx attended the Commercial Theater Institute and leveraged community connections to  successfully present her first play, Marrying up to full theaters.

Risks & Challenges

  • In order to attract quality talent and guarantee a good show, we need to pay the actors a competitive wage.
  • Our IndieGoGo campaign will help us fill that gap.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word via social media and word of mouth.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and post our campaign on your social media pages.

Thank you.
story_txt:
Short Summary Common Essence Theater is raising funds for its inaguaral project. We will present a production of Nina Foxx's Just Short of Crazy,  in  partnership with the Langston Hughes Performing Arts Center in Seattle, WA, on February 12, 13th and 14th 2016.
They have provided us with a building grant to make this possible.  Nina Foxx is an NAACP Image Award Nominated Writer, Award winning Filmmaker and Playwright. She has authored over 15 works. Just Short of Crazy is her second play and is based on the book of the same name, published by HarperCollins Publishers.

 This campaign will help us pay the actors a competitive wage and obtain set pieces.
   What We Need & What You Get
 To reach our goal, we need to raise $5000.
 We have levels of support ranging from $10, to one Presenting Sponsor of $5000.
 The IndieGoGo Flexible Program allows us to receive the funds even if we do not reach out goal. Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.    The Impact We often complain
about the lack of positive images of people of color and women in the media.
Supporting our
campaign will help us realize the dream of driving and controlling how we are
portrayed on stage and screen and what stories we want to tell.   We will be able to successfully employ actors from the community, as well as provide several opportunities for young people interested in the arts to attend and be involved in a professional theater production, where they can learn skills that translate to business well, no matter what their field.
 Nina Foxx attended the Commercial Theater Institute and leveraged community connections to  successfully present her first play, Marrying up to full theaters. 
    Risks & Challenges    In order to attract quality talent and guarantee a good show, we need to pay the actors a competitive wage.

Our IndieGoGo campaign will help us fill that gap.

   Other Ways You Can Help  Spread the word via social media and word of mouth.
 Use the Indiegogo share tools and post our campaign on your social media pages.
   Thank you.

story:
Short Summary

RadioActive Cardboard is a non-profit organization geared towards providing real, uncut b-boying to the 757 community. In the past, RadioActive Cardboard has raised money for other non-profit organizations to improve the Hampton Roads area b-boy scene. Its mission is to provide the youth and adults a place for positive building with the art of b-boying.  Please help continue the movement:

Donate

  • If you love music!
  • If you love dance!
  • If you love life!
  • If you ever felt the break-beat and want to get up and move?
  • Because you want to support your community and the b-boy scene.

What We Need & What You Get

This is our first attempt with a goal set to reach $500 or more. This will help us financially to do more for the dance community.  

Much of the funding will be going towards overhead costs such as venues, staffing (photographers, videographers, DJ's, etc), 

If we can't reach the entire goal, we would have to ask more adults and friends and somehow feel guilty in doing so because we didn't get enough scratch support, but you won't let this happen, I know it.  And you're still invited to come and celebrate with us!

The Impact

Why would you want to help?

  • Self Expression through dance!
  • The youth community are exposed to art and dance and has a passionate, positive venue for the creative mind and body to meet.
  • This is our 4th year doing this and every year it gets larger and create an awareness for the dance community around hampton roads area and bring in other neighboring city to network and compete all for the love of b-boying.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute and would like to help, your networking skill to spread the love, spread the campaign like jelly on peanut butter.  If you'd like to get your hands dirty, feel free to come out to the event and donate yourself, your sweat, trust us, we'll find something for you to do. :)

  • Spread our campaign to as many of your fellow like minded cool people as you can
  • Indiegogo say use the Share tool, it'll help spread the word!

That's all there is to it, you don't have to put your back into it, if it's a dollar, $5 dollar, $9.99 or you want to bake us cupcakes, we would be delighted and grateful, peace, love and help us break some bread!

story:
MODERN LUV - an original musical by Mark Siano, starring Mark Siano and Opal Peachey. 

Hot off the heels of packed houses for MODERN LUV at the Triple Door in Seattle, we have been invited to debut in NYC!

HELP US GET THERE!

We need to raise $1,000 to help cover a portion of the costs of sending our cast and crew to New York.

Don't let these hilarious performers go without a roof over their heads in NYC.

They killed it in Seattle, now help them show NYC how we roll.

See this review from the final show in Seattle http://thesunbreak.com/2012/04/11/modern-luv-about-to-be-all-up-in-your-inbox-nyc/

Starring: Mark Siano and Opal Peachey
Special Guests: David Swidler, Hillary Gault, Kimberly Durham, Jeremy Adams, Madison Greenlund, Troy Lund, Noel Parkinson, and Liz Zeff.

As you can imagine, it will take several thousand dollars to ship a show to NYC.  We have raised most of this money through local performances, including the shows at the Triple Door in March and another show at the Rendezvous JewelBox Theater in April.  We need $1000 more to be sure we can successfully promote the show and provide proper transportation costs to our performers.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us to promote our show in NYC.  Tell all your friends and family to come see this show.  You have laughed and cried with Mark Siano and Opal Peachey many times, now is your chance to let New York see what Seattle has to offer.

Tix -->http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/233133

IRT
154 Christopher Street, 3B
New York, NY 10014
United States

Original Music: Mark Siano
Musical Director: Kathy Moore + John Kranz
Written by: Mark Siano, Jeanne Lee and Opal Peachey
Stage Manager: Noel Parkinson
Producers: Mark Siano and Donna Stewart

Thank you for your support!

story:
SweetPea Producers, Inc. Invited Back to Mt. Olivet Village, Philadelphia, PA

SweetPea Producers, Inc., is an international arts company devoted to connecting arts, artists and the public together.  We successfully present mainstage productions, staged readings, review arts events, facilitate the NBTF-Artist Networking Showcase in Winston-Salem, NC and volunteer with Volunteer Divas Plus.

SweetPea Producers, Inc. was invited to present a play for the Seniors at Mt. Olivet Village in Philadelphia, PA in 2011.  The result was the 2011 FREE HOLIDAY EXTRAVAGANZA which was a great success.  After the buzz (which is still buzzing to this day), we are returning with another production under our newly created series OFF-BROADWAY GOES TO MT. OLIVET VILLAGE, PHILADELPHIA, PA.  

The goal is to prepare an Off-Broadway production and present it for the Seniors at Mt. Olivet Village with the possibility of touring it to other facilities throughout the Philadelphia Housing Authority (PHA).  All performances are presented FREE of charge to PHA residents because attending quality shows is very prohibitive for families living on a fixed income.

THE WHO, HOW, WHAT, WHERE & WHEN  

  • WHO - We are hiring Off-Broadway Actors.  (Check back for casting updates.)

  • HOW - We are rehearsing in New York.  We will bus & truck the show to Mt. Olivet Villege in Philadelphia, PA.

  • WHAT - Our play is SOCIABILITY by Charles Dizenzo.  

  • WHERE - Mt. Olivet Villege, Philadelphia, PA

  • WHEN -  November 16, 2012.

THE NEED & HOW YOU CAN HELP

To pull this off we need to raise $10,000.

Your Donation will support:

  • Production: Casting, Set, Costumes (includuing special rip-away garments), Food, Props, Curtain Up Playbill, Rental of Rehearsal Space, Rental of Vans (including Insurance) for round-trip transportation to and from Mt. Olivet Village in Philadelphia, PA.  ($4,500)

  • Post-Production: Salaries for - Actors, Director, Designers, Drivers and Crew.  ($4,000)

  • Promotion/Distribution: Marketing (posters, postcards) and Getting the word out to our audience.  ($1,500)

All Donors are important and will be listed in our Curtain Up Playbill.

The Impact

Supporting OFF-BROADWAY GOES TO MT. OLIVET VILLAGE, PHILADELPHIA, PA will let the Seniors and many others know that they are not forgotten.  Supporting this project will also encourage and inspire residents of the Philadelphia Housing Authority spreading the impact far beyond Mt. Olivet Village. (Every senior is an AARP member.)

Other Ways You Can Help

You may want to give but not have two pennies to rub together.  If that's you, you can still help us.  Share our link and campaign with everyone you know on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Tumblr, Instagram, ... 

With your support, like the 2011 FREE Holiday Extravaganza, we can give the Seniors of Mt. Olivet Village an event they will not soon forget.

THANKS FOR YOUR SUPPORT..."See You At the Theatre."...

story:
HEARTS LIKE FISTS

Hearts Like Fists is a genre-bending world premiere love story written by Adam Szymkowicz and directed by Saturn Award winning director, Jaime Robledo that is set in a world of evil villains and beautiful crime fighters!

The evil Dr. X is stealing into lovers’ rooms and injecting them with a serum, stopping their hearts while they sleep entwined in the perceived safety of their lover's arms. And even though the beautiful and unstoppable Crime Fighters have been hot on his trail, they have been unable to capture him.   

Lisa, a woman who is desired by every man that sees her, has fallen in love with Peter, the ingenious but tortured doctor, who is about to finish his greatest creation - an artificial heart.  Since Peter can't let himself love, he loses himself in his work.  Since Lisa can't have Peter, she joins the Crime Fighters.

In this funny, stylized and vicious story, we learn that the heart wants what the heart wants and not answering its desires will lead to a life of sadness, loneliness and possibly evil destruction. 

 

A GIVING HEART

Producing theatre is not an easy or cheap proposition.  Your donation will not only help us bring this story to life for the first time but will also allow us to employ all the dedicated artists it takes to make quality theatre happen.

Your donation helps to employ 10 actors, a director, 5 designers, and a full production crew. For your donation, you could receive free tickets to the show, tickets to our "Comic Strip" Benefit evening on 6/23 in Silver Lake, our fabulous marketing package and other amazing incentives.

Every little bit helps us reach our goal and even if the full goal isn't met, your donation helps to offset the costs of a truly remarkable theatrical production.

 

THE PRICE OF HEROISM

Would you like to know where your donation is going to? Of course you do! So here's a breakdown of the expenses that we as producers have to cover for this show:

$1500 - Marketing and Advertising
$3000 - Materials (set, costumes, props)
$3000 - Designer Stipends
$450  - Programs
$750  - Rehearsal Space Rental

You may have noticed that that totals more than our goal here so your donation in any amount truly makes a difference. 

 

THEATRE OF NOTE

We at Theatre of NOTE are an enduring ensemble of diverse theatre artists in the heart of Hollywood who inspire, inform, and ignite our audiences by discovering courageous voices and creating entertaining, provocative, and revelatory theatrical works.

NOTE was founded in 1981 by Kevin Carr, along with Kitty Felde, Marc Gordon, Melanie MacQueen, Heather Carr and Ted Parks as a forum for original one-act plays (N.O.T.E. stood for “New One-Act Theatre Ensemble”), and to provide a stimulating environment for new playwrights. Since its inception, NOTE has been through several transitions, but the integrity of the original idea has always remained intact. We premiere an average of four main stage productions a year by writers such as W.H. Auden, Bertolt Brecht, Sheila Callaghan, Christopher Kelley, Tony Kushner, Jennifer Maisel, Leon Martell, Murray Mednick, Dennis Miles, John O’Keefe, Erik Patterson, Bill Robens and JacquelineWright. NOTE also upholds a tradition of acclaimed late-night shows, first launched in 1988, in addition to the now annual, notorious, celebrity-crowd art magnet, The Hollywood Performance Marathon. We have earned consistent commendation from theLos Angelespress and national acclaim from such publications as American Theatre. In all, NOTE has accumulated almost 100 honors and nominations, including awards from the LA WEEKLY, Backstage West, LA Stage Alliance (Ovations), and PEN International. Thanks to over 25 years of advancing theatre in Los Angeles, NOTE has received generous government and corporate support, including grants from the California Arts Council, the Cultural Affairs Department of Los Angeles, the Flintridge Foundation, the Libby Holman Foundation, the Los Angeles County Arts Commission, Robinson’s/May, Sedgwick James Inc., the Audrey Skirball-Kenis Foundation, Verizon, Time Warner and, most recently, The Hollywood Chamber of Commerce in recognition of our Young Writers Project, an outreach program benefiting local high school students.

 

**Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization and donations are tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law

story:
Our Story

ENDURE is immersive, outdoor athletic theatre. The piece addresses themes of endurance, sport, obsession, loss and resilience – through a human story set within the drama of a 26.2 mile marathon race.  Audience members meet at the performance’s ‘start line’ and follow Ms. Melanie Jones through a sonic, visual and physical journey. The audio acts as both personal soundtrack (composed by Sweden’s Christine Owman) and internal monologue, giving participants a voyeuristic peek inside a marathoner’s mind.

 

The audience follows the performer across multiple terrains as the play’s narrative unfolds, traveling through public park space and trails. The performance is a blend of physical theatre, contemporary dance and pure running that taps into both the physical and emotional experience of endurance.

 

After opening to a sold-out world premier in Brooklyn, NY, ENDURE will travel for a Western Canadian tour before returning to New York City for an extended run in 2011-2012.


The Impact

The show seeks to present a new type of "immersive" theatre experience to audiences.  ENDURE is a performance in motion. The audience are issued iPods prior to the performance beginning. While listening to 26.2 audio tracks of spoken narrative and original music in their headphones, both audience and performer move through space. A riveting physical theater performance tells a story and is supported by a lush audio world. The audience is free to walk or run alongside the performance and experience it from different perspectives as they choose.


What We Need

During our Brooklyn, NY world premier, our audiences downloaded ENDURE audio tracks onto their iPods or other MP3 devices, and brought them along to the performance.  The audiences were then led through a somewhat excruciating sync process by our trusty ENDURE team, which was fraught with several technical errors and "do-overs" during the opening of the show. 

The ENDURE team thinks that if this could be done better for our audiences, the overall show experience would be dramatically improved.  So, this is where we need some help from you.  We've done a fair amount of research into alternate audience listening devices, and have found that there are many other more elegant options out there that the show could use.  However, they aren't cheap.  A specialized system designed for audio tours costs  $8,500 for 40 listening units plus another $4,000 to remix the audio for a mono mix plus another $1500 for headphones and batteries.   40 Ipod Nano's cost $6000, and fees to to hire a programmer to create a sync mechanism for the devices could easily cost another $4,000.   

Bottom line... we can't improve this system without investing somewhere in the neighborhood of $10,000.

So, this is why we need your help.  Every dollar of your contributions will help us get closer to the purchase of an audio system that can start ENDURE off the way that it should.  This performance needs to be about the amazing experiential journey that the audience travels with performer / creator Melanie Jones, and shouldn't be hampered by technical difficulties.   With your help, we can meet this challenge, so please contribute what you can.

Thanks for helping us ENDURE for the long run ahead!
