story:
This fall Rising Sun Performance Company hits a significant landmark in our history, one that few indie theatre companies in NYC will ever reach. We celebrate 12 years of making our signature raw, evocative, engaging and authentic theatrical experiences.

As we embark on Season 12, we put an emphasis on new works created from within the ensemble, including  The world premiere of Ice Age from resident playwright Mike Aguirre, Original Devised work that we will present as guests at festivals and special events, a return to the work in progress “Henry’s Wives” along with two revivals of published works: Brilliant Traces by Cindy Lou Johnson and the Remount of RSP’s inaugural production Hellcab by Will Kern. The next 4 months promises to be filled with many exciting moments on and off stage featuring the work of our talented ensemble, playwrights, directors  and an immensely talented design and support team.  Our Fall/Winter Season will run from October 30th thru December 20th.  

We have existed this long by working in the most cost effective and innovative ways possible. By the grace of donors and grants, donated space, in kind costumes, and with the exceptionally hard work of a 100% volunteer run staff and ensemble we have presented over 55 productions & events.  However, as cost effective as we run our company, we still need a significant amount of funding in order to function as a viable company in NYC. 

IN ORDER FOR SEASON 12 TO HAPPEN,
WE MUST RAISE $10,000 WITHIN THE NEXT MONTH. 

What we have in place:
Exciting New Works By Talented Playwrights
Killer Innovative Designers
Top Notch Directors
Breathtaking Actors
Stellar Stage Managers
& Wonderful Spaces to Rehearse in 

Here is the short list of what we need to accomplish our 12th season
$1,200 for our Hellcab Venue
$5,000 for our Fall Rep Venue
$1,600 for Royalty Rights for Brilliant Traces & Hellcab
$1,950 for Festival Fees for Henry’s Wives, Ice Age & Erik (If accepted into festivals)
$3,500 to pay our 3 Stage Managers, Publicist & Designers
$2,000 for our Set, Props & Costumes
$1,500 for rehearsal space
$700 for Postcards & Posters
$500 for Liability & Event Insurance
$1,000 for sound, lighting & Audio Visual technology

Be a part of our collective history and give Season 12 a chance to succeed! Donate today!

After the success of last year’s Hotel Suite, we look to return to a non-traditional venue to provide our audiences with an up-close and unforgettable theatrical experience.

So, almost all of the pieces have fallen into place – we have an amazing group of directors, playwrights, actors and collaborators.  THIS IS the team to make our season happen, BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP to get there!  We are in negotiations with a great venue, but we need to pay for the space in order to move forward! 

Here is where you get to be a part of the show!  Every donation goes a long way to making this season and our future seasons a reality. AND with ongoing updates on this campaign, fun hands on perks including backstage access, walk on roles and meet & greet opportunities, we make sure that you aren’t just in the audience but in on the action.

DONATIONS WILL UNLOCK UPDATES AND CHALLENGES FOR CHANCES TO WIN PRIZES

Help us continue our legacy of bold, exciting and uncompromising theatre just for you.

See the sidebar for the AWESOME PERKS starting with just a $10 DONATION!

The most important element besides the cool perks is the impact of having your money support local independent theatre in a very real way.  You could be a direct part of an exciting theatrical event and a leader in supporting art on a grassroots level.

Rising Sun Performance Company is a vital part of the Off-Off Broadway landscape; being one of the longest running ensemble companies at our producing level in NYC.  Established in 2001, we are a small but prolific non-profit theatre company, having produced over 55 productions and events both locally and nationally. Check out our website www.risinsunnyc.com for more information about us.

We bring to this project our long history of collaboration, existing audience, established reputation, enthusiastic energy and exciting award nominated work.  We feel confident that when we hit our IndieGoGo Campaign Goal, our 12th Season will be our best yet!  BUT it’s still A LONG WAY off from happening.  

If we don’t reach our goal, we will have to postpone our planned productions. 

Please be aware that contributions to the Indie Go Go Campaign are NOT tax deductible. However! If you would like to make a tax deductible donation you can do so HERE at our fiscal sponsor the Field.

PLEASE HELP OUR ARTISTS BRING THEIR WORK TO LIFE!

$10,000 is just the first step, and that will only cover the very basics towards our seasons needs

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially right now? That’s OK, just by visiting our page you have already helped! Here are some BIG ways that you can make a difference in our campaign and season! 

  • Help us go viral!  Spread the word about our campaign, share it on Facebook and Twitter, invite your friends to view our campaign and ask them to share it too! Be an online cheerleader for RSP.
  • Every time our campaign is shared and viewed it brings us up higher in our category and helps get potential donors outside our network! IT REALLY DOES HELP! And don’t forget Indie Go Go has made sharing and promoting our campaign super easy! USE THESE TOOLS TO GET STARTED!
  • Want to help in other ways? WOW! Thanks you rock! Handy with a needle & thread? Like to paint or bang nails? Drive a large car or van? Want to be hands on in the making of our season? Sign up to volunteer with us! Email staff@risingsunnyc.com and we’ll put you to work!

THANK YOU FOR READING OUR CAMPAIGN  & THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

The Rising Sun Performance Company:

Ensemble:  Andrea Cordaro ,Andres Pina, Arielle Hader, Ashleigh Herndon, Carl Fengler, Christina  Germaine, Christina Williams, Cristina M Ramos, Christopher Sanchez, Elizabeth Burke, Hanna Sender, Isaac Dean, Jason LeMaster, Joe Beaudin, Kelley Evans,  Kelsey Lidsky, Kervin Peralta, Kimberly DiPersia, Larry Phillips, Lauren Tyrell, Maggie Kissinger, Marquis Wilson, Michael Aguirre, Meg Dowling, Peter Buck Dettman, Phoebe Leonard, RJ Verchaud, Ryan Dusek, Samantha Coppola, Samantha DeSimone, Toby Macdonald & Yvonne Cole

The Staff: Akia, Tiffini Minatel, Jak Prince, Jenna Rafferty, Tim Butterfield & Nzinga Williams

Interns:  Alex Scordato, Cassidy Graves, Kimberly Lin,Ted Gu, Gianfranco Lentini & Megan Bandelt

Extended Family/Associated Artists:

David Anthony, John Patrick Bray, Jeff Woodbridge, Tim Errickson, Samantha Cooper, Mike Burns, Mia Anderson,  Louisa Pough & Kate Foster
story_txt:
This fall Rising Sun Performance
Company hits a significant landmark in our history, one that few indie theatre
companies in NYC will ever reach. We celebrate 12 years of making our signature
raw, evocative, engaging and authentic theatrical experiences. 
As we embark on Season 12, we put
an emphasis on new works created from within the ensemble, including  The world premiere of Ice Age from resident
playwright Mike Aguirre, Original Devised work that we will present as guests
at festivals and special events, a return to the work in progress “Henry’s
Wives” along with two revivals of published works: Brilliant Traces by Cindy
Lou Johnson and the Remount of RSP’s inaugural production Hellcab by Will Kern.
The next 4 months promises to be filled with many exciting moments on and
off stage featuring the work of our talented ensemble, playwrights,
directors  and an immensely talented
design and support team.  Our Fall/Winter Season will run from October 30th
thru December 20th.  
We have existed this long by
working in the most cost effective and innovative ways possible. By the grace
of donors and grants, donated space, in kind costumes, and with the exceptionally
hard work of a 100% volunteer run staff and ensemble we have presented over 55
productions & events.  However, as
cost effective as we run our company, we still need a significant amount of
funding in order to function as a viable company in NYC.  
IN ORDER FOR SEASON 12 TO HAPPEN,
WE MUST RAISE $10,000 WITHIN THE NEXT MONTH.

story:
Mission Possible!

The  Mama Juggs Show 2 Major City Road Trip...

*** Funded by  Artwork & fans of Mama Juggs! **

Now through July 2010, we're teaming up with IndieGoGo.com to raise $5,000 to take Mama Juggs, an independently produced one-woman show, on a month-long fringe festival tour. This 10 show run will not be possible without funding from fans of the arts like you! With your support, I’ll be able to take the Mama Juggs show to New York, Chicago and hire the required support staff, so that the show's run is a success!

CLICK to watch Mama Juggs TRAILER


Mama Juggs is invited to perform in America's largest fringe festival in New York, and also to debut in Chicago's Fringe Festival, a chance for the show to be seen by more than 75,000 people from around the globe. We invite you to support this exciting and innovative project and help us to reach the potential of our vision. All you have to do is get on board to purchase at whatever perk level fits your budget.


The Impact

Since 2009, Mama Juggs has received ovations from California to the Cameroon, Africa rainforest.  Being that Mama Juggs is an interactive show deals with Breast Cancer Awareness, it's a perfect way to bring attention to body image stereotypes without a preachy message. Plus, all the stories are true and based on real women in the actress' family. Many who've seen Mama Juggs say it's encouraged them to have mammogram exams for the first time in years or in their lives. That alone makes this project worth while to perform and worthy of  being supported by our global community.
CLICK to read AUDIENCE COMMENTS

If Goals Not Met

Mama Juggs can't hire all the needed support staff to participate in this level of the theatre world. If you are a solo performer, not being able to afford the high fees and not being able to hire the needed personnel will prevent you from participating in the festivals that may help you get to the next level of your career. But I am determined to not let ANYTHING stop Mama Juggs's message of Breast Cancer Awareness from reaching the big stage. If all the money is not raised to fund the project, theatre goers will miss a truly unique cultural experience that will impact their lives.

CLICK to read SHOW REVIEWS

Gifts Galore For You!

Whatever you give will get you a gift. However, the more you donate the more unique your gifts! Since the  Creator of Mama Juggs is a multi-talented artist as well there's a chance to snag one-of-a-kind pieces of her mixed-media art on canvas and on bras. Gifts include: family heirlooms, hand-stitched quilts by her 100-year old great-grandma who's portrayed in Mama Juggs, 2D Posters, Professionally edited DVD of Mama Juggs shot on 3 High-Defintion cameras in Los Angeles, autographed notecards, t-shirts available in two colors, call/s/videos from character of your choice.

CLICK to peak at the ARTWORK by the actress 'rie Shontel


Costs to Play Mama Juggs in New York & Chicago

I already have $500 personal funds put away for the project ... between t-shirt and ticket sells to put back into this project. Here’s where we are on the project timeline and the areas your contributions will help cover:


NEW YORK (August 12-28th) FUNDS NEEDED $3,485

  • $0 Lodging for staff **ALREADY SPONSORED by LocLife Natural Lifestyle Store
  • $600 Festival Participation Fee for 5 shows
  • $200 Liability Insurance for Mama Staff
  • $350 Technical/Lighting/Set Director Honorarium
  • $100 Stage Manager Honorarium
  • $125 Venue Front House Manager Honorarium
  • $500 Travel Roundtrip - Stage Manager(from California to NYC) 
  • $300 Airfare
  • $200 Shipping Mama Juggs Set
  • $60 Website
  • $550 Publicity & Playbill Printing Cost
  • $500 Staff Gas/Taxi/Subway Transportation August 12-28th

CHICAGO (September 1-11th) - FUNDS NEEDED $2,000

  • $0 Lodging for staff **ALREADY SPONSORED by Private Donor
  • $400 Festival Participation Fee for 5 shows
  • $550 Publicity Printing Cost
  • $100 Stage Manager Honorarium
  • $250 Travel Roundtrip Airfare for Actress
  • $150 Actress Public Transportation
  • $200 Shipping Mama Juggs Set
  • $350 Staff Gas/Taxi/Subway Transportation Sept 1-11th

CLICK to see BIO & UPCOMING SHOWS

When the $5000 Goal Is Met... MAMA JUGGS WILL GIVE BACK!

Mama Juggs goes to New York and Chicago Fringe Festival and give the best production ever! And I will donate TEN PERCENT (10%) of Mama Juggs Ticket sells for an entire year to the an organization that's dear to my heart: Sole Sisters/UNC Lineberger exercise program for women over 21 without a current exercise regimen. Since 2009, I've raised funds to run in the annual Susan G. Komen group with the women in this group after we train for several months to complete the 5K. That’s my personal pledge to you. Supporting Breast Cancer research is important to me because it continues to save lives. Together, let's send Mama Juggs on it's first tour in New York and Chicago to raise breast awareness AND support women who are changing their lives through exercise.

SPREAD THE WORD!

Spread the word about Mama Juggs latest mission! Tell all your friends online (use the share tools below) and talk to people at the water cooler. Word of mouth is the most effective marketing tool, so your referral is a gift that keeps on giving! Use the sharing tools below to tell your social networks.

story:
Cardboard Playhouse is a non-profit, educational theatre organization, dedicated to creating a new generation of theatergoers and promoting a greater understanding of the performing arts. Cardboard Playhouse does this by raising the standards of theatrical practice and providing an environment where youth of all ages feel confident and comfortable expressing themselves as artists and in their daily lives.


Cardboard Playhouse has been operating as an Albuquerque based, community, youth theatre organization since 2005. We are committed full time to creating artistic opportunities for Albuquerque youth. Our rehearsal and performance process is open to children of all ages and backgrounds, with a particularly strong effort towards reaching youth artists that do not have the same opportunities and artistic possibilities within their school or family efforts. Since many educational institutes in our community have had to severely cut arts programming in recent years, one of our largest goals is to further our success in bringing theatre to the students of these underprivileged schools through performances and workshops.

Cardboard Playhouse believes strongly in the power of theatre arts to instill stronger community roots, educational desires, self-esteem, and imaginative possibilities for today's youth. We believe it is our responsibility as teachers and theatre artists to create opportunities for children and young adults to express themselves and reach their furthest potential in a safe and caring environment. We understand that these goals can seem lofty, especially to many underprivileged youth, but that without a strong and fulfilling sense of community responsibility, a majority of young adults lack faith in themselves and their own environment. Cardboard Playhouse uses a variety of approaches and techniques to teach Albuquerque's youth the possibilities for their own lives, and how art can reflect positively on a community as a whole.

With your contribution, Cardboard Playhouse will have the ability to strengthen our outreach efforts towards raising awareness of the auditions, classes, and opportunities that are offered to Albuquerque youth, especially those who have had very little exposure to the performing arts. Although some of the efforts are through marketing and a stronger web presence, the most effective efforts are when Cardboard Playhouse is able to bring our productions into the public schools free of charge. There are very few students in our community that have had the experience of seeing a live theatrical performance, however, even fewer have had the inspirational opportunity of seeing a production that features students of their same age range and cultural background. We have found this reflection to be an important part of a students first experience with the performing arts. Cardboard Playhouse, with your generous support, will be providing more opportunities for students to not only grow as artists, but experience a heightened sense of esteem and expression, whether this be as a first time audience, or through the development as young theatre artists.

story:
With a fierce, awesome, delicious second season planned, Clockwise has actors memorizing lines and learning songs (for our first musical!), designers sketching, dreaming and creating, tickets are being sold, and it is all just fabulous.

Now all we need is an Apple.

And not just any Apple.

Yup, Clockwise needs a Macintosh computer.

One dedicated to do only the bidding of theatre-type things. Sound effects. Video projections. All that complicated technical stuff which takes the mastery of our brilliant designers and transforms it into magic.

And to make this magic happen consistently every performance…we need a new Mac capable of running the software we need. We’ve had some scary moments with secondhand equipment and we just can’t take any more computer-created gray hair!

So all we are looking to fund is an Apple. (The big price tag includes an extended warranty so we can protect our valuable asset!)

This is an Apple you can visit in the stage manager’s booth before any performance. An Apple which will bring joy and elation to designers, directors, and stage managers who we are so blessed to have pitching in with our scrappy troupe! A sweet and tart deliciously wonderful Macintosh to help us make sweet and tart and delicious theatre!

Any amount is appreciated: $5, $25, $100 -- the whole $1,650 enchilada. Yes, we are a 501(c)3 organization so you may deduct your generous donation to the extent allowed by those guys and gals at the IRS.

With deepest thanks for your sweet donation,
the fruit-loving Clockwise Theatre Company

story:
Our Story

The Harbor Stage Company is Amanda, Bob, Stacy, Jonathan, Lewis, and Brenda- 6 theater artists determined to preserve and advance the legacy of progressive, engaging live performance on Wellfleet Harbor.  The company's artists double as its administrators, ensuring an operation that prioritizes the artistic process.     

 

The Impact

For almost 30 years, the iconic theater at 15 Kendrick has provided a haven for fierce, delightful theater.  It has been home to an incredible assortment of engaged and engaging artists, a group of whole-hearted, serious-minded collaborators who've sacrificed to keep the space's puckish spirit alive and kicking.  There's no place like the Harbor, and we think it's wrong to let it slip away. 

 

It took the Harbor's previous tenant decades to work up to presenting a full season of professional theater.  We're trying to pick up where they left off with about 70 days of prep. Think we're crazy?  Have a thing or two to tell us about what we're getting ourselves into? Please write your sentiments on a series of twenty dollar bills and mail them in.  We can't wait to hear your thoughts!

 

But Seriously...

We're determined to make the Harbor a place where art comes first,  tickets are affordable, and artists are fairly paid.  Ideals don't come cheap, so right now we're moving fast to meet a very serious budget- researching grants, courting sponsors, and learning to play online poker.  

 

Still we're going to need some extra help funding our inaugural season.  And this $10K online campaign represents only a small fraction of what we need to raise overall.  We know that many of you are artists and working stiffs yourselves, so we're grateful for whatever you can contribute. Every little bit will mean a lot to us, and to a community we think deserves to be celebrated and preserved.  We'll thank you for your support in our hearts, in line at the market, and in the sands of Wellfleet Harbor (see our perks section! →).   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Does anyone have a piano? (In-kind donations are also very welcome!)
story_txt:
Our Story
The Harbor Stage Company is Amanda, Bob, Stacy, Jonathan, Lewis, and Brenda- 6 theater artists determined to preserve and advance the legacy of progressive, engaging live performance on Wellfleet Harbor.  The company's artists double as its administrators, ensuring an operation that prioritizes the artistic process.     
 
The Impact
For almost 30 years, the iconic theater at 15 Kendrick has provided a haven for fierce, delightful theater.  It has been home to an incredible assortment of engaged and engaging artists, a group of whole-hearted, serious-minded collaborators who've sacrificed to keep the space's puckish spirit alive and kicking.  There's no place like the Harbor, and we think it's wrong to let it slip away.

Please write your sentiments on a series of twenty dollar bills and mail them in.  We can't wait to hear your thoughts!
 
But Seriously...

Every little bit will mean a lot to us, and to a community we think deserves to be celebrated and preserved.  We'll thank you for your support in our hearts, in line at the market, and in the sands of Wellfleet Harbor (see our perks section! →).

story:
DIVAfest 2014

In May over 50 women artists are presenting DIVAfest 2014, a festival of theater, burlesque, music, poetry, art and more.  We need your help to raise $5,000 to complete the budget for the festival.

The budget for the 13th annual DIVAfest is $30,000 and half of that is artist fees and salaries.  We have raised most of the money needed from our gala fundraiser and other donations, along with ticket sales, but need your help for this last part.

Featured in DIVAfest 2014 are:

·  Kristin Hersh’s RAT GIRL – the stage adaptation of Kristin Hersh’s memoire, a surreal and comical exploration of how we make peace with who we are.

·  At the White Rabbit Burlesque – a topsy-turvy, titillating tumble down the mental rabbit hole, featuring an eclectic burlesque cast.

·  The Pas De Quatre – a hilarious look at the 19th century clash of the four reigning divas of ballet.

·  Diane di Prima – a reading by San Francisco poet laureate and Beat icon.

·  DIVAs Tell All – excerpts of work in progress by women artists, with audiences welcome to provide support and feedback.

·  Erika Atkinson – reading more tales from her tapestry of travels.

·  Transformation Into Reality and Women In Progress – a photo exhibit by DIVAfest visual artist Serena Morelli showing how scenes, stories and characters created for the stage are not fiction but, reality.

story:
Burlesque-A-Pades 101

Burlesque-A-Pades is a touring burlesque and variety revue created by the World Famous Pontani Sisters in 2006.  Over the years Burlesque-A-Pades has been hard at work spreading the glamour gospel and bringing the best of burlesque to venues throughout the USA.  As one of the first neo-burlesque productions to hit the glittery highway, Burlesque-A-Pades has been a trail blazing show, often bringing burlesque to markets that haven't seen a tail feather or panel skirt in over 30 years.  Keeping the art of burlesque alive and sharing it is our passion!  Not only do we present top-notch performers, we reinvent classic burlesque skits and incorporate all cast production numbers into each and every show. Burlesque-A-Pades is our version of a true golden age burlesque revue for the modern generation.  This style of burlesque was and is a unique form of American entertainment, we want to keep it alive and share it with the world, but this December we need your help to make our 14 city tour shine! 

What We Need & What You Get

We need funding to take Burlesque-A-Pades to the next level! We love our show, but we want to make it bigger and better! Over the years, touring has become more costly, and changes in the entertainment industry make it hard for independent shows like ours to stay afloat. But we are sashaying on and hoping that with your support we can grow our show. This December we are taking on one of our most ambitious tours to date, we have expanded our cast so that we can serve up more production numbers and variety all month long.  With an expanded cast comes more cost, but most importantly, a portion of the funds raised here will go towards covering a van to transport our cavalcade of stars as well as our set, props and costumes.

The remainder of these funds will be used to support our tour with an advertising budget. This is something we have never had before, but could be pivotal in increasing our success and ensuring the growth of our show.  Advertising in select markets will be key in helping Burlesque-A-Pades fan kick through the ceiling and into your town year after year!

Plus we are offering amazing perks! Giving was never so good! Not only are you supporting the arts and an amazing show, you can get great gifts, like a private tap dancing lesson with Helen Pontani, a signed Go-Go Robics I DVD, or even a nice Italian dinner in NYC with the entire cast!

Every little bit helps, and every single penny earned here will go to support this show as we spread the glamour gospel this December.

Why?

Live entertainment is a rare opportunity to share a moment with your favorite artist or to experience something totally new in the flesh. Seeing Burlesque-A-Pades is drinking from the well of this unique and uniquely American form of theatrical entertainment.  By donating to our cause, you aren’t only helping our show, you are helping to support the medium of live entertainment and to solidify the position of burlesque as a true genre of entertainment.

Well what can I say folks, the show must go on, help us make it happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute? It’s ok, we are performers, we understand the Ramen Soup diet days! There are a million ways to help, but let’s start with these 2!

·  Spread the word! Please share our campaign on your social media pages and with your friends! You can even use the awesome Indiegogo share tools!

·  Come to the show! Come out this December and join in the fun, we would love to see you in the audience!

Tour Dates

(For an updated list and more details please visit www.angiepontani.com)

Thursday, December 5th – TBA

Friday, December 6th – Bridge Street Live (Collinsville, CT)

Saturday, December 7th – Asbury Lanes (Asbury Park, NJ)

Sunday, December 8th- TBA

Monday, December 9th – Tip Top Café (Grand Rapids, MI)

Tuesday, December 10th – South Gate House (Newport, KY)

Wednesday, December 11th – Martyrs (Chicago, IL)

Thursday, December 12th – Fitzgeralds (Berwyn, IL)

Friday, December 13th – Beachland Ballroom (Cleveand, OH)

Saturday, December 14th – The Rex Theater (Pittsburgh, PA)

Sunday, December 15th – TBA

Monday, December 16th – TBA

Tuesday, December 17th- TBA

Wednesday, December 18th – Iron Horse (Northampton, MA)

Thursday, December 19th – Rams Head Tavern (Annapolis, MD)

Friday, December 20th – Katie's Bar (Smithtown, NY)

Saturday, December 21st – Le Poisson Rouge (NYC)

Monday, December 30th – The Birchmere (Alexandria, VA)

story:
Avirah, the University of Maryland's Israeli Dance Troupe, is a returning dance troupe to the university after a short hiatus. The group consists of many previous Israeli dancers as well as ones new to Israeli Dancing, and is energized and excited to make its return to the Israeli Dancing world! As a newer group, we have to work extra hard to accomplish all of our goals and that's where you come in! We are looking forward to performing later this year at the annual DC and New York Israeli Dance Festivals, as well as other venues around campus. But, of course, we can't do these performances without costumes. Additionally, we are looking to raise money to cover transportation needs and help pay for different Israeli Dance experiences that will allow us to better ourselves as performers and members of the Israeli Dance Community. Furthermore, this year we have pledged to donate 50% of our proceeds to the DC Israeli Dance Festival to help ensure this event that we love so much can continue to be successful for many years to come. We are hoping you can help us out by covering some of these costs and contributing to our donation to the DC Israeli Dance Festival!

If you have any other questions, please do not hesitate to contact one of the team members, or email us at avirahumd@gmail.com!

story:
The Remix Festival

Is coming to Philadelphia May 1st-4th, presented by <fidget> in collaboration with Annie Wilson and Mascher Space Cooperative. Four incredible artists from around the country are coming to Philadelphia:

John Jesurun (NYC)

Meredith Bove (DC)

Jen Rosenblit (NYC)

Rachel Slater (Portland, OR)

 to remix the dances of three amazing Philly-based choreographers, and vice versa.

Philly artists:

Susan Rethorst

Gregory Holt

Chelsea Murphy and Magda San Milan.

The festival is a unique chance to look at choreography, as process, in performance. Artists come to the festival on Tuesday, April 30th, with pieces of different levels of "doneness." Some are works in progress, some are finished pieces that have been performed many times. Then they switch dances around, and spend two days remixing the dance that they've been given. They haven't seen this dance before. They might not know the choreographer at all. They have free reign to do what they want in six hours of studio time. And then they are performed, side-by-side. The original pieces might be polished. The remixed pieces might be a hot mess. The entire festival is a mash-up of aesthetics, of place, and of process.

 The festival is made possible through the unique partnership of Mascher Space Cooperative and <fidget>, two studios and venues next door to each other.  The festival has received an extraordinary amount of in-kind donations, including food from the SHARE food program.

This fundraiser is to cover all the costs of the festival that cannot be donated- plane and bus tickets, gas, food, guest speakers, marketing, and any food not donated.

Any amount we fundraise over $2100 will go directly to the choreographers.

Budget and Perks

The majority of the budget comes from travel expenses, food, and marketing.

Travel for 3 Portland dancers, 1 DC dancer, and 5 NYC dancers:

$1,159.84. This is the bulk of the expenses.

Postcard and poster design and printing: $196.64

Guest speakers at IP law roundtable: $150

Food for shows: $200

Mini honorarium so out-of-towners can get around: $160

Unexpected expense padding: $150

Indiegogo fee: $82 

Total: $2100

It's a pretty bare bones budget. <fidget> and Mascher are opening their doors the entire festival so the artists can get down to work. Everyone is volunteering their time to make the dances happen. We are soliciting food donations, and have already received pledges from the SHARE Food Program (thank you Jillian Brainard!). But we can't make the festival happen without this last push of financial support from you: festival-goer, art-supporter, friends, or family.

The perks are pretty sweet, if I say so myself. Annie will make you dinner. Or she'll teach you yoga, or give you reiki. Or, this is your chance to produce a festival. Or you'll finally have a cocktail named after you. But most importantly, you'll receive the perk of making fresh, experimental choreography happen in a new way.

The Impact

The Remix Festival is inspired by The Wrecking Project, which was inspired by Susan Rethorst's technique of wrecking. However, it's the first of its kind: where all involved artists assemble, meet, re-imagine, and perform each others' dances in the course of five days.

It's a unique way to see what these artists are thinking about and why. It's a way to investigate locality- are there ideas that are uniquely "Philadelphian"? Or "District of Columbian"? Are there aesthetics that live in Portland that we can learn about as those aesthetics are laid on the scaffolding of a dance made in Philly?

Who owns the remixed dance in the end? What stays in a dance and what disappears when a different artist takes over? And what happens when you trade dances and spend two days working with it? How does choreography spread ideas in the studio?

Yes! You can make a tax-deductible contribution!

Just not on this campaign. Especially if you would like to co-produce the festival, please contact Annie Wilson at anne.macg.wilson@gmail.com to set up a tax-deductible donation.

And, as always, the second-best way to help is by sharing the campaign far and wide with folks who you think would be as interested in this festival as you are.

story:
Breve reseña

Tengo el honor de haber sido invitado al Chicago Improv Festival, siendo el primer Venezolano en alcanzar este honor, ire como parte del elenco de Atomica Arts, dirigido por el maestro Will Luera, siendo el primer venezolano en presentarme en este pretigioso festival, el mas grande en el mundo en su genero.

Para los que no conocen mi trabajo llevo 5 anios haciendo teatro de Improvisacion y 3 como entrenador de Improvisadores en el Ateneo de Caracas, el Centro Cultural Chacao, Centro de Arte La Estancia, El Festival de Teatro de Caracas, La Universidad Catolica Andres Bello, La Universidad Catolica Santa Rosa, ademas de para importantes marcas como Labs Roche, Bayer, Telefonica Movistar, Banco Central de Venezuela, Empresas Polar, Coca-Cola FEMSA, Sanitas de Venezuela, Brigestone Firestone y muchas mas, aplicando la "Impro" en la empresa. Ademas por toda Venezuela siendo ocasion de fundar nuevos grupos de improvisacin en el pais. He tenido la oportunidad de participar como actor, productor, director o tecnico en todos los formatos de improvisacion existentes en Venezuela.

Ademas de tomar cursos con grandes maestros de teatro e improvisacion en mi pais Venezuela y en Latinoamerica, fui a Colombia a cursar en 2011 el Diplomado Internacional de Improvisacion Teatral y en 2013 a The Second City Training Center Chicago a tomar su intensivo de verano en Impro y Comedia, para el cual este prestigioso centro me otorgo una beca.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes


  • Estoy buscando fondos para cubrir el costo del pasaje a Chicago el cual por las circunstancias que vive Venezuela es muy costoso o incluso solo se puede adquirir en moneda extrangera.
  • A quiene colaboren con mi viaje, les ofrezco entrenamiento en Improvisacion y escritura de comedia gratuitos por 8 horas academicas. Ademas de franelas (remeras, sudaderas) con disenios exclusivos sobre improvisacion y comedia. Y suvenirs del Chicago Improv Festival.
  • Si no logro alcanzar la meta, usare los fondos para producir un espectaculo gratuito de improvisacion teatral, La Caimanera de Improvisacion.

Experiencia

  • En mi viaje a Chicago para estudiar en Second City hice una campania similar en la que recaude 200 USD.

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

  • Si no puedes ayudar economicamente, ayudamente difundiendo esta campania, o con algunos contactos que me pudieran colaborar.

Un Abrazo y Gracias!!!!!

Ademas por toda Venezuela siendo ocasion de fundar nuevos grupos de improvisacin en el pais. He tenido la oportunidad de participar como actor, productor, director o tecnico en todos los formatos de improvisacion existentes en Venezuela.Ademas de tomar cursos con grandes maestros de teatro e improvisacion en mi pais Venezuela y en Latinoamerica, fui a Colombia a cursar en 2011 el Diplomado Internacional de Improvisacion Teatral y en 2013 a The Second City Training Center Chicago a tomar su intensivo de verano en Impro y Comedia, para el cual este prestigioso centro me otorgo una beca.Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes
Estoy buscando fondos para cubrir el costo del pasaje a Chicago el cual por las circunstancias que vive Venezuela es muy costoso o incluso solo se puede adquirir en moneda extrangera. 

A quiene colaboren con mi viaje, les ofrezco entrenamiento en Improvisacion y escritura de comedia gratuitos por 8 horas academicas. Ademas de franelas (remeras, sudaderas) con disenios exclusivos sobre improvisacion y comedia. Y suvenirs del Chicago Improv Festival.

Si no logro alcanzar la meta, usare los fondos para producir un espectaculo gratuito de improvisacion teatral, La Caimanera de Improvisacion.
ExperienciaEn mi viaje a Chicago para estudiar en Second City hice una campania similar en la que recaude 200 USD.
Otras formas en las que puedes ayudarSi no puedes ayudar economicamente, ayudamente difundiendo esta campania, o con algunos contactos que me pudieran colaborar.
Un Abrazo y Gracias!!!!!

story:
letter from Marlena Wolfe

Hello all! 

For those of you who don't know me, my name is Marlena Wolfe and I have been working as a professional artist in dance for 10 years in NYC. Besides working as an administrator, teacher, and dancer, I have increasingly been given more opportunities to choreograph on professionals and budding artists throughout the years and with each and every opportunity have had the need to give back to the dance community more and more. Making dances for me is a chance to share, support, and encourage each other as artists to keep pushing the boundaries of not only our art form but of who we are as people. Only then will we really inspire audiences to continue giving the love, support, and let's face it, resources, to an art form that deserves more exposure. For me, there are no back-up dancers behind Beyonce, there are just dancers, and the only way to continue giving our art form that presence in the world is in continuing to support the youth and education.

the Wolfe project began with this platform three years ago when a group of ten artists plus myself traveled to my hometown in Champion, Ohio to put on three shows as a fundraiser. Not only was this the first opportunity I had to showcase my work but it was also for a cause very close to my heart. All the funds raised benefited the scholarship fund my two sisters and I started in my Mom's name to award two scholarships every year: 1) to a student seeking higher education and 2) to a student seeking to further his/her dance education and training. When my Mom passed from cancer, it was one of the most difficult moments in my life. However, what she left me with was a passion to keep going as she kept going through all of life's struggles. My Dad is a constant reminder of this passion and that hard work and love for people is the only way to build a life to be proud of and enjoy living. My goal is to have the Wolfe project assimilate a similar role for others and support those that are dreaming as big as I did when I first moved to NYC through philanthropic endeavors.

For the last three years, I have worked at Peridance Capezio Center as the Certificate Program Coordinator. Besides playing an integral part in designing the infrastructure of the Program and managing daily affairs, I proudly act as mentor and adviser to students from 20+ countries with a variety of backgrounds, personal circumstances, and career aspirations. In speaking with student after student, money is of constant concern; Survival is the name of the game. Money holds each student back from receiving the high quality and well-rounded training and education needed to be conscious professional dancers and business people. It also just makes having a reasonable standard of living in an inflated city that much harder. I am inspired by the generosity of Igal Perry, Artistic Director, who does everything he can to organize financial aid for Certificate Program students in many forms and I would like to contribute. 

On August 3, 2014, a team of artists, otherwise known as the Wolfe pack - 

Dani-Juliet Atkinson, Shay Bares, Sara Braun, Katarina Lott, Melinda Moeller, Jackie Nowicki, Mikelle Rindflish, Suzie Rzecznik, Lynda Senisi, Mary Kate Sheehan, Daron Wehle, Marlena Wolfe, and special guest choreographers and artists 

- are coming together to do just that. There will be two shows (3:30p & 7:00p) and all tickets sales for this event will be given in Scholarship money to Certificate Program students.

As I seek new endeavors and plan to move to the Netherlands on August 11, I desire to leave a decade in New York with a bang and begin to give back to all those who supported and paved the way for me by passing it forward. Not to mention my 30th birthday is just two days before on August 1! This event is a time for reflection, celebration, and forward-thinking, and all that I ask is that you join the Wolfe pack. 

With heartfelt gratitude,

Marlena

_________________________________________________


This indiegogo campaign is solely to cover the expenses of preparing, producing, and executing the two shows at Peridance Capezio Center's Salvatore Capezio Theater on August 3, 2014 at 3:30p and 7:30p. Please donate what you can... $1, $20, $50, $100. The cliche exists for a reason because it is true - Anything helps us get closer to our goal of $10,000! 


join the pack! 

By donating any amount of money, you become a member of the Wolfe pack. This is our first perk and it's for everyone who contributes to our campaign with $10, $20, $500... it doesn't matter how much! the Wolfe project will recognize your contribution in the event's program by listing your full name. (For all other perks, see the sidebar on the right.)


why should you join the pack?

Becoming a pack member is necessary to help us put together events like the one we are launching on August 3, 2014 to raise funds for students seeking higher educations in dance. All tickets sales from the event will be donated as scholarship money to Certificate Program students at Peridance Capezio Center.


who are the guest choreographers and artists?

So far our guest choreographers include:


Mike Esperanza, Diego Funes, Tyler Gilstrap, Jana Hicks, and Breton Tyner-Bryan

"Like" our Facebook page now "the Wolfe project" and stay tuned for more. This event includes many choreographers and artists currently shaping, invigorating, and challenging the NYC and international dance scene. 


a brief look at the Wolfe project in the future

I am hoping to do an event of this nature every year to support aspiring dance students. As I jump into this head first feeling like I don't know how to swim, I am thankful you took the time to make it all the way down to reading this. From the bottom of my heart, thank you and cheers to many more.


Other Ways You Can Help

Contact Marlena at thewolfeproject@aol.com to inquire about other ways in which you can help. This campaign will not be successful without you. Let's make some noise!


Don't forget!

"Like" our Facebook page "the Wolfe project" to stay up-to-date with all the planning and fun until August 3, 2014.

story:
My name is Claire Farmer and I am passionate about dance and bringing it to people all over the world. I have been studying dance since the age of 5 and will be commencing a MA Dance Movement Psychotherapy in September. It is my intention to make dance and this fantastic form of therapy available to everyone and anyone who needs it, without the enormous price tag that often accompanies these services.

 

The only way that I can do this though is to complete a Masters in Dance Movement Psychotherapy to qualify me to practice and for this I am in search of funds to help me afford the 3 year course which is where you lovely people come in.

 

ABOUT DANCE MOVEMENT THERAPY

Dance Movement Therapy is the youngest of the arts therapies and can be used to treat a whole array of issues, emotional, psychosomatic, traumatic, actute or chronic illness. Arts therapies are also the only form of therapy to be effective in the treatment of schizophrenia. Dance therapy does not require the participant to have any dance training and can be used by anyone of any age.  Many people are currently referred for 'talking therapies' such as Cognitive Behavioural Therapy or counselling via their GP, however these types of therapies do not suit everyone as they may not feel comfortable vocalising something which may be traumatic or difficult to express.  Using the arts therapies you are able to go through 'experiential' exercises whereby ou can explore a certain emotion or event without having to describe it in depth.  This can be a much easier process for many people and something that I feel should be more prevelant within a GPs referal. Dance Therapy can also be used as a one-to-one therapy or as group therapy.

 

The Arts Therapies are available on the NHS but mainly focus on Art Therapy which is already more progressed than dance movement therapy. 

ABOUT ME

Now a bit about myself. I began dancing aged 5 and continued dance classes through to college when I then studied performing arts, theatre and art and design before moving onto University to complete a BA (hons) Dance Studies with drama, theatre and performance studies. My original intention was to become a professional dancer but I have since discovered that it is not the performing per se that I enjoy but more the experience dance gives me, the ability to get lost in the movement and to use dance as a form of self expression. It is this feeling and experience that I now wish to share with others and to bring dance and movement into their lives to enhance their understanding of themselves and to facilitate healing.

 

Over the past few years I have assisted on a number of dance workshops including with young people, those with autism and other learning difficulties, teaching primary school children as well as dance students. My experiences have allowed me to see how dance can touch the lives of people from all backgrounds and of all ages.

 

I am particulary interested in the differences between dance and dance therapy in the US compared to the UK and this is an area I would like to explore more as part of my studies. My intention throughout my studies and on completion is to be able to being Dance Therapy to all those who need it. Often those most in need of support are those that cannot easily afford the treatment they require. This is something I would dearly like to tackle, to be able to make Dance Therapy easily accessible to all those that need it and to bring more awareness of this type of therapy as 'talking' therapies are not suited to all people and perhaps more people would seek support if they knew this type of therapy was available.

 

 HOW YOU CAN HELP

In order to make this come true though I need to complete a 3 year Masters for which I need to raise funds to pay the tuition fees. I am completing the course part time to allow me to work at the same time to help fund my studies but unfortunately I am unable to reach the fees that are required which is why I ask for the support of the wonderful generous people on indiegogo.

 

With your help I will be able to help those people who are perhaps in a dark place and need some guidance, so I ask you not to think of funding the course but funding the outcome and the effect this can have on others lives.  One day I would love to set up an Arts Centre that houses all forms of arts and therapies and can also welcome those that would otherwise not be able to afford it and this is the first step towards that.

 

Thank you so much for taking the time to read this, I really appreciate any help, however large or small, it all counts.

story:
Zee Zee Theatre invites you to help us proudly present the return of the Jessie award-nominated play 

MY FUNNY VALENTINE by Dave Deveau

Directed by Cameron Mackenzie

Starring Anton Lipovetsky (2012 Sam Payne Award for Most Promising Newcomer)

February 19-March 2, 2013

 

WHAT CRITICS ARE SAYING ABOUT THE PRODUCTION:

The play explores the tragic murder of gay, 15-year old Lawrence King and takes the audience along for an artistic, rigorous conversation to find the humanity in the midst of this terrible hate crime.

“My Funny Valentine is a superb piece of theatre. The script is brilliant. This is the first play I’ve see by Dave Deveau, but it certainly won’t be the last.” – Meghan Leigh, HUSH Magazine

“Anton Lipovetsky is a compelling performer who embodies the idiocyncracies and contradictions of each character with energy and compassion… this is a near-perfect performance from one of Vancouver’s most talented young actors.”

"The success of the play relies heavily on a tour de force performance by solo actor Anton Lipovetsky... My Funny Valentine is serious, yet at times humorous, it's disturbing and yet serene. Anton Lipovetsky offers a nuanced performance that won't be easy to forget." -Review Vancouver

 “Lipovetsky’s delivery was so true on opening night that I had to swallow sobs.” – Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight

“The characters in My Funny Valentine were compelling and nuanced. Their distances from the action allowed what could have been a straightforward real-life horror story to unfold like a murder mystery, a whydunit where the answer will never make any sense”        -Mark Leiren-Young, Vancouver Sun

“The play transports the audience through gales of laughter, moments of clarity, fits of rage, and places of aching, compassionate sorrow…. We are left questioning what can possibly be done to stop this from continuing to happen – a heartbreaking and relevant question in recent months.”  - Brian Patterson, Laura Murray PR

“Lipovetsky is a bright-eyed, eager, engaging young actor who embraces each of the characters with a thoughtful sensitivity to their idiosyncrasies. “ -Jo Ledingham, Vancouver Courier

 

A death goes far beyond its immediate surroundings: it echoes through a community. On February 11, 2008, in California, 15-year-old Lawrence King asked his classmate Brandon McInerney to be his valentine. The next day, McInerney shot King twice in the head. After being declared brain-dead, King passed away on February 14, 2008–Valentine’s Day.

The critically acclaimed, Jessie-nominated My Funny Valentine examines the fracturing of opinion within a community in the face of this horrendous act and enters the minds of seven people on the fringes of a murder that will forever affect them. The play invites the audience to search through the confusing and chaotic implications of this death to find their own humanity.

"(I am) challenged to become an 11-year-old girl, a middle aged woman, a disgruntled father, (…) with each character presenting a complex and varied viewpoint of a heartbreaking true story. A timely piece and an absolute gift to an actor--I feel tremendously lucky." - Anton Lipovetsky, actor

Showtimes:
Tuesday-Friday, 8 pm
Saturday, 5 pm & 9 pm
Matinees: Wednesday 1 pm (Pay What You Can), Sunday 2 pm

Firehall Arts Centre, 280 East Cordova Street
Tickets are available at 604.689.0926 or www.firehallartscentre.ca

 

THE RESPONSE:

When MY FUNNY VALENTINE premiered in 2011 it was nominated for three Jessie Richardson Awards (Outstanding New Play, Outstanding Set Design, Outstanding Lighting Design) and won the Sydney Risk Prize for Outstanding Play by an Emerging Playwright. 

The play went on to have a second production at the DUBLIN GAY THEATRE FESTIVAL where it was nominated for Outstanding Writing, Outstanding Directing and won Outstanding Performance (Male). It is slated for a third production in Johannesberg, South Africa this fall. 

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP:

Despite the new cast and updated script, most government bodies see this as a remount, thus making us ineligible for our usual public funding. So we are turning to you to help in this process and ensure that we're able to keep this show going. 

We are happy to have Firehall Arts Centre on board co-presenting the work, but we are still responsible for sizeable production costs, which is where your contributions will assist us! 

Production costs include paying our performer, stage manager, our design team, as well as venue costs like FOH staff, Box Office staff, marketing costs, and our graphic designer.

In addition to helping support vital cultural programming here in Vancouver, there are of course perks attached to helping us out, including access to Zee Zee Nightlife Events like HUSTLA: HOMO HIP HOP, SHINDIG: SISSY SOCK HOP and APOCALYPSTICK: EAST VAN'S DRAG SHOW and even a special invitation for the first Annual ZEE ZEE TEA TIME at La Petite Cuillere. 

 

ABOUT ZEE ZEE THEATRE: 

Zee Zee Theatre (founded in 2008 by Cameron Mackenzie and Dave Deveau) is a company devoted to telling small stories in the lives of the marginalized. Through signature productions like My Funny Valentine, the company has established itself as having unique and provocative conversations with diverse audiences, offering recognizable situations with poignancy and building a connection with our surrounding community in order to inspire unity in shared human experience.

Over the past five seasons Zee Zee Theatre has helped carve our spaces and voices for marginalized communities and we hope that you will help us continue on that path. We're not asking for you to empty your wallets (though if you're in a place to do so, we would gratefully accept!), but more to throw a couple coins into the hat as it goes around to ensure that our community-based efforts continue.

In addition to helping support vital cultural programming here in Vancouver, there are of course perks attached to helping us out, including access to Zee Zee Nightlife Events like HUSTLA: HOMO HIP HOP, SHINDIG: SISSY SOCK HOP and APOCALYPSTICK: EAST VAN'S DRAG SHOW and even a special invitation for the first Annual ZEE ZEE TEA TIME at La Petite Cuillere. 
 
ABOUT ZEE ZEE THEATRE: 
Zee Zee Theatre (founded in 2008 by Cameron Mackenzie and Dave Deveau) is a company devoted to telling small stories in the lives of the marginalized. Through signature productions like My Funny Valentine, the company has established itself as having unique and provocative conversations with diverse audiences, offering recognizable situations with poignancy and building a connection with our surrounding community in order to inspire unity in shared human experience.
Over the past five seasons Zee Zee Theatre has helped carve our spaces and voices for marginalized communities and we hope that you will help us continue on that path. We're not asking for you to empty your wallets (though if you're in a place to do so, we would gratefully accept!), but more to throw a couple coins into the hat as it goes around to ensure that our community-based efforts continue.

story:
FIGHT OR FLIGHT

CART/HORSE THEATRE 2012/13

After six years of independant productions, Cart/Horse is proud to present our first full season of shows, including our first world premiere. 

Our mainstage show...

THIS LIME TREE BOWER by Conor McPherson. Directed by Sarah Dodd

December 6 to 22, 2012 at the Berkeley Theatre Upstairs.

Our studio show...

EIRLYS AND ECKHART by Arlin Dixon. Directed by Matt White.

March 6 to 16, 2013 at Theatre Passe Muraille's Backspace.

Two remarkable plays, one by an established master, the other by a talented new voice. In McPherson's Lime Tree... three young Dublin men recount a fateful weekend in this overlooked gem by the author of The Weir and Shining City. In new playwright Arlin Dixon's Eirlys and Eckhart, a pair of misfits spend the night fighting paranoia and fear as the kitchen walls seem to close in. A powerfully understated first play from a unique new writer.

 

ABOUT THE COMPANY

Where we’ve been


Cart/Horse Theatre has been producing intimate and independent shows since 2006. We have played in Toronto as well as taking some of our shows on the road to Nova Scotia. We`ve been nominated for some awards and we`ve won some others. We have pushed ourselves to grow bigger and better with each show, learning from our mistakes and daring to make new ones. We have delivered top quality shows, featuring performers, directors and designers of the highest caliber, that have remained accessible and affordable for the entire theatre going community. We have only just gotten started.


Where we are
The 2012/13 season, which we`ve named Fight or Flight, is our largest and most ambitious to date. With two fully realized productions we are employing more artists and technical staff than ever before. This is the first year we will stage a completely original script by a talented young playwright making her professional debut. This year is a major turning point for us. Make or break time. With so much on the line this year, it comes down to fight or flight.


Where we’re going
Our dream as a theatre company is to have a home. Not just a home for ourselves, one for the community as well. A place where artists and audience can share a space and share an evening and everyone feels included. A building designed with the audience experience on the top of the priority list. How can we make everyone feel like they’ve come home, to their favorite place, to see their favorite stories told. This will take us a long time, we will have to continue moving from space to space until we can find somewhere to settle. This is what we are building towards and I hope you can be a part of it.

Matthew Gorman, Artistic Director

 

WHERE YOU COME IN

All contributions made through this campaign will go towards the single largest cost of independant producing, performance space. By devoting the funds raised here to the rental fees of our two venues we can ensure that the revenues from the shows goes to the professional actors, directors, designers, writers, technicians, stage managers and administrators that work to bring these shows to the public.

 

YOUR IMPACT


Theatre doesn't happen until the audience steps in the door. Your contributions here help us keep tickets prices low so that more of our community has a chance to come to the theatre. With your help we can continue to offer discounted rush seats to many performances as well as complimentary tickets to various student and community groups.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Come to the show! Visit the website, our facebook or twitter page. 

Read more plays. Go see a play in your city. Put on a show.

story:
Under a Rainbow Flag is an exciting new musical about gay soldiers in World War II. Based on a true story of Jon Phillips - still alive in Chicago - it tells the story of the men he meets in the war and their fates in the decade thereafter.

The show is a lot of fun with some great ballads like the one you are listening to now. Leo Schwartz is the author and he has created a vivid and beautiful portrait of this group of young soldiers and the friendship that binds them. 

We will be running March 23 to April 21, 2013 in Chicago, and your support goes to the actors, musicians, and other artists crafting this beautiful and exciting project. 

Pride Films and Plays, the producer, is a new organization developing new LGBT works for the stage and screen. This is our first large musical project, and we need your support to fully achieve our dreams. 

Ultimately, we hope Under A Rainbow Flag will have a long life at regional theaters everywhere. Your support now is the first step to making that happen as we use our rehearsal time to hone every aspect of the production. 

If you can't support the project now, please keep in touch with us on our Facebook page, and let everyone you know who supports new musicals, or who supports LGBT causes that we need your help. 

If you want to make a donation in support of all the work of Pride Films and Plays, please go here.

Thanks for helping us tell this story. We will be sharing all the details of the production, and reviews as they come in!

David Zak, Executive Director, and the entire creative team for Under A Rainbow Flag.

story:
The Invisible City Project

"What begins as undifferentiated space becomes place as we get to know it better and endow it with value. … Furthermore, if we think of space as that which allows movement, then place is pause; each pause in movement makes it possible for location to be transformed into place. ... Home is intimate place."   ~Yi Fu Tuan

What if the city you lived in was personified as an artist?  Would you be able to point out unifying characteristics that run through its diverse body of work?  How might this awareness shift your sense of place?  Well, we have a hunch.  Perhaps because one's sense of place is something experienced in the body, we can learn something about a place through the embodied practice of artists who call the place home?  Perhaps the movement artists among us--dance, theater, and other performance practitioners--can unlock your own Invisible City, unearthing and embodying the abundance of hidden gems among us, one city at a time.

In The Invisible City Project, place is central.  If place is home, then the place in question is Hartford, and the vehicle for exploring this place is contemporary dance and performance practice.  The goal of The Invisible City Project is to get to know Hartford better, endowing it with value by pausing long enough to notice it.  Beginning this August, The Invisible City Project will invite performing artists and audiences to engage as ethnographers, together tracing Hartford-ness in through the diverse contemporary performance practice of current and former residents of Hartford, Connecticut.  This yearlong investigation will unfold through a series of performance events, works in progress showings, online engagement, community gatherings and conversations. 

Hartford is small. It is home to 125,000 people, but as Connecticut's capital city, Hartford is the area’s nexus point.  On the surface, Hartford has suffered the consequence of white flight and is often stigmatized by media images of urban blight.  At yet, this same Hartford has a compelling history too few claim, and a dynamic cultural life shaped by a significant number of artists operating just beneath the city's surface.  In many ways, it seems parts of the city remains invisible.  The land itself seems to harbor a residue from its past that continues to inform the city's personality and behavior.  The Hog/Park River once flowed through the city center, shaping city life along its path, but was buried in the 1940s to keep devastating floods at bay.  Replaced by a network of roads and highways, the now subterranean river continues to flow beneath the surface, providing an apt metaphor for the city’s seemingly latent vibrancy. 

So what might we learn about ourselves by uncovering the impact of Hartford's history, diverse populations, economic disparity, proximity to established cultural centers, and tension between risk aversion and innovation in relationship to the city's cultural expression?  The Invisible City Project sets out to shed light on this Hartford that is often invisible to the naked eye, but inevitably seep into and through the work of its artists. 

 

Who We Are

Founded by Hartford-native Deborah Goffe in 2002, Scapegoat Garden is a Hartford-based collaborative dance theater, driven to create daring, interdisciplinary performance that goes in through the nose, eyes, skin, ears and mouth to stir those who witness or participate. Scapegoat Garden seeks to exemplify Hartford's innovative, high quality professional dance theater and to contribute to the ongoing evolution of contemporary dance as a viable American art form. Further,the company strives to forge relationships with artists and communities, helping people see, create and contribute to a greater vision of ourselves, each other and our city.

The Garden Center for Contemporary Dance was founded in 2011 as a home to Scapegoat Garden, and a shared laboratory for creative process, performance and community engagement. Fueled by the idea that a garden is a place where humans define, initiate, and interact with form to create a specialized environment, our goal is to incubate deep engagement in the art of dancemaking. To this end, The Garden Center strives to serve as a nurturiing environment for social gatherings, discussions about arts and culture, classes, works-in-progress showings, and intimate performance salons. We are eager to share the bounty of the space while providing opportunities for members of our community to shape their own meaningful expression.

 

What We Need, How You Can Help & What You Get in Return

Scapegoat Garden is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization, making USD contributions tax deductible to the fullest extent of the law.  And in return for your generous contribution, you will receive a place of honor on our website's donor wall.  Depending on how much you give, you can also receive a seat of honor at one of The Invisible City Project performance event.  The more you give, the bigger the role you can play.  Bring a friend, bring a piece of the work home with you, sponsor a month of Invisible City programing in your name at The Garden Center.  At any level of support, you are an integral part of this exploration.

During this 60 day Indiegogo campaign, our goal is to raise $3600 in support of the Invisible City Project.  Of course our yearlong process will require quite a bit more than $3600.  The blog site must designed and launched, our hardworking participating artists must be compensated for that work, the entire process must be properly documented, and a space for all this activity must continue to be maintained. But as we seek funding from a variety of sources, we hope to root this process to the heart of the project ... you the individuals who define, interact with and intiate the kinds of places/experiences we are exploring.

With your dollars and your word, you can cast a vote for the expressive power of the moving body, the collective power of the collaborative process, and the value of a nurtured sense of place.  Your word-of-mouth power is an essential component in the success of this campaign, The Invisible City Project, and the health of the cultural eco-system wherever you live.  So, please PASS THE WORD ... tell it, email it, share it, post it, tweet it ... dance it!

story:
Good People Theater Company is Born!

We've got our Board of Directors.  

We've got our Producing Artistic Director...the award-winning and talented Janet Miller.

We've got the genius, Juilliard-trained Musical Director Corey Hirsch, plus a creative team of 13 and cast of 15 all booked and on board.   

We've got our first show--A MAN OF NO IMPORTANCE--registered as part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival and already in rehearsals!

And now we need YOU.  :)

Invest with Confidence, Because Others Already Have!

The good news: because people already know, love and believe in Janet Miller, Good People Theater Company has 75% of the $$ it needs to launch and put on this first show.  So we need just a little bit more -- just 25% of the total budget -- to come out of our first production in the black.  

And we're serious: ANY amount of support is a big deal to us...so don't be shy!

What Happens when You become Good People?

Your support helps...

...bring a beautiful, heartfelt musical to LA for it's first fully staged performance

...give a wonderful team of theater pro's a chance to do great work with good people

...give Janet Miller the forum she so richly deserves for her prodigious talents

And you get all the fun "thank you" gifts noted over there >>>>>

And Don't Forget to Come See the Show! (Buy Tickets)

A MAN OF NO IMPORTANCE opens Friday, June 7 and runs on the weekends through June 30 as part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival.  For tickets, check out our website or our Fringe page.

story:
Summary of Project:

Hello, Everyone!  My name is Catherine Tiso, and I am an independent modern dance choreographer based in Chicago, IL.  I moved to Chicago from Tampa, FL in 2011 to pursue my love of dance and choreography.  After about a year in Chicago, I finally decided it was time to tackle one of my big goals of producing a full-length dance concert as a platform to showcase my own work. 

So here I am, announcing that Diverge/Connect will premier in Chicago, August 16-18, 2013, at Constellation, the new home for iconic Links Hall!  In the concert, I will be premiering four new works: two ensemble pieces, one duet, and one solo.  Work will also be shown by guest artists Julie Brannen, Bonnie Christine Willis, and Pittsburgh-based company Texture Contemporary Ballet.  In addition to the dancing, audiences will also be treated to live original music from Denver-based singer/songwriter Lindsey Saunders.

What's Needed To Make This Work:

Producing a dance concert is never easy, nor is it ever cheap.  Especially working as an independent artist, funding for projects can tend to be difficult to come by.  I am looking to you for your help in making my first concert a smashing success!  Your donations would go towards funding the following concert components:

  • Links Hall rental fee
  • Rehearsal space
  • Technical Director fee
  • Photographer fee
  • Costumes
  • Printed materials, such as concert programs, posters/postcards for marketing purposes, etc.
  • Music licensing fees
  • Housing, food, and transportation costs for Texture Contemporary Ballet artists and Lindsey Saunders
  • Dancer pay!!!

With your help I know that I can make my dream of producing this concert a successful reality!  Any donation amount would be a huge help.  (I know that may sound a bit cliché, but it is in fact very true!)

Other Ways To Help:

If you find you are unable to donate this time around, don’t fret!  You can be a huge help by sharing this campaign link with your own contacts who may be interested in this.  You can also come see the show!  And of course, never discount the power of sending out some positive energy :-)

A Little More About Catherine...

Catherine Tiso is a native of Tampa, Florida.  She graduated Suma Cum Laude from the University of South Florida with a BFA in Modern Dance Performance in 2010.  While at USF, she had the privilege of performing in works by Bill T. Jones, Janis Brenner, Jennifer Archibald, Elsa Valbuena, Mariah Maloney, Lynne Wimmer, and Michael Foley.  In 2008 she studied abroad with the USF Dance in Paris Program in Paris and Marseille, France, and in 2009 was part of a USF concert tour that took her to various cities in northern Tunisia.  Among her accomplishments at USF, she received the Bill Hug Scholarship for Excellence in Choreography and the BRAVO Award for Excellence in Performance and Academics.  She was president of the USF Student Dance Production Board for the 2009-2010 season, and was selected by the faculty to present her senior choreography “mon corps n’est pas ton corps” at the American College Dance Festival in Richmond, Virginia.  Following graduation, she attended the Bates Dance Festival in Lewiston, Maine, where she choreographed and presented a new solo work, “Longing in Madness.”

Catherine participated in the National Society of Arts and Letters Choreography Competition in 2011, taking 7th Place at the national competition in Birmingham, AL with her solo “Situational Awareness.”  She has been a faculty member at Theatre Arts and Dance Alliance in Lithia, FL, where she taught classes in modern dance, jazz, and hip hop.  She has taught master classes in modern dance and choreography at Tampa’s Blake High School for the Arts and America’s Ballet School, created an original ballet on Blake High School students, and has choreographed contemporary solos for students participating in the Youth America Grand Prix.  In the fall of 2010, she was the rehearsal director for the restaging of Michael Foley’s work si bel giorno at USF. 

Catherine moved to Chicago in the fall of 2011.  In 2012 she performed her work “To Find Hope Among Ashes” through The Open Space Project in Chicago, and created “Dualities” on Texture Contemporary Ballet in Pittsburgh, PA for their concert Blur.  She is greatly looking forward to premiering her first full-length concert in Chicago in August 2013 titled Diverge/Connect.

Useful Links:

Catherine Tiso:

www.facebook.com/CatherineTiso

www.youtube.com/cjtdance1

 

Texture Contemporary Ballet:

www.textureballet.org

www.facebook.com/TextureContemporaryBallet

www.youtube.com/TextureBallet

 

Lindsey Saunders:

www.lindseysaundersmusic.com

www.facebook.com/lindseysaundersmusic

 

Thank you so much for your interest and support!!

A Little More About Catherine...
Catherine Tiso is a native of Tampa, Florida.  She graduated Suma Cum Laude from the University of South Florida with a BFA in Modern Dance Performance in 2010.  While at USF, she had the privilege of performing in works by Bill T. Jones, Janis Brenner, Jennifer Archibald, Elsa Valbuena, Mariah Maloney, Lynne Wimmer, and Michael Foley.  In 2008 she studied abroad with the USF Dance in Paris Program in Paris and Marseille, France, and in 2009 was part of a USF concert tour that took her to various cities in northern Tunisia.  Among her accomplishments at USF, she received the Bill Hug Scholarship for Excellence in Choreography and the BRAVO Award for Excellence in Performance and Academics.  She was president of the USF Student Dance Production Board for the 2009-2010 season, and was selected by the faculty to present her senior choreography “mon corps n’est pas ton corps” at the American College Dance Festival in Richmond, Virginia.  Following graduation, she attended the Bates Dance Festival in Lewiston, Maine, where she choreographed and presented a new solo work, “Longing in Madness.”
Catherine participated in the National Society of Arts and Letters Choreography Competition in 2011, taking 7th Place at the national competition in Birmingham, AL with her solo “Situational Awareness.”  She has been a faculty member at Theatre Arts and Dance Alliance in Lithia, FL, where she taught classes in modern dance, jazz, and hip hop.  She has taught master classes in modern dance and choreography at Tampa’s Blake High School for the Arts and America’s Ballet School, created an original ballet on Blake High School students, and has choreographed contemporary solos for students participating in the Youth America Grand Prix.  In the fall of 2010, she was the rehearsal director for the restaging of Michael Foley’s work si bel giorno at USF. 
Catherine moved to Chicago in the fall of 2011.  In 2012 she performed her work “To Find Hope Among Ashes” through The Open Space Project in Chicago, and created “Dualities” on Texture Contemporary Ballet in Pittsburgh, PA for their concert Blur.  She is greatly looking forward to premiering her first full-length concert in Chicago in August 2013 titled Diverge/Connect.
Useful Links:
Catherine Tiso:
www.facebook.com/CatherineTiso
www.youtube.com/cjtdance1
 
Texture Contemporary Ballet:
www.textureballet.org
www.facebook.com/TextureContemporaryBallet
www.youtube.com/TextureBallet
 
Lindsey Saunders:
www.lindseysaundersmusic.com
www.facebook.com/lindseysaundersmusic
 
Thank you so much for your interest and support!!

story:
PERCEVAL

An Equity Approved Showcase

The Kraine Theater, 85 E 4th St, New York, NY

SAT 8/10 @ 6; SUN 8/11 @ 4:30; MON 8/12 @ 9:15;

SUN 8/18 @ 9; SUN 8/25 @ NOON

Written by Haas Regen

Directed by Scott Raker

Original Music by Mackenzie Shivers

Stage Managed by Erin Person*

Featuring: Elizabeth King-Hall*, Michael Propster*, Haas Regen*, and Gillian Williams*

*Appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association

THE IMMEDIATE FAMILY, a small but tenacious New York theater company founded by graduates of the Brown/Trinity Graduate Acting Program, is bringing PERCEVAL to The New York International Fringe Festival!

HERE’S THE STORY…

Spanning centuries of sources from medieval poetry to the modern cinema, the Troubadouress resurrects this Arthurian legend of an unassuming boy’s quest for the Holy Grail. With the help of a small troupe of actors, she strives to conjure all the duels and damsels, curses and spells -- and hopefully even the Cup itself.  

But can one woman tell such a glorious tale -- and can one boy achieve such a holy prize?  Maybe neither of them can do it alone...

PLEASE CONSIDER MAKING A CONTRIBUTION

PERCEVAL has had two previous workshop productions in the Bronx as part of the Westchester Square Arts Festival and in Providence at 95 Empire. We are so thrilled to now be a part of this summer’s upcoming New York International Fringe Festival. We have a wonderful team and the original cast from our previous productions.

Until now, we have been able to cover all expenses of the workshop productions.  But now, for Perceval's biggest and best presentation yet, we must come to you for help. We are seeking $5,000 to help compensate for the costs of this first full-scale production.

ALL SUPPORT HELPS

Your donation would mean the world to us! $10 would cover the costs for one of our props. $25 will cover a full hour of rehearsal space. A donation of $50 will pay for our set pieces and $75 will cover the full cost of printing scripts. Even if you can't contribute now, you can still support us by posting this link to your Facebook profile or Twitter feed!

THANK YOU

We want to thank you in advance for your generosity. We look forward to seeing you at the theater in August. Join the Quest!
