story:
Our Story

Hi. We're the ATTIC Theatre and Film Center.  We are a non-profit theatre company that has presented the Denise Ragan Wiesenmeyer One-Act Play Festival for 20 years in Los Angeles.  We are dedicated to producing original plays that are socially and politically relevant, as well as artistically meaningful.  The 2011 Festival features one-act plays that reflect on, react to, and/or consider in some manner the influence of the 9/11 attacks on the previous ten years.  But we need your help.

 

We need to raise $3500 to cover the cost of rehearsing and producing four original one-act plays, or the 20-year tradition of the ATTIC’s festival will be broken and these previously unseen plays may never see the light of day.  So we're turning to our strongest supporters to ask for contributions. In exchange, we're offering tickets to the Festival and an invitation to the Closing Night Awards Ceremony Gala. Your contribution will help us continue to produce plays by emerging and undiscovered writers, and further, it will help commemorate the 10th Anniversary of 9/11. Thank you!

 

The Impact

The Denise Ragan Wiesenmeyer One-Act Play Festival celebrates the legacy of one our founders at the ATTIC Theatre.  Denise passed away in 2007, but her work as a theatre artist and producer lives on in the form of our play festival, which Denise created in 1991.  She believed in sharing the talents of new writers, and we continue that tradition to this day. 

 

The 2011 One-Act Festival will commemorate the 10th Anniversary of 9/11 by producing art that responds to that landmark day in our nation’s history.  Sharing a theatrical experience is one of the strongest ways to reflect on who we are and remember our past.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $3500 to cover the costs associated with rehearsing and mounting full productions of four original one-act plays.  This includes costumes, set and props, as well as marketing costs.  Every little bit helps!  A contribution of $10 pays for copies of the scripts, while $50 is another costume for an actor in a play! 


Your contribution will earn you recognition in our program, tickets to the Festival, or an invitation to our Closing Night Awards Ceremony Gala. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out!  Please tell your friends about our play festival.  Share this page on Facebook and Twitter to help support theatre and commemorate the 10th Anniversary of 9/11.

 

About the ATTIC Theatre & Our Play Festival

The ATTIC Theatre & Film Center is now entering its 25th season of developing new plays and voices for the American theatre.  As part of this commitment to fostering original work, the ATTIC sponsors a national playwriting contest for new one-act plays, The Denise Ragan Wisenmeyer One Act Festival, and offers classes and workshops year round to help develop those new artistic voices and plays.

 

For 20 years, the Attic Theatre’s One-Act Festival has provided playwrights with the unique opportunity to see their work leap from page to stage with the help of some of L.A.'s finest theatre & film professionals.  Out of the hundreds of entries submitted to the Festival, between three and six of the strongest contenders are selected to receive productions in the 2011 One-Act Festival. A panel of judges comprised of theatre professionals choose the two best plays of the event. The first place winner receives $300 and the second place winner receives $150 in prize money.

 

For more information about the Annual Denise Ragan Wiesenmeyer One-Act Play Festival and the ATTIC Theatre, please visit our website at www.attictheatre.org.

story:
Short Summary

We are a student theatre company based in London and our school has never made it up to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival...until now, that is.

    • Our company is made up of young, dedicated actors, technicians and reviewers who want to showcase their talents on an international platform.

    • The play that we have chosen to perform is written by a new, up-and-coming playwright called Polly Stenham. If we can perform at the Fringe then this will be the first time that the play, 'That Face', will have been performed outside of London.

    • Here is a synopsis of the play:

      "When Mia is sent home from boarding school having drugged a younger girl during a hazing ritual, her habitually absent father is recalled from his new life in Hong Kong.

      Her manipulative mother and dependent brother are embroiled in mind games, alcohol and prescription drugs leaving no room for Mia’s problems.Martha’s intense dislike for Mia further alienates her from the family and Henry, the much-loved son struggles to find his own space and identity under the influence of their mother.

      Hugh, their emotionally remote father returns only in an attempt to throw money at the problems his family have descended into during his considerable absence.

      Unwanted Mia is torn between family loyalties, Henry realizes that all his efforts to cure Martha of her problems are in vain and Martha realizes the devastating impact her Oedipal relationship has had on her son."

      'That Face' won the TMA Award 2007 for Best New Play. Polly Stenham received both the Charles Wintour Award 2007 and the Critics' Circle Award 2008 for Most Promising Playwright. Best of all, our performance will be an Edinburgh premiere.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We need help to pay the performance rights which amount to £750. We want to perform from the 5th to the 9th of August.

  • If you can contribute £20 then we will guarantee you a seat at the show and a meet and greet with the cast and crew after the performance.

  • If you can contribute £100 then you could become a friend of The Middle Peg Theatre Company.

  • If you donate £200 you could become a named sponsor of The Middle Peg Theatre Company.

  • If we don't reach our goal of £750 your money will still contribute towards performance rights- if necessary, we will just perform on fewer nights!

The Impact

  • Your contributions will help our aspiring cast and crew achieve their aim of performing on an international stage, give us the possibility of being talent-spotted and guarantee us an experience that will help further our careers.

  • Our teachers (Edinburgh veterans) who are helping us organise our Festival debut will have the pleasure of introducing the next generation into the delights of the Edinburgh Festival- passing on the cultural torch as it were.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Even if you can't contribute financially we would still love to see lots of people at our London performance, Wednesday 4th July at Bancroft's School, Essex.

  • Even better, you could come up to Edinburgh and see us at the Fringe. We are performing 5-9 August at Gryphon Venues: http://gryphonvenues.com/

  • You can book tickets for the Edinburgh Festival shows here: http://www.edfringe.com/whats-on/theatre/that-face

     

  • And finally...if you know of friends, family or colleagues going up to the Edinburgh Fringe this Summer then tell them about our show! http://twitter.com/TheMiddlePeg

story:
ITS TIME FOR TROUBLE

Nick and Jen’s love is being threatened.
Hannah is hiding a secret from her boyfriend James, 
and Sarah, his ex, wants him back.
Meanwhile, Joe is striking up drama with the hottest guy in school. 
tonight there is gonna be 
TROUBLE

About the Show

Trouble is a new rock musical from book writer Michael Alvarez and front woman of Hitchcock Blonde, Ella Grace. It follows the trials, tribulations, soaring spirits, and crushing angst of being 17 in small town America. 

This sexy new show strives to reinvigorate musical theatre culture by shying away from big production numbers in favor of heartfelt ballads and high energy rock show choreography along with hot, trendy clothing and a smart, mature story ripped from today's headlines. The people you see, the stories you know, the clothes you wear, the music you hear. TROUBLE is a night to remember. 

NYMF 2012

TROUBLE THE MUSICAL is thrilled to be an official selection of the 2012 New York Musical Theatre Festival (The "Sundance of Musical Theatre") and will present 6 performances in July at the Alice Griffin Jewel Box Theatre inside the Purshing Square Signature Theatre Centre on 42nd Street. We're providing jobs to over 30 different artists and performers in New York as well as contributing almost $60,000 to the New York City economy. Help us create jobs and support artists!

Who?

PHILLIP RUDY in association with THE NEW YORK MUSICAL THEATRE FESTIVAL presents TROUBLE book by MICHAEL ALVAREZ music and lyrics by ELLA GRACE starring LAURA DREYFUSS* KATIE MACK* DANIEL QUADRINO* MATTHEW J RIODAN DAVI SANTOS JUSTIN STIEN ABBE TANENBAUM* and WESLEY TUNISON set and costume design JOHN DUNNETT lighting design VICTOR ZEISSER sound design JULIAN EVANS  musical direction PETER HODGENSON production stage manager ERNIE FIMBRES* general manager EVE RYBNICK casting JASON NAJJOUM press agent JOHN CAPO orchestrations JOSS NIGHTINGALE choreography JENNIFER WEBER directed by MICHAEL ALVAREZ

*Member, Actors' Equity Association the Professional Association of Actors and Stage Managers in the United States

TROUBLE is presented under an Equity Approved Code. 

WHY?

On a personal note, producing independent theatre in New York is never easy or cheap. With the power of the internet, we're able to finally come to people directly and ask them to take an active part in the creation of something that we've poured out our hearts into over the last five years and more excitingly, we get to share that journey with you! A contribution in ANY amount will add you to our special supporters only mailing list including updates about the show, early access to discount codes, and all the exciting stories as we take Trouble from "Page to Stage". This is a musical for your generation and you can be a part of it. So, won't you please join us for this amazing ride? Contribution rewards start at just $25. It's our way of saying THANK YOU for helping to make our dreams come true and help us keep causing TROUBLE here in New York this summer! Don't forget to like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter! @troublemusical

story: Hey there! My name is Mariah Davis and I am 18 years old. My home town is in Hailey, Idaho, but I am currently a freshman dance major at the wonderful Cornish College of the Arts. I have always pushed myself harder with my dancing whenever I am given the opportunity, and this time, I have been blessed with an amazing opportunity. I have been invited for a summer ballet intensive for seven weeks in New York City. I auditioned in Seattle two weeks ago for the Joffrey Ballet Summer Intensive with a very positive feeling in my heart. I knew that if I was accepted to this intensive, it would be an experience of a life time. I have never been to New York myself, and that is the city that is known all over the world for its dancing. My father, Jeff Davis, opened Joffrey's acceptence email on the evening of February 24th, and burst into tears:its hard to make a 6'5" man cry. My parents have been the most loving and supportive parents a child could ever ask for, and now, I want to be able to tell them "Thank you" by raising money for this intensive. I am worried about the cost of this summer program because my parents are already paying a very large sum of money for my education at Cornish, and my younger sister is on the pathway of going to college soon enough. I want to be able to simply help in any way I possibly can. The amount of money I am trying to raise that will cover my tuition and housing is around $5,800. If the goal is not met, I will still use whatever is raised torwards my tuition and housing. I will be doing my part with trying to find a steady job along with babysitting, house sitting, pet watching, and bake sales. I will appreciate any sum for a donation: every little bit helps! Thank you so much for helping my family out, and helping me pursue my dreams of becomming an amazing dancer! Please feel free to spread the word as well! Thank you and much love.

story:
Note:  Evolving Doors Dance is fiscally sponsored by Fractured Atlas, a non-profit organization that sponsors arts groups an artists across the country!  This means your contribution to our project is tax deductible.  (Non-deductible portions of the donations are listed along with each perk at the right!)

 

 

Who We Are....

I'm Angie Simmons, Artistic Director of Evolving Doors Dance.  EDD is a professional, contemporary modern dance company that cultivates, collaborates, builds community, educates, and performs while nurturing the art of dance and movement and its place in our world.  The company was founded in 2006 in Boulder, Colorado.  Our dances often strive to spark audience engagement in ways that create questions, uncover fears, investigate relationships, question behaviors and promote self-examination.  Ultimately, Evolving Doors Dance builds connections through dance; uses dance as an expressive medium of artistic, political and social ideas and views; and evokes thought and questions about life, art, love, social behavior, acceptance, interaction, activism, and humanity.  We are an ever-evolving company in an ever-evolving society!

 

About This Project.... 

This project, SKIN, explores the concepts and reasons for human touch.  Why do we touch?  How do we use touch to communicate and what ARE we saying when we do?  Why do we long for touch and human contact?  How can touch be so universal and, at the same time, so uniquely intimate?  What happens to the human body at the moment of touch?  What happens when we are the observer of the interaction of touching?  Our SKIN is the largest organ we have.  Doesn’t it deserve a little attention?  This show promises to be filled with movement, image, texture, skin, contact, and touch.  What lies beneath the SKIN may be a whole other matter.

 

About Our Campaign.....

We have been a professional company since our founding in 2006.  With this, we maintain a few priorities that are essential to the growth of our company and of art as a whole!  A few of these priorities are to present high quality dance work in local, professional venues AND to pay our dancers and staff for their work and skill.  Through this campaign we are working to cover costs for our rental space, which totals $5000.  This allows us to rent space in Boulder’s performing arts venue, the Dairy Center, and also to cover a second performance weekend at a theatre in Denver.  We are also working, through this campaign, to raise a portion of the funds  to pay dancer stipends and staff.  The other portion will be raised through grants and ticket sales.  We are constantly striving to pay these amazing artists more of a living wage.  With your contributions, we can do both of these things!  This $6500 goal is no small feat but is a tremendous assist to our company.  Presenting our shows in professional venues and branching into Denver will continue to expand our audiences and help us grow!  Additionally, paying our dancers, artists, and staff at a more fair rate compensates them for all the time they commit to the process of making this work.  

 

Break It Down Now....

$3000 -- Our rental costs for tech week and 2 performances in the Dairy Center.  (This includes the space itself, our house staff, and a technical director... all required by the venue.)

$2000 -- Rent a comparable but slightly smaller space in Denver for additional week of tech and 2 performances.  

$1000  -- A start towards stipends for our dancers and staff.  Our dancers will each rehearsal for at least 200 hours over 6 months for this project!  That is a lot of jumping, turning, falling, and sliding!  If you're doing the math, that is 1400 hours, which, if paid only $5/hr is $1000 per dancer!  We generally can't, as an organization, pay our dancers by the hour, but we would love to some day in our future!  This will be a start.  

$500 -- This amount covers the fees we pay to Fractured Atlas for for being our fiscal sponsor in the endeavor.  In turn, we get great support and business-of-arts perks from them!

(In the spirit of full discloser, the total project will end up costing around $20,000. So, as you can see, this is just a piece of the pie!)

 

The Perks....

Yup.... there are totally great perks, including dinner and VIP passes to a show, complete with an invitation to our cast party!  There are also a whole mess of other fun perks you can choose!  (Wanna be included in the show?  Wanna shirt?  How about a sneak-peak of rehearsal?)  Be sure to check out all the perks and pick the donation level that is great for you!

 

If We Fall Short...

If we don't reach our whole goal, we will start skimming off the wish list.  We'll end up paying our dancers less per performance, reducing staff pay, and cutting back on things like costuming or equipment rental.  If necessary, we would omit our second weekend of performances in Denver.  But, we're hoping, after 6 months of building the show, that it doesn't come down to that!

 

Our Track Record...

We have an excellent track record with producing fully fleshed-out, professional, evening-length productions just like this one!  We've done so every year since 2006, our first year.  We have tremendously committed dancers and staff, and I'm personally very committed to this project.  It's realization means a great deal to me!  You can rest assured that we mean business!  We also have an excellent history of receiving local grants, which rounds out another portion of the funding on our projects.  And finally, our ticket sales follow up the end as the last portion.

 

You Want to Help but Just Can't Today...

You want to but it's not in the stars right now?  We, as artists, TOTALLY get it!  There ARE other ways you can help us reach this goal.  Make some serious noise about our campaign, our company, our goals, our wish list, etc!  Use the Indiegogo share tools and post about the campaign on your wall and to your friends.  Shoot out an email to people you think can contribute and are arts lovers!  Help us talk it up! We've got 30 days, so there is time to whoop and holla!   And.... if the stars align for you and us, come back to our campaign page and donate before it ends.  

 

However you contribute, we are grateful and so happy you visited our campaign page. The arts are important and essential in this world.  Do or see something art-ful daily!  It will enrich and fill your life.

 

 

 

(Photo for this campaign header by Drew Levin.  Internal video photos by Drew Levin and Heather Gray. Performance lighting by Lacey Erb.)

story:
24/7 Collective and pivotal(arts) present the 25th Anniversary Production of 

The Anger in Ernest and Ernestine 

Written By Robert Morgan, Martha Ross and Leah Cherniak 

Directed By Robert Morgan 

Starring Jennifer De Lucia and Daniel Stolfi 

Set, Lighting and Costume Design By Glenn Davidson 

Sound Composition By George Axon

Play Synopsis

Ernest and Ernestine live in a perfectly ordered world until cracks appear in the veneer. Repressed anger rears its ugly head and the coupleâ€™s efforts to maintain order and affection range from comic to tragic.

 

About the Team

Jennifer De Lucia (Artistic Producer-pivotal(arts) theatre company) and Daniel Stolfi (Executive Producer-Cancer Canâ€™t Dance Like This) are award winning producers who have formed  24/7 Collective to celebrate the 25th anniversary of the Canadian Classic The Anger in Ernest and Ernestine. Both Daniel and Jennifer are embarking on this production with the keen desire to celebrate Canadian playwrights.  Teaming up with Robert Morgan (Director and Original Creator), Glenn Davidson (Original Designer) and George Axon (Original Composer) this celebration will be at its finest.

 

We decided that the venue neednâ€™t be at a grand theatre, but a venue that is site specific to the plays location â€“ a basement apartment. The production will have a healthy three week run at The Unit 102 theatre, in Toronto, this November, and with your support we can make this dream a reality.   

 

The Impact

This adventure is a tremendous undertaking. It is hard to believe the amount of money and work that goes into producing theatre, and how little people often get paid for the hundreds of hours of time spent; creating, developing, rehearsing and promoting a piece of work.   Daniel and Jennifer are two very professional producers who have always made theatre and have been able to finance according to budget.   This campaign will help give them and their entire team the opportunity to share something very special together.   Your support will help cover the production costs of this amazing show and provide the city of Toronto with a much deserved celebration of Canadian art.  


What We Need & What You Get

So hereâ€™s the scoop, if you help, we give back. We want to ensure that all those helping us will be recognized and given gratitude accordingly. Your investment will not go to waste as this production is providing the city of Toronto with a celebration of art, presented by two emerging artists that have proven themselves in the past. The budget for this show is quite high right now, but every dollar you give helps us cover the costs of:  workshops, rental for our rehearsal hall and theatre space, costumes, props, set pieces, and income for the artists. There are, of course, some fabulous perks which accompany this campaign and we hope you will take the time to check out what is offered at each level.  Even if you can only contribute $10 â€“ trust us, it goes far!


Other Ways You Can Help

Another fabulous way to help us out is by sharing this link with others. Many people love the arts and we would really truly appreciate if you could spread the love!

story:
What's this all about?

We are a group of undergraduate students working hard to put on Blithe Spirit by Noël Coward at the University of Southern California. 

 This is a non-profit production entirely funded by donations; we cannot do it without your help!

We are made up of high-achieving students in USC's School of Dramatic Arts, School of Cinematic Arts, and Dornsife College of Arts & Sciences as well as UCLA's Department of Design Media Arts. 

Though we are a brand-new artistic collective, Productions Under Vesuvius hopes to continue to oversee artistic endeavors across various mediums. Supporting us in this first stage of existence will allow us to establish ourselves as a capable and determined company. 

Blithe Spirit is our first full-length theatrical production. This project has been in development since December 2013 and rehearsing since January 2014. After several months of balancing theatre with schoolwork, jobs, and extracurriculars, the month of our debut has finally arrived. Our team of actors, directors, and producers have consistently dedicated upwards of twenty-five hours a week and our hard work has nearly come to fruition.

We are so excited to share our efforts with you and appreciate any support you may be able to provide. 

What We Need & What You Get

To be specific:

  • We operate on a donation-based system for ticket sales. If all audience members donate the suggested $5, still only about 50% of total costs of production will be covered.
  • Your donations will help us cover all production costs including theatre rental (~$1,000), licensing fees (~$500), scenic design, and costumes. 
  • Every dollar counts. We are a brand new production company intending to produce a professional-quality show. Every dollar you can give will make an impact.

The Impact

  • Theatre is in decline as a medium; your donations help us keep this ancient art alive!
  • Supporting this production will allow our team to continue to do projects like this one. We're already looking towards next year and hope to be able to expand our efforts to mixed media, game design, and film in addition to theatre. Our ability to foster the aspirations of talented young people depends on financial backers like you.
  • Successful funding will encourage other students like us to continue to take artistic risks and produce exciting works on college campuses.  

Productions Under Vesuvius proudly presents:

Blithe Spirit by Noël Coward 

Directed by Kate Lavelle 

Show dates & times:

March 27th at 7pm

March 28th at 7pm & 11pm

March 29th at 2pm & 7pm 

Reserve your tickets now!

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/blithe-spirit-tickets-10812401183?aff=eorg

Blithe Spirit is a fast-paced comedy featuring novelist Charles Condomine and his inexplicable connection to the beyond. When the neighborhood medium, Madame Arcati, summons his deceased first wife, Elvira, Charles and his second wife, Ruth, must find a way to return her mischievous spirit to the other side—before Elvira’s antics escalate to dangerous heights.  The couple faces a rather inconvenient obstacle, however; Ruth can neither see nor hear the ghost of Elvira. 

The Cast (in order of appearance):

Edith - Christine Barron 

Ruth - Shannon Sheridan 

Charles - Matthew Solomon 

Dr. Bradman - Jason Smith 

Mrs. Bradman - Anisha Jagannathan 

Madame Arcati - Sammy Olson 

Elvira - Jessica Garcia 


The Crew:

Assistant Director - Nikita Lamba 

Assistant Director - Katie McKay

Stage Manager - Gabby Nowack 

ASM - Andrea Moore

Production Design - Lauren Mahon 


For any questions, or if you're interested in getting involved behind the scenes, email us at: blithespiritusc@gmail.com 


Produced by special arrangement with Samuel French, Inc.

story:
The Project

Whim Productions is launching its first independent production! Flowers in the Wardrobe, written by Kevin King, is a play that combines the worlds of Flowers in the Attic and The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe with dark and campy results. Whim Productions is collaborating with the Steven Eubank of Egads! Theatre Company (Carrie: The Musical, Rocky Horror Picture Show, Hedwig and the Angry Inch), who will direct Flowers in May 2014.

Flowers in the Wardrobe tells the twisted tale of four children who try to save their family while exploring the wintry landscape of Narnia. After the death of their father, and faced with crushing debt, their mother moves the family into her estranged parents’ mysterious mansion. The children are shunned by their grandmother and imprisoned in the mansion’s attic. While waiting for their grandfather to die so their mother can inherit his wealth, the children seek comfort in cookie binges, dirty dancing, and loving each other in all the wrong ways. A magical wardrobe offers the children a chance for adventure and escape, thrusting them into a sinister land populated by talking beavers, fauns, and witches.

The talented cast and crew for the show includes:

Actors:

Stefanie Stevens

Bobby Turnbaugh

Alisa Lynn

J. Will Fritz

Amy Kelly

Genewa Stanwyck

Andy Perkins

Pete Bakely

Diane Bulan

Philip blue owl Hooser


Production Team:

Director: Steven Eubank

Playwright & Producer: Kevin King

Stage Management: Ashley Pike

Prop Design: Regina Weller

Costume Design: Tabatha Terry-Treml

Set Design: Laura Burkhart

Light Design: Alex Perry

Sound Design: Joseph Concha


After a successful test run in December as a staged reading, this show is set to win audiences over with its irreverent camp and shocking twists, while showcasing the wild comedic talent of Kansas City actors.

Now, Whim Productions is asking for your help to launch Flowers in the Wardrobe.

About the Company

Whim Productions is a growing theater company based in Kansas City, MO. Its past productions were Film Classics Presents: Heaven So Far and Film Classics Presents: Suspicion, both of which were produced as part of the Kansas City Fringe Festival (in 2011 and 2012). Heaven So Far was the 7th best attended show in the 2011 Fringe Festival.

In addition to Flowers in the Wardrobe, Whim Productions is excited to have an upcoming play in the 2014 Kansas City Fringe Festival and long-term plans for a production in late 2014 or early 2015.

The Need

$6,000

This represents only a portion of the budget for Flowers, but because Whim Productions is dedicated to compensating actors and designers fairly for their talents, your help is needed to make this project a reality.

You’ll see a snapshot below of items from the budget for Flowers. With your help in getting this play off the ground, any eventual proceeds from Flowers will be applied toward future productions employing Kansas City artists.

Rehearsal and Performance Space (at The Arts Asylum):  $4,000

Sets (Designer and Build):   $1,800

Costumes (Designer and Development):  $1,400

Cast and Crew:   $8,100

The funding goal of this campaign is only a portion of the total budget, but we recognize that by undertaking this venture, Whim Productions has a responsibility to invest its own funds in the dreams of its artists.

The Impact of Your Donation

By supporting a new production company, you are growing more and more opportunities for talented theatre artists in Kansas City to provide entertainment for new audiences. Your donation will help make Flowers in the Wardrobe a fully realized production, and will prevent a drastic streamlining of the show design. Without your support, Whim Productions may have to cancel future projects.

Spread the Word

Please share a link to this campaign via your favorite social media feeds! Tell your friends about the campaign, and bring them with you to the show in May 2014.

Thank you for your generosity!

Rehearsal and Performance Space (at The Arts Asylum):  $4,000
Sets (Designer and Build):   $1,800
Costumes (Designer and Development):  $1,400
Cast and Crew:   $8,100
The funding goal of this campaign is only a portion of the total
budget, but we recognize that by undertaking this venture, Whim Productions has
a responsibility to invest its own funds in the dreams of its artists.
The Impact of Your
Donation
By supporting a new production company, you are growing more
and more opportunities for talented theatre artists in Kansas City to provide
entertainment for new audiences. Your donation will help make Flowers
in the Wardrobe a fully realized production, and will prevent a drastic
streamlining of the show design. Without your support, Whim Productions may
have to cancel future projects.
Spread the Word
Please share a link to this campaign via your favorite social
media feeds! Tell your friends about the campaign, and bring them with you to
the show in May 2014. 
Thank
you for your generosity!

story:
Vai al testo in italiano  ➞


Intro

One night during fall 2013, few days after Lou Reed's death, me - Franco Mosconi - and some friends were listening to the valuable demos included in the Velvet Underground's box set of cd's, bought about twenty years ago. The tracks are full lenght, and in the background you can hear the dialogues between the musicians during the reharsals. Our emotions travel fast, while listening  to that voices and sounds, we're taken back in the early sixities, in the famous New York loft and studio of Andy Warhol, the place where the Velvet's were reharsing, The Factory.

Inside this intense artistic and cultural context, the production of a piece of art was a result of collective project, the contribution of different people and ideas. This is the scene where the Exploding Plastic Inevitable (E.P.I.) was born, the multimedial Andy Warhol's show, with the live music of the Velvet Underground, starring along with Nico, Gerard Malanga and Edie Sedgwick. It was part show, part a live concert, an happening in which the art was performed each night in different ways. The E.P.I. was and underground and avant-garde production, and for this reason, few people have been so lucky to attend. It was staged only in the States, between 1966 and 1967 in a limited number of replicas, and does not exist significative video footage and photographic documentation.

So, my question was: how can we make again this amazing show and less known piece of art  from one of the master's of the american Pop Art available to enjoy for the contemporary and future audience, before it will be lost forever in the memory? 

The only way is throught the witness of the only living participant, Gerard Malanga.


I'll go straight to the point, just to say that incredibly in three months time, I found myself in Hudson, in the State of New York, knocking on no less than Mr. Malanga's home door!

I've got the appointment after many exchanged mails between us, and thanks to the artist's availabilty, therefore after a long and interesting talk we decide together to produce an E.P.I. inspired show called: Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs.

Poet, photographer, actor and filmaker, Gerard Malanga is best known for being the assistant and for a certain period the manager of Andy Warhol. He worked closely with the artist during his most creative period, from 1963 to 1970. Malanga was involved in all the phases of the Warhol's creative output,  silkscreen, painting and filmaking, he also founded with his famous friend "Interview" magazine. In 1992, "The New York Times" refers to him as «The Andy Warhol's most important associate». 

Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs is born from the Gerard's "in person" experience in the Factory and in the E.P.I.,  it tells about the parties, tensions of the everyday life, the characters, the celebrities, diving deeply in the atmospheres of the underground  counterculture remembered as the "Siver Sixties" that has defined the concept of the american Pop Art.

Why not seeking a producer? In order to respect the original spirit of the Factory, be indipendent! The essential condition for the total freedom or artistic expression.

This is an unmissable opportunity. The exceptional witness and collaboration of Gerard Malanga is priceless, and must be used in the best, possible way. 


The Impact

The show is divided into two acts. The first act is an inside "behind the curtain" look that reveals throught real happened facts, the conditions that led to the production of the E.P.I., a glimpse into a reality that became legendary, the recent past of a bunch of artists and intellectuals that have deeply influenced and fascinated generations of people, and that keep even doing so nowadays.

In the second act, the show becomes a live concert, with a band playing on stage the Velvet Undergound's music taken from their first famous album, among them, Sunday Morning, All Tomorrow's parties, Heroin, Venus in Furs ("Rolling Stone" magazine ranked this album n. 13 of the best ever records in the Rock history), all around, multiscreen projections of experimental films, frames, a bombardment of lights and sounds, incursions in the audience, frantic dance performances.

The raised funds are needed to produce the show and take it to the debut, so that it can be distributed in Italy and abroad giving the possibility to everyone to be seen, enjoyed and remembered.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to make the best of this project the costs are important, for different reasons, an high level quality product needs artistic and technological investments commisurated to, like:

  • Audio and video technologies: Theaters usually provide for a small part of the equipment , everything else that we need must be rented, then, for a complex kind of show like this, and in order to give back the audience the original feeling to enjoy for a contemporary audience, we need the ultimate state of the art technology, as Warhol and the factory's artists did in 1967.
  • Scenography: Scenographies must be built by professionals, they must be safe, easy transportable as well as strong and made to last, other than easily adaptable to different situation of size and shape you can find in different theatres and locations. We also need furnitures and props to complete the set, to be found in second hand markets, and restored.
  • Salary for the artists: Actors, musicians, scenographist, costumist, light designer, stage assisitants, the director, all the people that work for the production, inside and outside the set, must be paid weekly, a salary commisurated to the hours of work, the experience and skills.
  • Reharsals: We've planned 20 days of reharsals.The locations, the equipments, even if in a reduced form, must be rented and paid for, the actors and all the other people involved must reharse the script (before studying at home!) and have to be paid and reimboursed for food and travel.
  • Costumes: We have planned 24 changes of costumes, we'll do our best to find them in flea markets, but of course they have to be paid, and often repaired and adapted by size.
  • Promotion: Posters (and the people that sticks them), flyers (and the guys that distributes them), the press agency, who works on the social networks, the website and the Indiegogo pages  to constantly update them for your pleasure.
  • Rights to use of original footage and images: The intellectual property is essential, in Italy we say "diamo a Cesare cio che è di Cesare" which more or less means, who made it deserve to be respected (and we add, paid for. Seems that no less than Jesus said that).
  • Insurances and safety in working environments: Safety first.The workplace must be safe, any worker on the set must be kept away from any risk of accident.


    • Your contribute is essential, even the smallest. If we cant' reach the goal, this show will never see the lights, and this opportunity will be lost forever. You know what you can.

    Risks & Challenges

    The show uses different languages from the theatre, music, cinema and art, with all the problems that involves their same time management. A challenge that we decide to take creating a group of work composed by professionals coming from different artistic fields, so that the the skills of one can be integrated with the ones of others.

    Furthermore, Gerard Malanga knows well all the issues, and problems related to the staging of this show, as he did it in person long before us, thanks to his direct involvement in the E.P.I.!

    Why a Flexible Funding Campaign?

    We’re confident and passionate about this project. If we cant’ reach the goal with a  Fixed campaign (all or nothing), we can’t even begin the production. With a Flexible campaign (take it all), a partial funding would enable us to start with the first steps of the production.

    A further Fixed campaign to complete the production of Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs could then be  launched, supported by the work we’ve already done,  that we’ll show you in details.

    If we simply did well the first part of our job, we hope to be rewarded by other contributions!

    The Perks

    After you'll have placed your donation, we will contact you by email for your size and chosen design.
    Please, don't forget to add the "Costi spedizione per l'Italia" perk for shipping in Italy ($11), or the "Shipping costs outside Italy" perk ($24). 


    Pop Art is (nearly) for Everyone
    If you can't  wait until it will be staged in your local theatre, the Premiere of Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs will be filmed and we’ll send to all contributors a private link to watch the video of the whole show.

    Other Means to Support Us... in the Spirit of the Factory!

    The Factory, as an artistic independent "experimental lab" could count on multiple talents that were involved, contributing in different ways to many projects, in the same way you all, could give an hand to achieve the production of this amazing show, even simply spreading the word. Please share on your favorite socials our website, this Indiegogo page, our Facebook and Twitter profile, where you can find pictures, curiosity about the extraordinary people at the Factory.

    Thanks for your support    , you know what you can, each contribute is essential, even the smallest one! With your help we can switch on the lights!

    P.S.

    We did our best, even thought, English is not our mother tongue, so forgive us for any mistake, hoping we succeded to show how excited we are about this project!


    The Team

    Gerard Malanga (Art director)
    Poet, photographer, actor and filmmaker, Gerard Malanga is best known for being the assistant of Andy Warhol. He worked with the artist from 1963 to 1970. In 1992 "The New York Times" refers to him as «The Andy Warhol's most important associate».

    Franco Mosconi (Author)
    He’s been working for over 20 years in the Milan’s music, art, design and clubbing scene as a producer, project manager and venue owner. In the past seven years, has brought to Italy the best international talents from all around world from the cabaret and circus scene, such as illusionists, funambolists, magicians, top burlesque performers, live band and dj’s.

    Attilio Reinhardt (Co-author)
    Actor, compere, writer and researcher. He’s an expert of vintage cabaret and entertainment from the 20’s. His wide interests spans from the underground music to cinema and arts. He holds a degree in Art, Music and Entertainment.

    Roberta Monopoli (Scenographer and costumist)
    She's a scenographer and costumist graduated with honors at the Accademia delle Belle Arti di Brera, in Milan. She had many experiences with famous directors such as: Giorgio Barberio Corsetti, Marco Baliani, Elio DeCapitani and prestigious theatres: Israeli Opera - Tel Aviv, Teatro Petruzzelli - Bari, Teatro alla Scala - Milan, Mariinsky Theatre - Russia, Operà Royale - Liège, Teatro Real - Madrid, just to name a few.

    Fabio Iaquone and Luca Attilii (Video and light designers)
    In 2004, they decided to team together and open a studio based in Rome. The collaboration between the two artists soon became extremely successful. The list of all the works in these past 10 years, is nearly endless, and can count on prestigious institutions, universities and theatres. Just to name a few: 

    • Elements - with music by John Cage - Rome - Italy
    • 3 for Andy Warhol - Den Haag - Holland
    • Macbeth by Giuseppe Verdi - Teatro alla Scala - Milan - Italy
    • Candide by Leonard Bernstein - Teatro dell’Opera - Rome - Italy
    • CYP17 - Houston Dance Centre - U.S.A.
    • Telephone and Birds - with Achille Bonito Oliva - Auditorium parco della musica - Rome - Italy

    Manuele Scalia (Band frontman)
    He's a musician and dj with a long career. Actually he’s the guitarist and frontman of the “The Three Blind Mice“ an indie rock band based between Milan and Berlin. Manuele is responsible for the live music part of the project with his new band created specifically for this show.



    ITALIANO

    Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs

    Rivivi gli avvenimenti che negli anni '60 hanno sconvolto il mondo dell'arte!
    Sostieni la realizzazione dello spettacolo ispirato agli artisti della Factory di Andy Warhol! 


    Introduzione

    Una sera dell’autunno 2013, a pochi giorni dalla scomparsa di Lou Reed, io - Franco Mosconi - e alcuni amici riascoltiamo le preziose demo contenute nei cd del box set dei Velvet Underground acquistato quasi vent’anni fa. Le tracce sono integrali e riportano anche i dialoghi tra i musicisti durante le prove. Quelle voci e quei suoni ci trasportano emozionalmente indietro, nei primi anni '60, nel celebre studio / loft newyorchese di Andy Warhol dove i Velvet provavano: The Factory.

    All'interno di un contesto di intenso fermento artistico e culturale, in cui l’opera d’arte era anche frutto di un progetto collettivo, nasceva The Exploding Plastic Inevitable (E.P.I.), lo spettacolo multimediale di Warhol con le musiche dei Velvet Underground di Lou Reed, protagonisti insieme a Nico, Gerard Malanga ed Edie Sedgwick. Era uno show, un live e un happening in cui l’arte nasceva sul palco ogni sera in modo diverso. Proprio perché si trattava di una produzione unica e  avant-garde, poche persone hanno avuto l’opportunità di assistervi. Andò difatti in scena solo negli Stati Uniti tra il 1966 ed il 1967, in pochissime repliche. Inoltre non esistono documentazioni fotografiche e video significative. 

    Come fare riscoprire al pubblico contemporaneo, prima che se ne perda definitivamente la memoria, questa parte poco conosciuta della produzione artistica di uno dei più importanti rappresentanti della Pop Art?

    L’unico modo possibile è attraverso la testimonianza del solo protagonista ancora vivente, ovvero, Gerard Malanga. 

    Vi tralascio tutti i dettagli, limitandomi a dirvi che, incredibilmente, nel giro di tre mesi mi ritrovo a Hudson, nello stato di New York, a bussare alla porta di casa di Mr. Malanga!

    L’incontro, frutto di una fitta corrispondenza e della disponibilità dell’artista, porta alla decisione comune di realizzare uno spettacolo ispirato all’E.P.I. che scegliamo insieme di chiamare Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs.

    Poeta, fotografo, attore e filmmaker, Gerard Malanga è conosciuto al pubblico soprattutto per essere stato assistente e manager di Andy Warhol nel suo periodo di maggiore creatività, dal 1963 al 1970. Malanga è stato coinvolto in tutte le fasi della produzione artistica di Warhol nella Factory: dalle serigrafie - la cui tecnica si deve a lui -, ai dipinti, ai film sperimentali. Insieme a Warhol ha fondato la rivista Interview. Nel 1992, il "New York Times" si riferisce a lui come «The Andy Warhol’s most important associate». 

    Dall’esperienza di Malanga nella Factory e nell’E.P.I. nasce quindi Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs: una testimonianza vissuta in prima persona, che narra gli avvenimenti, le feste, le tensioni della vita quotidiana, i personaggi e le celebrità, immergendoci nelle atmosfere della controcultura underground dei “Silver Sixties”, che hanno definito il concetto di Pop Art americana.

    Perché non mettere il progetto nelle mani di un produttore? Per rispettare lo spirito originario della Factory e dei suoi artisti, lo stesso che ha portato alla creazione dell’E.P.I.: la totale indipendenza produttiva, condizione essenziale per la piena libertà artistica.

    Questa è una grande e irripetibile opportunità: l’eccezionale testimonianza di Gerard Malanga è assolutamente preziosa e va messa a frutto nel migliore dei modi.


    Cosa Vedrete sul Palco

    Lo spettacolo è strutturato in due atti. Il primo atto è un “dietro le quinte” che svela, attraverso episodi e percorsi realmente accaduti, le condizioni che hanno portato alla realizzazione dell’E.P.I., uno spaccato su una realtà divenuta leggendaria, il passato recente di un gruppo di artisti ed intellettuali, che hanno culturalmente influenzato ed affascinato generazioni, e che continuano a farlo ai giorni nostri.

    Nel secondo atto, lo spettacolo si trasforma in un concerto live, con una band che interpreta sul palco le musiche dei Velvet Underground estratte dal loro primo celebre album, tra le quali Sunday Morning, All Tomorrow Parties, Heroin, Venus in Furs, (classificato da "Rolling Stone" al n. 13 dei migliori album di sempre nella storia del rock). Intorno, un collage di proiezioni di film sperimentali, diapositive, bombardamenti di luci, suoni, incursioni tra il pubblico e frenetiche performance di danza accompagnate da citazioni, racconti e aneddoti videonarrati dallo stesso Malanga.

    I fondi servono per produrre lo spettacolo e portarlo al debutto affinché abbia l’opportunità di essere distribuito in Italia e all’estero e poter essere visto da tutti.

    Di Cosa Abbiamo Bisogno e Perché 

    Per realizzare al meglio Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs i costi da sostenere sono consistenti, per diversi motivi. Un prodotto di qualità richiede investimenti in termini tecnici e artistici: 

    • Tecnologie audio video: I teatri forniscono solo una piccola parte delle attrezzature che necessitano per la realizzazione dello spettacolo, tutto quello che manca lo dobbiamo noleggiare. Inoltre, per uno spettacolo così complesso e per ricreare lo stesso impatto dello show originale ma per il pubblico contemporaneo, sono necessarie tecnologie all’avanguardia. Proprio come fecero Warhol e i gli artisti della Factory nel ’67.
    • Scenografie: Le scenografie vanno costruite in un laboratorio esterno da professionisti, in quanto devono essere realizzate in modo che siano facilmente smontabili e trasportabili, e allo stesso tempo solide e che possano durare a lungo, oltre che adattabili  alle diverse situazioni di spazio e dimensioni che si incontrano nei vari teatri e location, bisogna poi arredare il set con gli oggetti di scena, da recuperare nei mercatini, restaurare e portarli a nuova vita.
    • Pagare gli artisti: Attori, musicisti,tecnici, macchinisti, regista, scenografo, costumista, light designer, tutte le figure che lavorano alla produzione, sul set e fuori dal set devono percepire un compenso settimanale adeguato all'impegno, alle capacità e all'esperienza.
    • Prove: Abbiamo pianificato 20 giorni di prove, gli spazi vanno affittati, le attrezzature tecniche, anche se in forma ridotta, vanno noleggiate, gli attori e le altre figure che lavorano allo spettacolo  devono necessariamente provare il copione, e devono essere pagate e rimborsate per diaria e spostamenti.
    • Costumi: I cambi di costume sono 24, ci daremo da fare a scovarli nei mercatini delle pulci, ma vanno comunque pagati, a volte aggiustati e spesso messi a misura.
    • Promozione: Locandine, manifesti (e chi li attacca), flyers (e chi li distribuisce), l'ufficio stampa, chi segue e aggiorna i social il sito e la pagina Indiegogo.
    • Diritti per l’utilizzo di filmati e immagini d’epoca: I diritti d' autore e la proprietà intellettuale sono imprescindibili, diamo a Cesare ciò che è di Cesare!
    • Polizze assicurative & sicurezza degli ambienti di lavoro: La sicurezza prima di tutto. L'ambiente di lavoro deve essere in sicurezza, chi lavora sul set deve essere messo al riparo dal rischio di infortuni.


    Il vostro contributo è fondamentale, anche il più piccolo. Se non riusciamo a raggiungere l’obiettivo, lo spettacolo non potrà mai essere prodotto e questa opportunità sarà perduta definitivamente.

    Rischi e Sfide

    Lo spettacolo usa linguaggi differenti, quelli del teatro, della musica, del cinema e dell’arte, con tutte le problematiche che comporta la loro gestione contemporanea. Una sfida che abbiamo scelto di affrontare creando un gruppo di lavoro formato da professionisti provenienti da diverse esperienze nei vari campi artistici, affinché le competenze di ognuno siano integrate con quelle degli altri.


    Inoltre, Gerard Malanga ha affrontato tutte le problematiche relative alla messa in scena di questo tipo di spettacolo ben prima di noi, grazie al suo coinvolgimento diretto nell’E.P.I.

    Perché una Campagna di Raccolta "Flexible"?

    Siamo ottimisti e molto motivati nei confronti di questo progetto. Se non riuscissimo a raggiungere l'obiettivo prestabilito con una campagna "Fixed" (tutto o niente) , non potremmo neppure incominciare la produzione. Con una campagna di tipo "Flexible" (si ottengono tutti fondi raccolti) anche un finanziamento parziale ci permetterebbe di partire con le prime fasi della produzione.

    Una successiva campagna "Fixed" al fine di completare la produzione di "Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs" potrebbe poi essere lanciata, con il supporto del lavoro già fatto, e che vi faremo vedere nei dettagli. Semplicemente, se abbiamo eseguito bene la nostra prima parte del lavoro, ci auguriamo di essere ricompensati con ulteriori contributi!

    I "Perk"

    Dopo che avremo ricevuto la vostra donazione, vi contatteremo via email per la misura e il soggetto desiderato.
    Ti preghiamo di aggiungere anche il perk "Costi spedizione per l'Italia" ($11), o il "Shipping costs outside Italy" perk ($24).

    La Pop Art è (quasi) per Tutti

    Se proprio non riuscite ad aspettare che arrivi nel teatro della vostra città, il debutto di Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs verrà ripreso, e tutti i contributori riceveranno un link privato dove potranno guardare il video dell’intero spettacolo.

    Altri Modi per Supportarci... Nello Spirito della Factory!

    La Factory, in quanto laboratorio di sperimentazione artistica indipendente, poteva contare su molteplici talenti che contribuivano in diversi modi alla creazione dei tanti progetti. Nello stesso modo, tutti potete dare una mano a realizzare questo spettacolo, anche semplicemente spargendo la voce. Condividete sui vostri social preferiti il nostro sito, questa pagina Indiegogo, la nostra pagina Facebook e il profilo Twitter, dove troverete immagini e curiosità sullo spettacolo e sugli straordinari personaggi della Factory. 

    Grazie per il vostro supporto, sapete voi quanto potete offrire, ogni contributo è fondamentale, anche il più piccolo.

    Il Team Creativo

    Gerard Malanga (Direttore artistico)
    Poeta, fotografo, attore e filmmaker, Gerard Malanga è conosciuto al pubblico soprattutto per essere stato assistente e manager di Andy Warhol. Ha lavorato con Andy dal 1963 al 1970. Un articolo del "New York Times" del 1992 si riferisce a lui come «The Andy Warhol's most important associate».

    Franco Mosconi (Autore)
    Lavora da oltre vent’anni a Milano nella scena artistica, musicale, del design a del clubbing, come produttore, project manager e proprietario di locali. Negli ultimi sette anni, ha portato in Italia i migliori artisti stranieri appartenenti alla scena del circo e cabaret, quali illusionisti, funamboli, maghi, burlesque performers, live bands e dj’s.

    Attilio Reinhardt (Co-autore)
    Attilio è un presentatore, scrittore e ricercatore. Esperto di vintage cabaret e intrattenimento dagli anni '20 in poi. I suoi interessi spaziano dal cinema underground alla musica e all’arte. È laureato in Discipline dell’Arte, della Musica e dello Spettacolo.

    Roberta Monopoli (Scenografa e costumista)
    Roberta è una scenografa e costumista, laureata con 110 e lode all’Accademia di Belle Arti di Brera. Nonostante la giovane età, può vantare importanti collaborazioni con famosi registi quali: Giorgio Barberio Corsetti, Marco Baliani, Elio DeCapitani, e prestigiosi teatri: Israeli Opera - Tel Aviv, Teatro Petruzzelli - Bari, Teatro alla Scala - Milano, Mariinsky Theatre - Russia, Operà Royale - Liège, Teatro Real - Madrid.

    Fabio Iaquone and Luca Attilii (Video and light designers)
    Nel 2004 decidono di unire le forze e aprire insieme uno studio a Roma. La collaborazione tra i due artisti si rivela estremamente proficua. L’elenco dei lavori dello studio in questi ultimi dieci anni è quasi interminabile e conta collaborazioni con prestigiose istituzioni, teatri ed università, solo per citarne alcune:

    • Elements - con le musiche di John Cage - Roma
    • 3 for Andy Warhol - Den Haag - Holland
    • Macbeth di Giuseppe Verdi - Teatro alla Scala - Milano
    • Candide di Leonard Bernstein - Teatro dell’Opera - Roma
    • CYP17 - Houston Dance Centre - U.S.A.
    • Telephone and Birds - con Achille Bonito Oliva - Auditorium parco della musica - Roma

    Manuele Scalia (Band frontman)
    Manuele è un musicista e dj con una lunga carriera alle spalle. Attualmente è il chitarrista e cantante dei “Three Blind Mice“, una rock band indipendente con basi a Milano e Berlino. Manuele è responsabile della parte musicale live del progetto con la sua nuova band creata appositamente per questo spettacolo.



    «Multimedia extravaganzas, I like to call them, have a long and dazzling history. They go back to those Kurt Weill cabarets of the mid-1920s.
    They pick up again with Andy Warhol’s Exploding Plastic Inevitable (1966) and with Le Stelle di Mario Schifano (1967) for which I played a major part in their inception. They were meant to dazzle and astonish a live audience, and in this they had succeeded. I had so much fun.
    Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs (2015) continues this tradition into the digital 21st Century, and I look forward in connecting with this creative spirit yet once again».
    Gerard Malanga
