Malanga was involved in all the phases of the Warhol's creative output,  silkscreen, painting and filmaking, he also founded with his famous friend "Interview" magazine. In 1992, "The New York Times" refers to him as «The Andy Warhol's most important associate». 
Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs is born from the Gerard's "in person" experience in the Factory and in the E.P.I.,  it tells about the parties, tensions of the everyday life, the characters, the celebrities, diving deeply in the atmospheres of the underground  counterculture remembered as the "Siver Sixties" that has defined the concept of the american Pop Art.
Why not seeking a producer? In order to respect the original spirit of the Factory, be indipendent! The essential condition for the total freedom or artistic expression.
This is an unmissable opportunity. The exceptional witness and collaboration of Gerard Malanga is priceless, and must be used in the best, possible way. 





The ImpactThe show is divided into two acts. The first act is an inside "behind the curtain" look that reveals throught real happened facts, the conditions that led to the production of the E.P.I., a glimpse into a reality that became legendary, the recent past of a bunch of artists and intellectuals that have deeply influenced and fascinated generations of people, and that keep even doing so nowadays.
In the second act, the show becomes a live concert, with a band playing on stage the Velvet Undergound's music taken from their first famous album, among them, Sunday Morning, All Tomorrow's parties, Heroin, Venus in Furs ("Rolling Stone" magazine ranked this album n. 13 of the best ever records in the Rock history), all around, multiscreen projections of experimental films, frames, a bombardment of lights and sounds, incursions in the audience, frantic dance performances.
The raised funds are needed to produce the show and take it to the debut, so that it can be distributed in Italy and abroad giving the possibility to everyone to be seen, enjoyed and remembered.


What We Need & What You Get
 

In order to make the best of this project the costs are important, for different reasons, an high level quality product needs artistic and technological investments commisurated to, like:

Audio and video technologies: Theaters usually provide for a small part of the equipment , everything else that we need must be rented, then, for a complex kind of show like this, and in order to give back the audience the original feeling to enjoy for a contemporary audience, we need the ultimate state of the art technology, as Warhol and the factory's artists did in 1967.

Scenography: Scenographies must be built by professionals, they must be safe, easy transportable as well as strong and made to last, other than easily adaptable to different situation of size and shape you can find in different theatres and locations. We also need furnitures and props to complete the set, to be found in second hand markets, and restored.

Salary for the artists: Actors, musicians, scenographist, costumist, light designer, stage assisitants, the director, all the people that work for the production, inside and outside the set, must be paid weekly, a salary commisurated to the hours of work, the experience and skills.

Reharsals: We've planned 20 days of reharsals.The locations, the equipments, even if in a reduced form, must be rented and paid for, the actors and all the other people involved must reharse the script (before studying at home!) and have to be paid and reimboursed for food and travel.

Costumes: We have planned 24 changes of costumes, we'll do our best to find them in flea markets, but of course they have to be paid, and often repaired and adapted by size.

Promotion: Posters (and the people that sticks them), flyers (and the guys that distributes them), the press agency, who works on the social networks, the website and the Indiegogo pages  to constantly update them for your pleasure.

Rights to use of original footage and images: The intellectual property is essential, in Italy we say "diamo a Cesare cio che è di Cesare" which more or less means, who made it deserve to be respected (and we add, paid for. Seems that no less than Jesus said that).

Insurances and safety in working environments: Safety first.The workplace must be safe, any worker on the set must be kept away from any risk of accident.




Your contribute is essential, even the smallest. If we cant' reach the goal, this show will never see the lights, and this opportunity will be lost forever. You know what you can.


Risks & Challenges  
The show uses different languages from the theatre, music, cinema and art, with all the problems that involves their same time management. A challenge that we decide to take creating a group of work composed by professionals coming from different artistic fields, so that the the skills of one can be integrated with the ones of others.
Furthermore, Gerard Malanga knows well all the issues, and problems related to the staging of this show, as he did it in person long before us, thanks to his direct involvement in the E.P.I.!
  Why a Flexible Funding Campaign? 
We’re confident and passionate about this project. If we cant’ reach the goal with a  Fixed campaign (all or nothing), we can’t even begin the production. With a Flexible campaign (take it all), a partial funding would enable us to start with the first steps of the production.A further Fixed campaign to complete the production of Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs could then be  launched, supported by the work we’ve already done,  that we’ll show you in details.If we simply did well the first part of our job, we hope to be rewarded by other contributions!The Perks


After you'll have placed your donation, we will contact you by email for your size and chosen design.Please, don't forget to add the "Costi spedizione per l'Italia" perk for shipping in Italy ($11), or the "Shipping costs outside Italy" perk ($24). Pop Art is (nearly) for EveryoneIf you can't  wait until it will be staged in your local theatre, the Premiere of Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs will be filmed and we’ll send to all contributors a private link to watch the video of the whole show.
Other Means to Support Us... in the Spirit of the Factory!
The Factory, as an artistic independent "experimental lab" could count on multiple talents that were involved, contributing in different ways to many projects, in the same way you all, could give an hand to achieve the production of this amazing show, even simply spreading the word. Please share on your favorite socials our website, this Indiegogo page, our Facebook and Twitter profile, where you can find pictures, curiosity about the extraordinary people at the Factory.Thanks for your support, you know what you can, each contribute is essential, even the smallest one! With your help we can switch on the lights!

P.S.
We did our best, even thought, English is not our mother tongue, so forgive us for any mistake, hoping we succeded to show how excited we are about this project!


The Team



Gerard Malanga (Art director)Poet, photographer, actor and filmmaker, Gerard Malanga is best known for being the assistant of Andy Warhol. He worked with the artist from 1963 to 1970. In 1992 "The New York Times" refers to him as «The Andy Warhol's most important associate».



Franco Mosconi (Author)He’s been working for over 20 years in the Milan’s music, art, design and clubbing scene as a producer, project manager and venue owner. In the past seven years, has brought to Italy the best international talents from all around world from the cabaret and circus scene, such as illusionists, funambolists, magicians, top burlesque performers, live band and dj’s.

Attilio Reinhardt (Co-author)Actor, compere, writer and researcher. He’s an expert of vintage cabaret and entertainment from the 20’s. His wide interests spans from the underground music to cinema and arts. He holds a degree in Art, Music and Entertainment.

Roberta Monopoli (Scenographer and costumist)She's a scenographer and costumist graduated with honors at the Accademia delle Belle Arti di Brera, in Milan. She had many experiences with famous directors such as: Giorgio Barberio Corsetti, Marco Baliani, Elio DeCapitani and prestigious theatres: Israeli Opera - Tel Aviv, Teatro Petruzzelli - Bari, Teatro alla Scala - Milan, Mariinsky Theatre - Russia, Operà Royale - Liège, Teatro Real - Madrid, just to name a few.

Fabio Iaquone and Luca Attilii (Video and light designers)In 2004, they decided to team together and open a studio based in Rome. The collaboration between the two artists soon became extremely successful. The list of all the works in these past 10 years, is nearly endless, and can count on prestigious institutions, universities and theatres. Just to name a few: 


Elements - with music by John Cage - Rome - Italy

3 for Andy Warhol - Den Haag - Holland

Macbeth by Giuseppe Verdi - Teatro alla Scala - Milan - Italy

Candide by Leonard Bernstein - Teatro dell’Opera - Rome - Italy

CYP17 - Houston Dance Centre - U.S.A.

Telephone and Birds - with Achille Bonito Oliva - Auditorium parco della musica - Rome - Italy


Manuele Scalia (Band frontman)He's a musician and dj with a long career. Actually he’s the guitarist and frontman of the “The Three Blind Mice“ an indie rock band based between Milan and Berlin. Manuele is responsible for the live music part of the project with his new band created specifically for this show.




ITALIANO
Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs

Rivivi gli avvenimenti che negli anni '60 hanno sconvolto il mondo dell'arte!Sostieni la realizzazione dello spettacolo ispirato agli artisti della Factory di Andy Warhol! 




IntroduzioneUna sera dell’autunno 2013, a pochi giorni dalla scomparsa di Lou Reed, io - Franco Mosconi - e alcuni amici riascoltiamo le preziose demo contenute nei cd del box set dei Velvet Underground acquistato quasi vent’anni fa. Le tracce sono integrali e riportano anche i dialoghi tra i musicisti durante le prove. Quelle voci e quei suoni ci trasportano emozionalmente indietro, nei primi anni '60, nel celebre studio / loft newyorchese di Andy Warhol dove i Velvet provavano: The Factory.
All'interno di un contesto di intenso fermento artistico e culturale, in cui l’opera d’arte era anche frutto di un progetto collettivo, nasceva The Exploding Plastic Inevitable (E.P.I.), lo spettacolo multimediale di Warhol con le musiche dei Velvet Underground di Lou Reed, protagonisti insieme a Nico, Gerard Malanga ed Edie Sedgwick. Era uno show, un live e un happening in cui l’arte nasceva sul palco ogni sera in modo diverso. Proprio perché si trattava di una produzione unica e  avant-garde, poche persone hanno avuto l’opportunità di assistervi. Andò difatti in scena solo negli Stati Uniti tra il 1966 ed il 1967, in pochissime repliche. Inoltre non esistono documentazioni fotografiche e video significative. 


Come fare riscoprire al pubblico contemporaneo, prima che se ne perda definitivamente la memoria, questa parte poco conosciuta della produzione artistica di uno dei più importanti rappresentanti della Pop Art?
L’unico modo possibile è attraverso la testimonianza del solo protagonista ancora vivente, ovvero, Gerard Malanga. 

Vi tralascio tutti i dettagli, limitandomi a dirvi che, incredibilmente, nel giro di tre mesi mi ritrovo a Hudson, nello stato di New York, a bussare alla porta di casa di Mr. Malanga!
L’incontro, frutto di una fitta corrispondenza e della disponibilità dell’artista, porta alla decisione comune di realizzare uno spettacolo ispirato all’E.P.I. che scegliamo insieme di chiamare Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs.
Poeta, fotografo, attore e filmmaker, Gerard Malanga è conosciuto al pubblico soprattutto per essere stato assistente e manager di Andy Warhol nel suo periodo di maggiore creatività, dal 1963 al 1970. Malanga è stato coinvolto in tutte le fasi della produzione artistica di Warhol nella Factory: dalle serigrafie - la cui tecnica si deve a lui -, ai dipinti, ai film sperimentali. Insieme a Warhol ha fondato la rivista Interview. Nel 1992, il "New York Times" si riferisce a lui come «The Andy Warhol’s most important associate». 
Dall’esperienza di Malanga nella Factory e nell’E.P.I. nasce quindi Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs: una testimonianza vissuta in prima persona, che narra gli avvenimenti, le feste, le tensioni della vita quotidiana, i personaggi e le celebrità, immergendoci nelle atmosfere della controcultura underground dei “Silver Sixties”, che hanno definito il concetto di Pop Art americana.
Perché non mettere il progetto nelle mani di un produttore? Per rispettare lo spirito originario della Factory e dei suoi artisti, lo stesso che ha portato alla creazione dell’E.P.I.: la totale indipendenza produttiva, condizione essenziale per la piena libertà artistica.
Questa è una grande e irripetibile opportunità: l’eccezionale testimonianza di Gerard Malanga è assolutamente preziosa e va messa a frutto nel migliore dei modi.


Cosa Vedrete sul Palco
Lo spettacolo è strutturato in due atti. Il primo atto è un “dietro le quinte” che svela, attraverso episodi e percorsi realmente accaduti, le condizioni che hanno portato alla realizzazione dell’E.P.I., uno spaccato su una realtà divenuta leggendaria, il passato recente di un gruppo di artisti ed intellettuali, che hanno culturalmente influenzato ed affascinato generazioni, e che continuano a farlo ai giorni nostri.
Nel secondo atto, lo spettacolo si trasforma in un concerto live, con una band che interpreta sul palco le musiche dei Velvet Underground estratte dal loro primo celebre album, tra le quali Sunday Morning, All Tomorrow Parties, Heroin, Venus in Furs, (classificato da "Rolling Stone" al n. 13 dei migliori album di sempre nella storia del rock). Intorno, un collage di proiezioni di film sperimentali, diapositive, bombardamenti di luci, suoni, incursioni tra il pubblico e frenetiche performance di danza accompagnate da citazioni, racconti e aneddoti videonarrati dallo stesso Malanga.
I fondi servono per produrre lo spettacolo e portarlo al debutto affinché abbia l’opportunità di essere distribuito in Italia e all’estero e poter essere visto da tutti.


Di Cosa Abbiamo Bisogno e Perché 


Per realizzare al meglio Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs i costi da sostenere sono consistenti, per diversi motivi. Un prodotto di qualità richiede investimenti in termini tecnici e artistici: 


Tecnologie audio video: I teatri forniscono solo una piccola parte delle attrezzature che necessitano per la realizzazione dello spettacolo, tutto quello che manca lo dobbiamo noleggiare. Inoltre, per uno spettacolo così complesso e per ricreare lo stesso impatto dello show originale ma per il pubblico contemporaneo, sono necessarie tecnologie all’avanguardia. Proprio come fecero Warhol e i gli artisti della Factory nel ’67.

Scenografie: Le scenografie vanno costruite in un laboratorio esterno da professionisti, in quanto devono essere realizzate in modo che siano facilmente smontabili e trasportabili, e allo stesso tempo solide e che possano durare a lungo, oltre che adattabili  alle diverse situazioni di spazio e dimensioni che si incontrano nei vari teatri e location, bisogna poi arredare il set con gli oggetti di scena, da recuperare nei mercatini, restaurare e portarli a nuova vita.

Pagare gli artisti: Attori, musicisti,tecnici, macchinisti, regista, scenografo, costumista, light designer, tutte le figure che lavorano alla produzione, sul set e fuori dal set devono percepire un compenso settimanale adeguato all'impegno, alle capacità e all'esperienza.

Prove: Abbiamo pianificato 20 giorni di prove, gli spazi vanno affittati, le attrezzature tecniche, anche se in forma ridotta, vanno noleggiate, gli attori e le altre figure che lavorano allo spettacolo  devono necessariamente provare il copione, e devono essere pagate e rimborsate per diaria e spostamenti.

Costumi: I cambi di costume sono 24, ci daremo da fare a scovarli nei mercatini delle pulci, ma vanno comunque pagati, a volte aggiustati e spesso messi a misura.

Promozione: Locandine, manifesti (e chi li attacca), flyers (e chi li distribuisce), l'ufficio stampa, chi segue e aggiorna i social il sito e la pagina Indiegogo.

Diritti per l’utilizzo di filmati e immagini d’epoca: I diritti d' autore e la proprietà intellettuale sono imprescindibili, diamo a Cesare ciò che è di Cesare!

Polizze assicurative & sicurezza degli ambienti di lavoro: La sicurezza prima di tutto. L'ambiente di lavoro deve essere in sicurezza, chi lavora sul set deve essere messo al riparo dal rischio di infortuni.




Il vostro contributo è fondamentale, anche il più piccolo. Se non riusciamo a raggiungere l’obiettivo, lo spettacolo non potrà mai essere prodotto e questa opportunità sarà perduta definitivamente.

Rischi e Sfide
Lo spettacolo usa linguaggi differenti, quelli del teatro, della musica, del cinema e dell’arte, con tutte le problematiche che comporta la loro gestione contemporanea. Una sfida che abbiamo scelto di affrontare creando un gruppo di lavoro formato da professionisti provenienti da diverse esperienze nei vari campi artistici, affinché le competenze di ognuno siano integrate con quelle degli altri.Inoltre, Gerard Malanga ha affrontato tutte le problematiche relative alla messa in scena di questo tipo di spettacolo ben prima di noi, grazie al suo coinvolgimento diretto nell’E.P.I.

Perché una Campagna di Raccolta "Flexible"?


Siamo ottimisti e molto motivati nei confronti di questo progetto. Se non riuscissimo a raggiungere l'obiettivo prestabilito con una campagna "Fixed" (tutto o niente) , non potremmo neppure incominciare la produzione. Con una campagna di tipo "Flexible" (si ottengono tutti fondi raccolti) anche un finanziamento parziale ci permetterebbe di partire con le prime fasi della produzione.
Una successiva campagna "Fixed" al fine di completare la produzione di "Gerard Malanga's Venus in Furs" potrebbe poi essere lanciata, con il supporto del lavoro già fatto, e che vi faremo vedere nei dettagli. Semplicemente, se abbiamo eseguito bene la nostra prima parte del lavoro, ci auguriamo di essere ricompensati con ulteriori contributi!


I "Perk"


Dopo che avremo ricevuto la vostra donazione, vi contatteremo via email per la misura e il soggetto desiderato.

Ti preghiamo di aggiungere anche il perk "Costi spedizione per l'Italia" ($11), o il "Shipping costs outside Italy" perk ($24).


La Pop Art è (quasi) per Tutti

Se proprio non riuscite ad aspettare che arrivi nel teatro della vostra città, il debutto di Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs verrà ripreso, e tutti i contributori riceveranno un link privato dove potranno guardare il video dell’intero spettacolo.
Altri Modi per Supportarci... Nello Spirito della Factory!

La Factory, in quanto laboratorio di sperimentazione artistica indipendente, poteva contare su molteplici talenti che contribuivano in diversi modi alla creazione dei tanti progetti. Nello stesso modo, tutti potete dare una mano a realizzare questo spettacolo, anche semplicemente spargendo la voce. Condividete sui vostri social preferiti il nostro sito, questa pagina Indiegogo, la nostra pagina Facebook e il profilo Twitter, dove troverete immagini e curiosità sullo spettacolo e sugli straordinari personaggi della Factory. 
Grazie per il vostro supporto, sapete voi quanto potete offrire, ogni contributo è fondamentale, anche il più piccolo.




Il Team Creativo


Gerard Malanga (Direttore artistico)Poeta, fotografo, attore e filmmaker, Gerard Malanga è conosciuto al pubblico soprattutto per essere stato assistente e manager di Andy Warhol. Ha lavorato con Andy dal 1963 al 1970. Un articolo del "New York Times" del 1992 si riferisce a lui come «The Andy Warhol's most important associate».



Franco Mosconi (Autore)Lavora da oltre vent’anni a Milano nella scena artistica, musicale, del design a del clubbing, come produttore, project manager e proprietario di locali. Negli ultimi sette anni, ha portato in Italia i migliori artisti stranieri appartenenti alla scena del circo e cabaret, quali illusionisti, funamboli, maghi, burlesque performers, live bands e dj’s.

Attilio Reinhardt (Co-autore)Attilio è un presentatore, scrittore e ricercatore. Esperto di vintage cabaret e intrattenimento dagli anni '20 in poi. I suoi interessi spaziano dal cinema underground alla musica e all’arte. È laureato in Discipline dell’Arte, della Musica e dello Spettacolo.

Roberta Monopoli (Scenografa e costumista)Roberta è una scenografa e costumista, laureata con 110 e lode all’Accademia di Belle Arti di Brera. Nonostante la giovane età, può vantare importanti collaborazioni con famosi registi quali: Giorgio Barberio Corsetti, Marco Baliani, Elio DeCapitani, e prestigiosi teatri: Israeli Opera - Tel Aviv, Teatro Petruzzelli - Bari, Teatro alla Scala - Milano, Mariinsky Theatre - Russia, Operà Royale - Liège, Teatro Real - Madrid.

Fabio Iaquone and Luca Attilii (Video and light designers)Nel 2004 decidono di unire le forze e aprire insieme uno studio a Roma. La collaborazione tra i due artisti si rivela estremamente proficua. L’elenco dei lavori dello studio in questi ultimi dieci anni è quasi interminabile e conta collaborazioni con prestigiose istituzioni, teatri ed università, solo per citarne alcune:


Elements - con le musiche di John Cage - Roma

3 for Andy Warhol - Den Haag - Holland

Macbeth di Giuseppe Verdi - Teatro alla Scala - Milano

Candide di Leonard Bernstein - Teatro dell’Opera - Roma

CYP17 - Houston Dance Centre - U.S.A.

Telephone and Birds - con Achille Bonito Oliva - Auditorium parco della musica - Roma


Manuele Scalia (Band frontman)Manuele è un musicista e dj con una lunga carriera alle spalle. Attualmente è il chitarrista e cantante dei “Three Blind Mice“, una rock band indipendente con basi a Milano e Berlino. Manuele è responsabile della parte musicale live del progetto con la sua nuova band creata appositamente per questo spettacolo.



«Multimedia extravaganzas, I like to call them, have a long and dazzling history. They go back to those Kurt Weill cabarets of the mid-1920s.They pick up again with Andy Warhol’s Exploding Plastic Inevitable (1966) and with Le Stelle di Mario Schifano (1967) for which I played a major part in their inception. They were meant to dazzle and astonish a live audience, and in this they had succeeded. I had so much fun.Gerard Malanga’s Venus in Furs (2015) continues this tradition into the digital 21st Century, and I look forward in connecting with this creative spirit yet once again».
Gerard Malanga

story:
Help!!!

We need $5400 to cover the cost of a FULL LENGTH stage reading of:

"54" the musical

to be presented as part of Emerging Artist Theatre's New Work Series on  March 30th, 2014!!!


 That's in ONE WEEK!!!!


But we're not scared!!! And we LOVE exclamation points!!!!! Woot woot!!! 

"54" the musical has been awarded the coveted final spot in the festival and while E.A.T. generously provides for all the hard costs, such as venue rental, rehearsal space, insurance,  lighting, sound and support staff, we are still obligated to pay our tremendous artists a stipend for their contribution towards the development of the piece.  With fourteen actors, five musicians, one audition pianist, one production stage manager, one director and one choreographer it adds up - but that's both the cost and the reward of thinking BIG! 


Here's why YOU need to respond to our DISCO EMERGENCY:  

Not only have we already had tremendous results from our last IGG CAMPAIGN #1 which funded our concert production at THE CUTTING ROOM we have now attracted the attention of a current TONY award winning producer (representing current hits suchs as PIPPIN, ROCKY and BULLETS OVER BROADWAY) who is on board to champion the piece! Together we are inviting industry guests and fellow producers to this reading so they can evaluate us for a bigger commitment and take this show to the next level...and we already have major interest from several other producers who will be at the show!!!


Where the money goes:

DIRECTLY TO THE ARTISTS!!! So many actors donate so many hours of time and talent doing readings like this in the hopes that the project they're working on moves into production. Luckily for our tremendous cast of actors and musicians we are already well on our way towards that goal! The stipend they will receive is but a gesture of gratitude and we want to be sure they know how important their contribution to "54" the musical is - and that's where YOU come in! Your donation becomes a virtual "thank you" to all the performers who don't read about in People magazine. And we have assembled a crew of not only well-seasoned Broadway veterans but also solid new "discoveries," working musicians and professional dancers. Here are a few outtakes from our first music rehearsal where I'm doing (very) scratch vocals along with THE BAND.


What you can do beyond contributing:

TELL YOUR FRIENDS! Use the Indie GoGo tools to share this campaign through all your social media sites or copy and paste the link into an email and do it old-school-style!


Here's the concept everyone is responding to: 

Picture yourself standing outside the doors of the most infamous discotheque of all time, Studio 54. The velvet rope teases your legs as a gorgeous young bouncer points to you, beckoning you into a place only a select few are lucky enough to explore. You brush past the unlucky ones and enter into a world of glamour and excess. The disco beat vibrates through your body like a tribal rhythm as you approach the dance floor where the club’s chanteuse, COCO DE GRAND PRIX, sits on a giant crescent moon suspended from the ceiling delivering her signature song of the evening, MACARTHUR PARK. You are escorted to a seat in the shadows where you can choose to either become part of the action or just get high off the sights and sounds surrounding you. Suddenly the room explodes as couples erupt into a brisk choreographed hustle on the dance floor and we are introduced to our leading lady, ROBYN CONNORS - a privileged divorcée and one-hit disco wonder, whose dream is to return to the spotlight and headline the hottest club of all time, Studio 54. When she bumps into CLIFF KNIGHT - front man for the funk band THE BLACK KNIGHTS, she finds herself falling in love with someone who is not only on the other side of the music scene but also the racial divide. When CLIFF’s frustrated ex-girlfriend TONYA learns of their affair, she arranges for ROBYN’s segregationist brother BRIAN to play in the band – one of several attempts to see that CLIFF and ROBYN never lay hands on each other again.

“54” – the musical is an updated version of a jukebox musical, combining the touching feel of a Memphis-type story, the exciting narrative of a Rock of Ages- type disco score, the immersive experience of Fuerza Bruta and the sheer fun of The Donkey Show – allowing you to become part of the hypnotic club scene of the 70s. Utilizing a cast of 5 principal and 9 featured characters on one moving set, this funny and heartbreaking original story is enhanced by an incomparable playlist of the era’s greatest songs - reminding you that disco never sucked and that it’s still ok to have more than a great time. 

And here's how it came to be:

“54”- the musical was conceived during the summer of 2009 thanks to an excellent iTunes playlist and a decent car stereo and actually written whilst alternate-side-of-the-street parking in Manhattan the fall of 2009. It was registered with the DGA in March 2010, received a copyright in June 2010, was informally read around a dining table sometime thereafter and subsequently read in December 2010 at the historic Gramercy Theatre (now concert venue) in NYC. A more formal (private) reading was enjoyed at the Lark Theatre in NYC in the Spring of 2012 and after a successful Indie Go-Go Campaign where over $10,000 was raised in just over two months, a staged and choreographed concert production of “54”- the musical was unveiled at The Cutting Room on November 11th, 2012 to a sold-out crowd. “54”- the musical is currently in development for Broadway. 


Thanks in advance for your generous contribution and stay tuned for exciting updates along the way!


Love,


Team "54"

ROCKY and BULLETS OVER BROADWAY) who is on board to champion the piece!
Together we are inviting industry guests and fellow producers to this reading
so they can evaluate us for a bigger commitment and take this show to the next
level...and we already have major interest from several other producers who will be at the show!!!Where the money goes:DIRECTLY TO THE ARTISTS!!! So many actors donate so many hours of time and talent doing readings like this in the hopes that the project they're working on moves into production. Luckily for our tremendous cast of actors and musicians we are already well on our way towards that goal! The stipend they will receive is but a gesture of gratitude and we want to be sure they know how important their contribution to "54" the musical is - and that's where YOU come in! Your donation becomes a virtual "thank you" to all the performers who don't read about in People magazine. And we have assembled a crew of not only well-seasoned Broadway veterans but also solid new "discoveries," working musicians and professional dancers. Here are a few outtakes from our first music rehearsal where I'm doing (very) scratch vocals along with THE BAND.What you can do beyond contributing:TELL YOUR FRIENDS! Use the Indie GoGo tools to share this campaign through all your social media sites or copy and paste the link into an email and do it old-school-style!
Here's the concept
everyone is responding to: 
Picture yourself standing
outside the doors of the most infamous discotheque of all time, Studio 54. The
velvet rope teases your legs as a gorgeous young bouncer points to you, beckoning
you into a place only a select few are lucky enough to explore. You brush past
the unlucky ones and enter into a world of glamour and excess. The disco beat
vibrates through your body like a tribal rhythm as you approach the dance floor
where the club’s chanteuse, COCO DE GRAND PRIX, sits on a giant crescent moon
suspended from the ceiling delivering her signature song of the evening,
MACARTHUR PARK. You are escorted to a seat in the shadows where you can choose
to either become part of the action or just get high off the sights and sounds
surrounding you. Suddenly the room explodes as couples erupt into a brisk
choreographed hustle on the dance floor and we are introduced to our leading
lady, ROBYN CONNORS - a privileged divorcée and one-hit disco wonder, whose
dream is to return to the spotlight and headline the hottest club of all time,
Studio 54. When she bumps into CLIFF KNIGHT - front man for the funk band THE
BLACK KNIGHTS, she finds herself falling in love with someone who is not only
on the other side of the music scene but also the racial divide. When CLIFF’s
frustrated ex-girlfriend TONYA learns of their affair, she arranges for ROBYN’s
segregationist brother BRIAN to play in the band – one of several attempts to
see that CLIFF and ROBYN never lay hands on each other again.

“54”
– the musical is an updated version of a jukebox musical, combining the
touching feel of a Memphis-type story, the exciting narrative of a Rock of
Ages- type disco score, the immersive experience of Fuerza Bruta and the sheer
fun of The Donkey Show – allowing you to become part of the hypnotic club scene
of the 70s. Utilizing a cast of 5 principal and 9 featured characters on one
moving set, this funny and heartbreaking original story is enhanced by an
incomparable playlist of the era’s greatest songs - reminding you that disco
never sucked and that it’s still ok to have more than a great time. 
And
here's how it came to be:
“54”- the
musical was conceived during the summer of 2009 thanks to an excellent iTunes
playlist and a decent car stereo and actually written whilst
alternate-side-of-the-street parking in Manhattan the fall of 2009. It was
registered with the DGA in March 2010, received a copyright in June 2010, was
informally read around a dining table sometime thereafter and subsequently read
in December 2010 at the historic Gramercy Theatre (now concert venue) in NYC. A
more formal (private) reading was enjoyed at the Lark Theatre in NYC in the
Spring of 2012 and after a successful Indie Go-Go Campaign where over $10,000
was raised in just over two months, a staged and choreographed concert
production of “54”- the musical was unveiled at The Cutting Room on November
11th, 2012 to a sold-out crowd. “54”- the musical is currently in development
for Broadway. Thanks in advance for your generous contribution and stay tuned for exciting updates along the way!Love,Team "54"

story:
Summary

Frivolous Fools Performance is an Alberta born company interested in bringing new life to neglected stories while giving new purpose to discarded junk. We are a collective of emerging artists interested in creating new works, which exploit the potential for captive story-telling through folklore, devised sound and re-appropriated discarded materials.  We are currently planning a Fringe tour of our production titled, The Hudson Bay Epic.  This one-act script was written by two of the ensemble members, Geneviève Paré and Ian McFarlane. It is a historical fiction, which reveals an unexpected love affair amongst two of Henry Hudson’s crew, on his last expedition into the Canadian arctic.

By staging this performance on a Fringe tour of Western Canada, we can expand our audience range, explore new performance opportunities and connect with a wider web of Canadian artists.   We see this production as a landmark in our early careers because it is the first production that we have nurtured to fruition with a voice that is distinctly our own.

The Hudson Bay Epic will be touring at:

  • Winnipeg Fringe Theatre Festival, July 16th - 27th, 2014
  • Calgary Fringe Theatre Festival, August 1st - 9th, 2014 
  • Edmonton Fringe Theatre Festival, August 15th - 25th, 2014.

Your support will assist with:

  • Fringe Festival fees
  • Venue rentals for rehearsals and set construction
  • Touring expenses such as gas, accommodation and food
This project is worth funding because it is an opportunity to nurture the commitment of up and coming Canadian Artists with multi-disciplinary training, proven professional successes, an original voice, sustainable practices and who are interested in Canadian stories.  This project is a genuine example of the joy that exists in committed collective creativity.

story:
Salut!

Thank you for visiting our indiegogo page. My name is Jackie Schiffer (www.jackieschiffer.com) and I am a NYC-based actor and first time producer. My co-producer and I are writing to ask for your support in an upcoming business and theatrical adventure. This upcoming September 12th and 13th, we will be producing our first musical together- a two-woman  show in cooperation with Dramatic Publishing at New York's famed cabaret venue, The Duplex. These performances will mark the NYC premiere of C'est La Vie by Gregg Opelka.  

The show is about two cabaret singers in 1950s Paris who decide to take charge of their creative destiny after being dealt years of the same boring set at Chez Leplee (the cabaret). 

I was particularly drawn to the piece because of my Chicago roots (Gregg is Chicago-based and C'est la Vie had a run at Light Opera Works... a place I interned before moving to NYC) and because I am a French speaker. The team was also particularly drawn to the piece because it is about two friends who come together to create their own opportunities-- a challenge we both feel this musical will offer us. 

As young artists, we feel that it is important to capture the message of the two women we will portray--- to seize the moment and create your own rich artistic experiences. 

We are committed to making this wonderful work of life be an outstanding piece of immersive theater in NYC. Updates about our production can be found at: www.cestlavienyc.weebly.com. We will host a cabaret fundraiser this June to raise additional funding, but where will your funds go?

-Rental fee of scores: $400

-Royalties: $150 

-Costumes: $300

-Scripts: $50

-CD: $30

-Stipend for Director: ~$150

-Stipend for Musical Director: ~$150

-Stipend for Choreographer: ~$150 

-Actor Stipends: $300 

-Space Rental: $230 

-Dialect Coaching: 4 sessions at $120/hr. 

-Printed Materials (programs, posters, postcards): $150

-Press Kit: $200

-Publicity Shoot: $200 

Additional Expenses: Dialect CD, props, CD/Videography of Performance, Promotional ads, rehearsal space rental

The composer/writer Mr. Opelka  is interested in attending our premiere. Please help us give this piece the NYC debut it deserves! 

Any support you can offer would be so greatly appreciated. Thank you for your time and we hope to see you at the performances September 12 and 13th.

Merci,

Jackie

story:
Creative Philanthropy 

Hello! My name is Lauren Cox (@humanlauren), I am a San Francisco born, New York-based artist and dancer to the soul.  With a degree in Sociology, 10+ years of experience in movement & life skills programming and 25 years of diverse dance training and performance.  I have set my sights to higher purpose.

I love travel.

I love people.

I love the studio & stage. 

I am traveling to Hyderabad, India January 28th to March 6th, 2014.  In this month I plan to...

1. Teach a 2 week workshop for beginners in western dances including strength/flexibility, contemporary, ballet, street jazz & freestyle...

2. Learn some of the cultural dances of India including Bharata Natyam (the "fire" dance) & Kathak (an Indian classical dance), and maybe slip into a meditation/yoga class or 3 ;)

3. Teach at a local orphanage,

and... 4. Choreograph and set a 30 minute showcase including myself and the Steps Studio director, Prithviraj, for the local community at Ravindhra Bharathi auditorium in Hyderabad.

The Campaign 

The plane ticket is bought by Steps Dance Studio (Thanks!!) and the workshop and show is in the making.  The total amount needed, $2,000 USD, will be used to…

1. fund 5 workshop goers 

2. fund the costumes, props and music for the set. 

3. support the local orphanage 

4. fund my food and cover my butt! 

If the full amount isn't reached, it's okay, any little bit helps. See all good karma "perks" below!...

The Impact

Dance is a pure expression of the soul, no matter what the background.  This is my gift and I would like to share it with as many people as possible.  I hope that in opening my gift I can inspire those that surround me to open theirs.  Art and happiness is real when shared.

I recently traveled to Hong Kong to perform at the Hong Kong Coliseum with the beautiful Joey Yung and to teach a few classes at Ones To Watch Dance Studios.  There is a demand for versatility in the industry and the dance community worldwide.  The more diverse you are in your art the more unique, inspiring and valuable you become.  This is my attempt to not only share this philosophy with others but to keep growing myself.  I cannot wait to share the result of this trip with you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share this campaign and to approach me with an idea for the next HumanLauren Creative Philanthropy project!

story:
Boomerang Theatre Company needs your support!

Boomerang Theatre Company has spent the last 16 years building an unparalleled track record of exceptional work in Indie Theatre. The body of work speaks for itself: 56 full productions; nearly 60 readings and workshops of new plays; 8 New York Innovative Theatre Nominations; A Caffe Cino Fellowship; 17 free productions of Shakespeare plays in parks throughout New York City, serving nearly twenty five thousand audience members; nearly fifty thousand overall audience members served; and an uncountable number of artists given an opportunity to grow, shine, and demonstrate their passionate understanding of the world.

During the next 8 months, we are embarking on our biggest projects ever:

-We are expanding our First Flight New Play Festival to include more opportunity and support for artists.
-We are producing the New York Premiere of the hit drama WAVING GOODBYE by acclaimed playwright Jamie Pachino, directed by Jordana Williams
-And we are remounting our smash hit comedy LICKSPITTLES, BUTTONHOLERS AND DAMNED PERNICIOUS GO-BETWEENS by Johnna Adams, directed by John Hurley.

Producing these projects is the next defining moment for our company, setting the tone for the company we are as we approach our 20th anniversary milestone year in 2018. We are striving to be a company keeps our audience engaged by telling the stories that reverberate with the world we live in. We are also the company that knows these compelling projects on happen when artists are nurtured, supported and free.  Now, 56 full productions under our collective belt, the same ideas still fuel the organization. Boomerang Theatre Company does plays that have to be done, created by artists living in the moment in history right now, responding to the world be live in and putting that response onstage to talk about, scream at, laugh along with, mourn with and celebrate. These plays burn, pulse, and rage. They are not timid plays. They seek to break ground, to make a difference to the audience, leaving them a different set of people then they were when the lights went down. Whether producing detailed revivals, rediscovering lost plays that needed a new examination, or premiering a new play born yesterday, these plays are chosen to communicate the way we live today, the inherent urgency of a life lived fully on each day.

We need your help to continue making this vision a reality!

story:
THANKS TO YOU ALL FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!! WE MADE BUDGET AND EVEN MORE! WE SOLD OUT OUR RUN TOO! THANKS EVERYONE!

FATTY FATTY NO FRIENDS from Mind The Art Entertainment, is a dark, spoken-word musical composed & directed by Christian de Gre, with lyrics by Joseph Reese Anderson, premiering this summer at the New York International Fringe Festival (August 8th - 24th, 2014.)

Based on the children’s book of the same name by Serrana Gay, with illustrations by Ashley Soliman, it tells the story of Tommy, an overweight kid just trying to get through the day as best he can. But when the cruelty of the other kids becomes too much to bear, Tommy snaps and realizes that in the great lunchroom of life, bullies are delicious. 

Together, both the book & musical take on the subject of bullying - as well as the aftermath of revenge - and are as entertaining as they are poignant. For the stage, we’ve gathered a highly talented cast and creative team to create a truly unique show that is poised to become a breakout hit at this year’s New York International Fringe Festival. 

But for that to happen, we need your support! 

With your donation, you can help make both the book and the show a reality. And in addition to the perks of donating, over the next few months, we will be taking you behind-the-scenes through videos, interviews, and our blog, giving you the inside scoop on the process of bringing these projects to life. 

Help bring Tommy’s story - and the story of countless others - to the world. Thank you in advance for your help and we hope to see you this summer at the New York International Fringe Festival.

story:
Palatinotes need you! 

Do you remember, the 21st night of September? Co-presidents Julia and Lizzie realised that they had a dream, a song to sing. In a very female empowered, sisters are doing it for themselves kinda way they decided to start takin' care of business so they could no longer say that they'd never had a dream come true. It was a time to not stop believin' and realise that they could have it all. So as the autumn leaves began to drift past their windows they travelled the world and the seven seas, looking for someone (well 10 other someones) to raise their glasses with, sing songs with and no longer leave them dancing with themselves. They grew stronger than yesterday, together, together everyone and time after time they proved that anything others could do, Palatinotes could do better. 
But give me a second, I need to get my story straight - it wasn't the thrill of the fight these new kids on the block were looking for. No, they would walk five hundred miles, maybe even five hundred more to reach the lands of Loch Lomond and sing to the bonny bonny banks of the Royal Mile. 
We ain't got 99 problems, just this 1 that we need a dollar, dollar, dollar is what we need. We will share with you our story until the Scottish hills are alive with the sound of music. 
It's our lives and it's now or never, we need your love, we need your time. Please don't stop the music. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need a bit of extra money to fund our publicity and advertising. It will also go towards props and costumes. To get the word out there and to add that pizazz. 
  • Every little helps but the more generous the bigger and better the perks. We're offering signed posters, singles, serenades and sass. 
  • We'd love to be able to make this the best that we can and will work hard to make sure every penny is matched in effort from our end. 

The Impact

  • So we can bring our new and fresh outlook on music in Durham to a bigger stage. So we can learn and grow and have fun along the way. 
  • Help make our Fringe debut a blinder! 
  • Put a smile on our faces.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Come see our show! 19th-23rd of August at theSpace@Niddry Street. 
    • Like us on Facebook (Durham University A Capella Choir) and follow us on twitter and instagram (@Palatinotes)

story:
LOCKHART©

A new musical

Music and lyrics by Jason Carr

Book by Ashley Robinson

How Lockhart Came to Be

Lockhart, the musical, is about hope. We can all identify with it.  It celebrates who we ‘really are’ rather than who other people want us to be. Imagine wanting to let your hair down and join in with all the authentic personalities on stage?

Producer Leila Witkin has always been fascinated by the human voice and what it tells us about a person.  The voice is the muscle of the soul.  She has sought ways to delve into the psyche for all individuals and to tap into the persuasive power of successful communication.  This does, of course, lead to opening up an entirely new world for those who previously have been unable to portray themselves authentically. 

To that end, Leila wrote a book that explores how one can attain those lofty, but achievable goals, of self-awareness and ultimately become that authentic person, especially by being able to speak in public.  Its title is UnAfraid, UnFrazzled and UnFrogettable. 

Believe it or not, public speaking is the number one fear for most people. Comedian Jerry Seinfeld has said that, “most people would rather be in the casket than making the eulogy.”  We all strive to be liked and we want to be accepted, regardless of who we are.

And, it sometimes takes real intestinal fortitude to be authentic and not let fear lead the way.  It all comes down to the question of mind-set, to no longer live falsely, but to simply be oneself. Discovery of the true self is a valid revelation of oneself. Lockhart illustrates this and at the same time deals with forgiveness.

Once the thought of creating a musical that would explore one’s individuality to find the courage to stand up and stand out, to be different, to find one’s authentic voice began to resonate, a call was made to Jason, to begin discussions about creating a musical. 

He suggested that Ashley Robinson be brought on board to create the book.

This show is a classic American book musical in a Southern-gothic style.  It is based on the premise that is espoused by Leila Witkin herself, her beliefs and the book that she wrote, that we all have the right to celebrate our authentic selves.


Lockhart: Story Premise

Gilbert Worthy, 27, is a young man stuck in Lockhart, Georgia, a dying, poor Southern mill village that no longer has a mill – population 367.  It’s nearly an hour from even a supermarket, a movie theater, or a Walmart.  He lives in a tiny house in dire need of repair with his chronically ill mother Melinda.  Trapped with a cheating girlfriend, three dead-end jobs, Gilbert has an intense longing to get out.

One night, he escapes to his “spot” by the river where he goes to get away and to think, lying in the bed of his pick-up truck and just looking up at the stars.  He feels stuck, trapped by the isolation of his poverty-stricken town with no opportunity.  It’s like quicksand—the more you try to escape, the deeper you sink.  But, he feels a pull of greatness.  There’s something better for him out there, somewhere…

As he gazes up at the stars, he hears some commotion coming from the other bank of the river.  Then, in the starlight…colourful lights illuminate!  THE FAIR is here this week; he forgot!  The fair hasn’t been to this town since the mill closed 16 years ago.  Gilbert is excited; it’s as though a colourful cluster of stars has fallen to the ground.  “A cluster of stars that I can actually reach, walk right into, a magnetic mystery pulling me into itself.” 

Gilbert has found something extraordinary in the most unlikely place, a light in the darkness, a mirage.  This is the opening metaphor for finding one’s greatness where it is least expected.

The Team:


Leila Witkin - Producer


Leila Witkin is bright and skilful as a performer, director and producer.

She possesses a remarkable and fascinating background that, with many twists and turns, has produced a fully integrated and well-rounded individual with a passion for all fields of the performing arts.

She is totally capable of taking her background and expertise towards working in a positive way for creating new and inspiring projects in the theatre. So who exactly is Leila Witkin? First of all, her mother was a very successful theatre director and the performing “bug” hit Leila when she was only five years old.

Alas, she was also a shy child and needed to find a way to express her own talents and ideas. Her father was a lawyer and, in fact, his clerk was a much younger Nelson Mandela prior to his many years of incarceration.

He was the one who urged the young Leila to “find her own voice” which took on many forms over the years as she matured and developed as a person and as a professional. She completed her Licentiate Teachers Diploma at Trinity College of Music London in Speech and Drama.

 At the age of fifteen she went abroad to Lausanne, Switzerland where she was a voice student and became quite successful even at that tender age. She gave a concert where she had a standing ovation following her performance that gave her, her first big taste of stardom. The pressures to succeed on the stage, however, were daunting. She made a conscientious decision to turn her focus towards obtaining a Performers Diploma in speech and drama at Cape Town University. Severe allergies to paint and dust found in all theatres were a stumbling block to life as a performer.

But, undeterred and determined to follow her passion for the arts, she turned to directing both theatre and television, after attending a television production and direction course at New York University. Her first major success for which she received an award was a production of Ekhaya in 1977 in South Africa. She worked at the South African Broadcasting Corporation where she produced and directed a weekly live magazine programme for Kidults. She received the Star Tonight award for the best children’s programme in 1983.

It was while Leila was producing and directing her award-winning weekly live television programme that she was introduced to Dr. Mark Rittenberg, a charismatic educator and leader in the human development field.

He was offering coaching courses to executives using theatre skills as his method to build communication in business world. For Leila Witkin, this was a natural progression, a way to bring together all of her background, expertise and experience of the theatre and to work with those who are challenged when standing in front of an audience.

She armed herself with credentials that were granted for completing her certification as a Personal, Corporate and Executive Coach through the Coaching Academy at the University of California at Berkeley’s Haas School of Business. Having immigrated to the United Kingdom now almost 25 years ago, Leila Witkin has continued her association with Dr. Rittenberg over the years. He has encouraged her to integrate her very successful skills as producer and director into her work as a coach.

Considered a leader by clients and colleagues alike, Leila Witkin has established a wise and dynamic presence in academic seminars, leadership conferences, and corporate presentations on three continents.

With her extensive background in stage direction, television production, and business development, Leila Witkin is particularly attracted to celebrities and creative people for whom she has a special empathy.

A forward-looking person, surrounded with life experiences and events, who is then able to transform all of that into a novel and inventive way, can only achieve this success. This describes Leila Witkin at this point in her own life.


Jason Carr (Composer & Lyricist)

Biography


Born in Leeds, Jason attended the Guildhall School of Music and Drama in London’s Barbican Centre, where he studied composition with Francis Shaw.

After winning the 1988 Vivian Ellis Prize for young writers of musicals, Jason was invited by director Peter Hall to compose the musical Born Again (from Ionesco's absurdist play Rhinoceros), which was produced at Chichester Festival Theatre in 1990 with Broadway and Hollywood stars Mandy Patinkin and Jose Ferrer.

From 2003-5 he was Associate Composer at the Chichester Festival Theatre where, as well as composing incidental music for six plays and hosting a sell-out series of late-night cabarets, his music and lyrics were heard in two new musicals: a main-stage adaptaion of Charles Kingsley’s The Water Babies (book by Gary Yershon) directed by Jeremy Sams, starring Louise Gold and Joe McGann in 2003; and a specially-commissioned chamber musical for the Minerva: Six Pictures of Lee Miller (book by Edward Kemp) directed by Anthony van Laast, starring Anna Francolini in 2005.

His most recent works are musical adaptations of Dickens’ A Christmas Carol (written with playwright Bryony Lavery) produced at Birmingham Rep, and (also with Ms. Lavery) Hans Christian Andersen’s The Snow Queen for Chichester.

Jason has written songs and dance numbers for Lido – La Tournee (the Paris Lido’s world tour), the chamber opera Strangers Inside for Liza Pulman, as well as a ballet score for Tom Sapsford Last Night at the Empire (Clore Studio Upstairs, Royal Opera House).

Jason has composed incidental music for over 40 plays at the RNT, RSC, in the West End and on Broadway. Favourites include four by Tennessee Williams – The Glass Menagerie (directed by Sam Mendes at the Donmar), Suddenly, Last Summer (directed by Sean Mathias at the Comedy), Camino Real (RSC Swan) and Vieux Carre (both directed by Steven Pimlott). And many people seem to have fond memories of Bim! Bam! Bom! – The 'winning' entry in Tim Luscombe's EuroVision (Vaudeville)!

Work as an orchestrator includes the 5 Olivier Award-winning London revival of Stephen Sondheim’s Sunday in the Park with George which transferred to Broadway, winning Jason the Drama Desk Award and a Tony Award nomination for Best Orchestrations in 2008. He has also orchestrated the recent London productions of Annie Get Your Gun, La Cage Aux Folles and A Little Night Music (currently playing on Broadway with Angela Lansbury and Catherine Zeta- Jones).

Also in demand as a pianist and musical director, Jason has appeared with Elisabeth Welch, Betty Garrett, Kitty Carlisle Hart, Lorna Dallas, Maria Friedman By Special Arrangement (Donmar, Whitehall, Ambassador's), with Michael Ball in Alone Together (Donmar), Louise Gold By Appointment (Jermyn Street), in Noel and Gertie (Duke of York’s). He is also a musical director for the Lost Musicals seasons.


Jonathan Butterell - Director 

Recent work in NY includes directing SECOND CHANCE at The Public Theatre New York.

Other work includes, directing the World Premiere of Josh Schmidt”s WHIDA PERU, RESSURECTION TANGLE and also directing Victoria Clark in TRES NIÑAS, both part of Inner Voices for Premier Stages.

He directed the World Premiere of GIANT, based on Edna Ferber’s sweeping American novel, at the Signature Theatre as part of their New American Voices commission program.

He created Musical Staging for the 2005 Tony Award Winning THE LIGHT IN THE PIAZZA and the 2004 Tony Award winning ASSASSINS.

He choreographed the 2003 Tony Award winning NINE revival, starring Antonio Banderas & Chita Rivera as well as the London Donmar Warehouse, Buenos Aires and Tokyo productions of NINE, all directed by David Leveaux.

Additional Broadway:
  • New Musical Staging for FIDDLER ON THE ROOF revival, (director David Leveaux).
  • Musical Staging for the original workshop of Sondheim’s WISE GUYS (director Sam Mendes) at New York Theater Workshop;
  • Lynn Ahrens & Stephen Flaherty’s A MAN OF NO IMPORTANCE, Lincoln Center Theatre (director Joe Mantello);
  • Staged the 50th Anniversary celebration of the Public Theatre titled PUBLIC SINGS!
  • At New York City Center with Meryl Streep, Ben Stiller, Elaine Stritch, Eartha Kitt

UK :
  • Stiles & Drewe’s Soho Cinders at the Soho Theatre. Earlier work includes:
  • Donmar Warehouse: COMPANY (director Sam Mendes, West End transfer); HABEAS CORPUS; INTO THE WOODS (co-directed with John Crowley);
  • HOW I LEARNED TO DRIVE;
  • THE MAIDS and ELECTRA starring Zoe Wanamaker (Broadway transfer);

He devised and directed Michael Ball in ALONE TOGETHER -- “Divas at the Donmar” (also at the Royal Haymarket Theatre in London).

Co-directed with David McVicker SWEENEY TODD (Opera North and Sadlers Wells).
Co-directed with Julia McKenzie PETER PAN (Royal Festival Hall) Musical Staging Sondheim’s PASSION (director Jeremy Sams, West End).

Associate Director: OTHELLO at Royal National Theatre (director Sam Mendes) and HAMLET at Royal Shakespeare Company (director Stephen Pimlott).

INTERNATIONAL: Directed THE SOUND OF MUSIC in Buenos Aires at the Opera Theatre.

He directed both ORPHEUS DESCENDING and Strindberg’s CREDITORS, for Theatre Project Tokyo.

Film:
Choreography for FINDING NEVERLAND starring Johnny Depp and Kate Winslet (7 Academy Award nominations) and STAY starring Ewan McGregor (both directed by Marc Forster).


Ashley Robinson - Writer, Actor

Ashley Robinson is both a writer and an actor. Born and raised in rural South Carolina, he specializes in writing about life in the South and most especially about the small town in which he spent his formative years, Lockhart.

He also has had the advantage of honing both his writing and acting skills, at which he excels, at the prestigious University of North Carolina, School of the Arts.! This exceptionally talented young man, still in his 20s, is making quite a name for himself on both fronts of writing and acting. He has adapted books for musicals based on works by Tennessee Williams and has developed a new piece with David Binder and Warner Brothers Theatrical Ventures.

He is also currently finishing a pilot for a television show that takes place in North Carolina.! Currently, Ashley Robinson is in production for Truman Capote’s Christmas Memory in the role of Capote that is preparing for its Off-Broadway debut.

As an actor, he also just premiered in Steve Martin’s bluegrass musical Bright Star at the Old Globe Theatre in San Diego CA this past Fall 2014. He recently was seen as Tyler in the Olivier Award- winning Merrily We Roll Along (Tyler - Menier Chocolate Factory and West End), as well as originating the role of Jett Rink in the musical version of Giant that received a Helen Hayes Award nomination.

Ashley Robinson’s numerous theatre credits also include the roles of Tybalt in The Last Goodbye (the Jeff Buckley/ Romeo and Juliet musical) at Williamstown Theatre Festival, Sweeney Todd (NY Philharmonic), Wicked (Original Chicago Cast), Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet (Benvolio), Take Me Along (Richard, Irish Repertory Theatre, NYC), Meet Me in St. Louis (Lon, Irish Repertory Theatre, NYC), A Child’s Christmas in Wales (Irish Repertory Theatre, NYC), Hair (Claude), Floyd Collins (Floyd, Gerald Freedman, director), Stud’s Terkel’s The Good War (World Premiere), Twelfth Night (Feste), Waiting for Godot (Lucky), Cripple of Inishmann (Billy).

His film and television credits include Merrily We Roll Along, Hate (with Marcia Gay Harden), Fallen Souls, and The Accident. This is Ashley Robinson’s second collaboration with composer/lyricist Jason Carr on the book for Lockhart, the musical!


Use of proceeds:

The proceeds will go towards commissioning of the workshop and the musical in order to create as exiting and ground breaking new show.

The money raised during this campaign will be used towards the £1.5 million Production Costs (from inception to Opening Night). These costs include production fees, rehearsal salaries, theatre expenses advertising & publicity, contingency and running reserve.

Target market:
  • Regular musical theatre-goers
  • Quality West End audiences seeking an event, or special occasion ticket
  • Domestic visitors to London
  • International tourists, with an emphasis on Americans
  • Groups (coach operators, tour operators)

Classic Broadway fans Characteristics of target market According to the 'Economist' - the tills are alive - the musicals business is bigger, more global and more fabulous than ever!

SALT states that London theatre takes more than £600 million at the box office. Audiences of more than 22 million visited London theatres in 2012/13. Both box office and attendance at London theatres are increasing – box office was up 1.6% and attendances 5.5% year on year from 2011/12 to 2012/13 (although yield fell).

London theatre is better attended than Premier League football and takes more at the box office than London’s cinemas. Average price paid for a London theatre ticket is £27.76 (in 2012/13) nearly a quarter (24%) of holiday visitors who stay in London will go to the theatre.
What We Need & What You Get

We need your support- whether its £10, £25 or £50, any amount helps, and we want to thank you for it! For your tax deductible donation, we'd like to give an extra thank you by sending you gifts. Because our audience is who we do this for, and because we can't wait for you to see our new musical.

Other Ways You Can Help this campaign! >>

Unable to throw us a cash donation right now? Share this on your social network of choice, email, text message, or phone call. As we say every night, "Word of mouth is the best form of advertising". Please share this campaign with your friend! :-)

LOCKHART©



A new musical


Music and lyrics by Jason
Carr
Book by
Ashley Robinson






How
Lockhart Came to Be
Lockhart,
the musical, is about hope. We can all identify with it.  It celebrates who we ‘really are’ rather than
who other people want us to be. Imagine wanting to let your hair down and join
in with all the authentic personalities on stage? 
Producer
Leila Witkin has always been fascinated by the human voice and what it tells us
about a person.  The voice is the muscle
of the soul.  She has sought ways to
delve into the psyche for all individuals and to tap into the persuasive power
of successful communication.  This does,
of course, lead to opening up an entirely new world for those who previously
have been unable to portray themselves authentically.  
To
that end, Leila wrote a book that explores how one can attain those lofty, but
achievable goals, of self-awareness and ultimately become that authentic
person, especially by being able to speak in public.  Its title is UnAfraid, UnFrazzled and
UnFrogettable.  
Believe it or not, public speaking is the number one fear for most people. Comedian
Jerry Seinfeld has said that, “most people would rather be in the casket than
making the eulogy.”  We all strive to be
liked and we want to be accepted, regardless of who we are. 
And,
it sometimes takes real intestinal fortitude to be authentic and not let fear
lead the way.  It all comes down to the
question of mind-set, to no longer live falsely, but to simply be oneself.
Discovery of the true self is a valid revelation of oneself. Lockhart
illustrates this and at the same time deals with forgiveness. 
Once
the thought of creating a musical that would explore one’s individuality to
find the courage to stand up and stand out, to be different, to find one’s
authentic voice began to resonate, a call was made to Jason, to begin discussions
about creating a musical.  
He
suggested that Ashley Robinson be brought on board to create the book.

show is a classic American book musical in a Southern-gothic style.  It is based on the premise that is espoused
by Leila Witkin herself, her beliefs and the book that she wrote, that we all

The proceeds will go towards commissioning of the workshop and the musical in order to create as exiting and ground breaking new show. 

The money raised during this campaign will be used towards the £1.5 million Production Costs (from inception to Opening Night). These costs include production fees, rehearsal salaries, theatre expenses advertising & publicity, contingency and running reserve.



Target market:
Regular musical theatre-goers 
Quality West End audiences seeking an event, or special occasion ticket
Domestic visitors to London
International tourists, with an emphasis on Americans
Groups (coach operators, tour operators)
Classic Broadway fans

Characteristics of target market
According to the 'Economist' - the tills are alive - the musicals business is bigger, more global and more fabulous than ever!

SALT states that London theatre takes more than £600 million at the box office. Audiences of more than 22 million visited London theatres in 2012/13.
Both box office and attendance at London theatres are increasing – box office was up 1.6% and attendances 5.5% year on year from 2011/12 to 2012/13 (although yield fell).

London theatre is better attended than Premier League football and takes more at the box office than London’s cinemas. Average price paid for a London theatre ticket is £27.76 (in 2012/13) nearly a quarter (24%) of holiday visitors who stay in London will go to the theatre.

We need your support- whether its £10, £25 or £50, any amount helps, and we want to thank you for it!  For your tax deductible donation, we'd like to give an extra thank you by sending you gifts. Because our audience is who we do this for, and because we can't wait for you to see our new musical.

this campaign! >>Unable to throw us a cash donation right now? Share this on your social network of choice, email, text message, or phone call.  As we say every night, "Word of mouth is the best form of advertising". Please share this campaign with your friend! :-)

story:
Awakening Movement is a faith-based dance organization formed in February 2013 with the aim of supporting and encouraging artists. We are committed to exploring, creating, and presenting works that will transform lives and unite communities. Six dancers from Awakening Movement will be traveling from New York City to Indianapolis and Chicago this August to present work and launch our E3 Initiative outreach program. Collaborations, performances, and workshops will occur throughout the surrounding areas from August 7th-August 17th, but we need your help raising the funds for our tour! Please take a moment and consider partnering with us on this new endeavor. Donations made to our Indiegogo Campaign are not tax-deductible to the extent by law; however, to make a tax-deductible donation through Fractured Atlas click here - https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=12900 

Any amount is greatly appreciated!

Sponsor a Dancer

Directly partner with Jake Bone, Megan Guinta, Devin Oshiro, Hannah Smith, Brandon Welch, or Sarah Zielinski by sponsoring a dancer on our Midwest tour. Your donation will enable each individual to share their passion and love of movement with people of all ages and backgrounds. Through this one time opportunity, a donation of $750 will cover transportation, accommodation, performance fees, and allow us to collaborate with dance companies, churches, schools and studios. Each artist will personally speak to their sponsor in a phone conversation following the Midwest Tour as well as a postcard along the way. 

Become an E3 Founding Patron

Awakening Movement’s E3 Initiative has been crafted to encourage by lifting the heads of the discouraged, empower by equipping individuals in their purpose and calling, and provide a safe space for anyone to encounter the love of Jesus. This new outreach program will open doors for Awakening Movement to build personal connections through workshops, creative sessions, and performances. Donors of $300 or more will forever be considered as a founding patron of the E3 Initiative. Your support will enable us to empower others through the gift of movement.

Meet the Team

Awakening Movement functions by the faithfulness of our Volunteer Staff. As a team we seek to be a safe haven in which dancers of all backgrounds can explore their art, spirituality, express themselves, serve others, and be a part of a supportive community. Here is a personal statement from each of our team members about what we are seeking to personally awaken:

“I am awakening joy in movement.” –Brandon Welch

“I am awakening a union of strength and grace.” – Hannah Smith

“I am awakening a loving environment for mind, body, and spirit.” – Nicole Jones

“I am awakening an individual stamp of authenticity.” – Jake Bone

“I am awakening honesty with others--being true--being connected.” –Sarah Zielinski

“I am awakening our society to see the importance, relevance, and legitimacy of artistic expression.” – Megan Guinta

“I am awakening my eyes to see God's beauty in all I do.” – Devin Oshiro

story:
What Is "Hyperlink"?

Hyperlink is a new song cycle - 

Back up. What's a Song Cycle?

Oh, right. A song cycle is basically the musical theatre version of a concept album. It's an hour of songs connected by a theme and musical motifs. Unlike a traditional musical, there is no overarching narrative, but rather smaller narratives contained within the songs that feature different characters. This will be a fun challenge for the actors, as there are only three of them. :P

Performed live?

Yep! Like a cabaret. But more interconnected. Halfway between a cabaret and a musical, I guess.

Got it. Continue...

Cool. So, "Hyperlink" came about when I was a student at NYU under the guidance of Julianne Wick Davis. The concept was inspired by a couple of articles by David Wong and Leigh Alexander in which they described new forms of emotions invented by the Internet. As an avid internet-user and someone chronically fascinated by humanity, I knew this was something I had to dig into.

Because after all, the internet isn't made of "a series of tubes" or a bunch of pre-installed modems. It's made of people.

And that's kinda cool.

Also, terrifying.

That's what "Hyperlink" explores.


Alright, but why ask for money now?

Because "Hyperlink" is happening! "Hyperlink" will be presented in its entirety at the Metropolitan Room in New York City on July 20th, 2016.
We really want to deliver the highest quality of performance to our audience, so that's why we are starting this campaign. This money covers:
  • Payment for the three professional performers, two females and one male.
  • Marketing costs, so we can get the word out there.

  • Instrumentalists costs, including payment for a Musical Directors.

  • Director's fee.

  • Producer fee. (I am so fortunate to have Rachel Kunstadt on board, who founded LezCab and has produced cabarets across NYC, including Broadway Sings for PKD!)

  • Indiegogo's platform fee.


So, what happens if you make money from this?
Should there be any profit after all expenses have been paid, the money will go directly towards funding future performances & projects.
Cool... but what can I get?
Besides the emotional benefit of helping new artists?
Yes. Besides that.
Well, I've got some cool perks lined up! How about... tickets to see the show?
What if I'm not in NYC?
Then maybe you'd like some public adoration. I've got social media shoutouts and program recognition.
Got anything custom-made?
Glad you asked. For higher-tier rewards, I will write you a custom Thank You song and post it on YouTube.
Additionally, we have a reward tier wherein digital artist and moderator of the internet sensation Scamp the Corgi, Katie Fiete, will draw you a custom avatar! Send her a picture of your dog - or any dog - and your favorite Broadway character, and she will put them together. Wow.
That's kind of cute.
It's really cute. Look at this. Here's a corgi.


Here's a corgi as Mark from "Rent."


Say I don't like dogs...
Yes, you can have a cat avatar.


Risks & Challenges

The good news for donors is this: the performance at the Metropolitan Room is happening for sure. They, and we, have a mentality of "the show must go on." So any donations will 100% be going towards a very real production.
If we do not meet our goal, we will be paying the expenses out of pocket, which hinders the possibility of any future performances and projects coming to fruition for quite a while.

Other Ways You Can Help

There is no pressure to donate! I will still love you. There are other ways you can help us out, though!

  • Share this campaign on social media! Indiegogo has some handy sharing tools.
  • Share the Facebook event page and invite your friends.
  • Spread the word about the show.
  • You can buy a ticket by clicking here.

You can buy a ticket by clicking here.

story:
THE EXPULSION: Would you lie again?

Two estranged step-sisters re-unite on the night before their father’s funeral. Wine, grief, and a certain unexpected visitor propel them to confront the truth and lies buried in their past. What does it truly mean to be family? When is a mistake too big to confess? And if you had it all to do over, would you lie again?

The play runs at the Hudson Guild Theatre (441 W. 26th St.) on July 14th at 6:15PM, July 15th at 6:15PM, and July 17th at 8:30 PM.

ABOUT THE PLAYWRIGHT
Mary DeCarlo is an up-and-coming playwright living in NYC. Her plays have had readings and productions in Philadelphia, NYC, London, England, and Heidelberg,Germany. She has an MA in Text and Performance from the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art and Birkbeck University of London and has studied playwriting in NY at Primary Stages ESPA. This campaign will help to fund her production of The Expulsion at the Thespis Festival in NYC this July in collaboration with director Rachel Levens. 

WHAT WE NEED

By funding this campaign you are supporting the creation of live theatre, new writing, and a powerful playwright/director collaboration between two women. We are hoping to raise $1200 to help cover the costs of production! Your thoughtful contribution will help us to cover production expenses, such as:
- Sound Design
- Lighting Design
- Posters and advertising materials
- Payment for our brilliant creative team
- Rehearsal Space

WHAT YOU GET

Handwritten creations made just for you. Different levels of giving will bring you different types of mail.
- A digital smattering of love: a thank you full of compliments and praise on whichever social media platform (or private email address!) you prefer
- A haiku mailed to your home along with a postcard image of the show
- A love and friendship letter written to you (2 page minimum, oozing with my affection for you!) along with a postcard image of the show
- A short scene written with YOU as the star along with a postcard image of the show 
- A short story with YOU as the hero along with a postcard image of the show 

I am thrilled to have the opportunity to bring The Expulsion to an audience in New York City. This play began as an idea that creeped into my head three years ago when I was studying writing in London and has grown through many drafts to what I am presenting today. I am honored to be able to further develop this piece with my incredible director and creative actors. I hope the questions this play raises will speak to my audience and push them to question the ways they communicate with those closest to them. Producing my own writing is a scary endeavor, but with your help and the collaboration of my cast and crew I am confident that we can create a memorable and thought-provoking production!


Other Ways You Can Help

- Share our campaign through social media or email with your friends!
- If you are living in NYC or have friends who are, please come out to our show this July! Tickets can be purchased at http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2549698
