story:
Campaign Over View:


Out-of-the-Box, and outdoors, Sonoma County's unique Shakespeare In The Cannery is revving up for it's 3rd Season and needs your financial Support. Thousands of patrons have been enjoying fun with friends and family in a setting that is comfortable, playful, and entertaining.

Funded by local individuals and businesses, Shakespeare In The Cannery depends on Grass Roots Support to make operating costs. We need a few of your dollars to make it happen again this year.


Campaign Pitch:



Who We Are

Shakespeare In The Cannery is a non-profit theater company in Santa Rosa, CA. We are entering our 3rd season of plays by William Shakespeare in a festive outdoor picnic setting. We have reclaimed a large piece of derelict land in the heart of our city, and repurposed it into a dynamic summer theater. In cooperation with the City of Santa Rosa we offer patrons a safe, fun place to play for the entire family.


“… a truly unique experience in the City of Santa Rosa.”

- Mayor of Santa Rosa

Our theater is unpretentious, super relaxed, and we offer “bring your own recliner and blanket” seating, Patrons enjoy the show with picnic ‘n drinks much more like it was in Shakespeare’s own day. This year marks the addition of a new play written especially for our company by playwright David Beckman. This new comedy along with Shakespeare’s Macbeth will be our 2016 season offering.


We are asking for a Donation

Please consider making a contribution in whatever amount you can, to help us raise our indiegogo budget of $10,000. Your donation will be added to the contributions of other local individuals and businesses including, Friedman Bothers, Beyers Costin Simon Attorneys, City of Santa Rosa, Wright Brothers Construction, and Oliver’s Markets, and Willow Creek Financial and Ygrene.


Critics Have Praised Our Productions

“... smart, fast, and full of fun.”

- David Templeton, North Bay Stage and Screen


We have entertained over 3,00 fun seeking folks so far, and attendance at Shakespeare in the Cannery grows each year. The word is getting out and …

it’s“Happening”!


Check out our full website at: shakespeareinthecannery.com

Your Donation will have a big effect and help pay for:


Cast & Crew

City Permits and Licenses Sound & Lighting Acquisitions Set Building

Costumes

Audience Conveniences and Facilities

For the past 3 years, theatergoers like your self have been contributing small and large amounts to Shakespeare in the Cannery. Along with friends and members of the community, all together we make great theater possible. Help support the Arts, with a donation now and then come and enjoy the show.


As Shakespeare himself said over 400 years ago "The Play's the Thing"

Thank You for your Support!

story:
Short Summary

The Unfortunates - Solo Chicago Theatre

Help us produce this haunting, one-woman show.  Based on a true story The Unfortunates is set in Victorian London, and follows Mary-Jane Kelly, a down on her luck “unfortunate.”  One night, she encounters a stranger alone in her local tavern.  Will this mysterious gentleman buy her safety for the night or turn out to be Jack the Ripper?

This stunning tour-de-force stars Gail Rastorfer with direction by Kurt Johns. The Unfortunates promises to tell a chilling and unexpectedly humorous story.  Help us tell that story.

SoloChicago Theatre Company

Founded by Chicago theatre veteran Ronald Keaton in 2014, SoloChicago is creating a home for solo performance artists.  Our mission is to develop, encourage, and celebrate solo theatrical performance and work that embodies the spirit of the individual artist.  We have thought long and hard about the easy path of becoming an “old white guys” club or the Churchill group. But we seek a path of balance...to tell stories that need to be heard by the people who need to tell them. We aspire to create, at the highest professional level, a body of work that is worthy of national recognition and the pride that we have in Chicago Style Theatre.  

SoloChicago’s inaugural production Churchill was created and performed by founder Ronald Keaton under the direction of Artistic Director Kurt Johns.  It ran at the Greenhouse Theatre Center for multiple extensions and earned Mr. Keaton a Joseph Jefferson award for excellence in Chicago theatre.  CHURCHILL subsequently opened a successful Off-Broadway run  at the Shubert-Owned New World Stages and is now seeking bookings across the US.

Even though we enjoyed artistic success with Churchill, SoloChicago came out of that experience with not enough money to produce our next endeavor. So in order to reach our goals artistically, we continue to work towards our financial goals to keep producing quality solo theatre. We need your support to make The Unfortunates a success.

SoloChicago Theatre Company is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of SoloChicago Theatre Company must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

The Play.

London, November 1888.  Mary Jane Kelly is out tonight on Dorset Street in Whitechapel.  She is an “unfortunate.”  She needs money and to get out of the cold.  In the shadows, one of the world’s most notorious murderers waits.   

The captivating script, written by Aoise Stratford, is based on the true story of Mary Jane Kelly, Jack the Ripper's last proven victim. The Unfortunates stars Gail Rastorfer as Mary and is directed by SCT Artistic Director Kurt Johns. It has been called “haunting…engrossing” by The New York Times.  TimeOut New York gave it 4 stars, saying, "it achieves a rare combination of pathos and humor, breathing fresh life into women we might have otherwise think of only as long-dead prey.”

The Unfortunates by Aoise Stratford

Playing at Theater Wit, 1229 W Belmont, Chicago
June 17 – July 10 (Opening Night is June 20).

Tickets (starting at $38 and subject to change) can be purchased online at www.theaterwit.org or by phone at 773-975-8150.

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need

Your support is vital to our storytelling – from rights, costumes and theatre rental, to paying the artists and marketing the show - producing theatre is costly. As a new theatre company, your contributions, no matter the size, mean so much to us.  We invite you to helps us tell our stories and nurture solo theatre artists.  Please consider donating today – your contributions will be used for things like:

·  Marketing:  posters, postcards, and online content
·  Media:  photography, video, and other content
·  Press & Publicity
·  Production:  lighting, sound, costuming, props, artist fees 

What You Get

Charitable contributions are crucial to our mission of producing solo work of the highest professional level. Without you, we would not exist. Please consider making a secure, tax-deductible donation to SoloChicago today! With your generous gift, you can partner with us to produce compelling and thought provoking solo work.

Besides our invitation to join us on this adventure, we want to show you how important you are to us. Ticket sales account for only a small portion of our operating expenses and the generosity of our supporters will help us to continue. Every supporter will receive our heartfelt thanks, along with a variety of perks at each level of giving, including: 

·  SoloChicago Theatre merchandise
·  Autographed production playbill or poster
·  Free tickets to the show
·  And more!

The Impact

Why support solo performance? As theatre artists, we are storytellers, and we are uniquely challenged to weave stories using just one voice and just one body. The solo process is full of challenges and opportunity, and offers a truly engaging and intimate theatre experience unlike any other.   

Like any production, there are risks and challenges to overcome.  As a non-profit organization with 501(c)(3) status in process, our biggest challenge is financial.  ticket sales alone are not enough to support the work.  That’s where you come in.  Please consider making a donation, made tax-deductible through our affiliation with Fractured Atlas.  Please help us continue telling our stories.

   

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you are not able to contribute financially, and that’s okay too!  There are many ways you can help support The Unfortunates and SoloChicago Theatre:

·  Share on social media!  It’s that simple – share our campaign and our show information with your friends and family

·  Buy a ticket & join us in the audience!

·  Volunteer…we can always use good people to help with production, administration, marketing, or box office support.

·  Give us your email…let us keep you in the loop on upcoming projects

·  Donate things – products or services that help us tell our story.  If you are a business – sponsor us for things like graphic design and printing, or donate props or costuming. 

The possibilities are endless. We thank you for your continued in support of SoloChicago Theatre. We are grateful to continue sharing our stories.

In the shadows, one of the world’s most notorious murderers waits.   
The captivating script, written by Aoise Stratford, is
based on the true story of Mary Jane Kelly, Jack the Ripper's last proven victim. The Unfortunates stars Gail Rastorfer as Mary and is directed by SCT Artistic Director Kurt Johns. It has been called “haunting…engrossing” by The New
York Times.  TimeOut New York gave it 4
stars, saying, "it achieves a rare combination of pathos and humor,
breathing fresh life into women we might have otherwise think of only as
long-dead prey.”
The Unfortunates by Aoise Stratford
Playing at Theater Wit, 1229 W
Belmont, Chicago
June 17 – July 10 (Opening Night is June 20).
Tickets (starting at $38 and subject to
change) can be purchased online at www.theaterwit.org or by phone at 773-975-8150.
   What We Need & What You Get 

What We Need
Your support is vital to our storytelling – from rights,
costumes and theatre rental, to paying the artists and marketing the show -
producing theatre is costly. As a new theatre company, your contributions, no
matter the size, mean so much to us.  We
invite you to helps us tell our stories and nurture solo theatre artists.  Please consider donating today – your
contributions will be used for things like:
· 
Marketing:  posters,
postcards, and online content· 
Media:  photography,
video, and other content· 
Press & Publicity· 
Production:  lighting,
sound, costuming, props, artist fees What You Get
Charitable
contributions are crucial to our mission of producing solo work of the highest
professional level. Without you, we would not exist. Please consider making a
secure, tax-deductible donation to SoloChicago today! With your generous gift,
you can partner with us to produce compelling and thought provoking solo work.
Besides our invitation to join us on
this adventure, we want to show you how important you are to us. Ticket sales
account for only a small portion of our operating expenses and the generosity
of our supporters will help us to continue. Every supporter will receive
our heartfelt thanks, along with a variety of perks at each level of giving, including:  
· 
SoloChicago Theatre merchandise· 
Autographed production playbill or poster· 
Free tickets to the show· 
And more!
The Impact
Why support solo performance? As theatre artists, we are
storytellers, and we are uniquely challenged to weave stories using just one
voice and just one body. The solo process is full of challenges and opportunity,
and offers a truly engaging and intimate theatre experience unlike any
other.   
Like any production, there are risks and challenges to
overcome.  As a non-profit organization
with 501(c)(3) status in process, our biggest challenge is financial.  ticket sales alone are not enough to support
the work.  That’s where you come in.  Please consider making a donation, made
tax-deductible through our affiliation with Fractured Atlas.  Please help us continue telling our stories.
     Other Ways You Can Help 

We understand if you are not able to contribute financially, and
that’s okay too!  There are many ways you
can help support The Unfortunates and
SoloChicago Theatre:
·  Share on social media!  It’s that simple – share our campaign and our
show information with your friends and family 
·  Buy a ticket & join us in the
audience! 
·  Volunteer…we can always use good
people to help with production, administration, marketing, or box office
support. 
·  Give us your email…let us keep you in
the loop on upcoming projects
·  Donate things – products or services
that help us tell our story.  If you are
a business – sponsor us for things like graphic design and printing, or donate
props or costuming.  

The possibilities are endless. We thank you for your continued in
support of SoloChicago Theatre. We are grateful to continue sharing our stories.

story:
A Short Summary

We're a new company that's excited to produce classic theatre with young, fresh voices and performers. You need reasons?

  • This is our first production, and we're ready to hit the road running.
  • We came together as a collective to produce our own work: as young artists, we can't wait around for work to come to us!
  • Supporting young actors in the beginning of their careers is an invaluable cultural investment for Vancouver and beyond.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's our break down for folks:

  • Location rental costs are where the majority of funding will go.
  • Depending on what you donate, you can receive publicity for the company you represent, tickets to our shows and mentions before every performance of you company name.
  • If we have profit after our run, it will be divided between our cast and crew as this is a profit share arrangement.

The Impact

We believe in young artists being compensated for their work and to do this, we need your support.

  • Theatre is a vital asset to arts and culture in this city and projects like ours ensure a diversity of voices and influences across Vancouver.
  • Members of our production team have produced other sold out performances in Vancouver.
  • We are all at the beginning of our careers and believe in the value of our work.

Risks & Challenges We Face

We could, because this production is unsupported by a major donor, lose money on our labour of love. We are willing to do this for our art.

However, we think with solid publicity and your support, we can come out of the production with cast and crew earning something from their time and talent.

  • We're tenacious!
  • Through fundraising and sponsors, we know we can stay in the black and also make theatre worth seeing again and again.

Other Ways You Can Help Us Out

If you can't contribute directly, support us by sharing our event, telling your friends and more than anything else, come see our production!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
My name is Karen Thomas

I Karen Thomas is the sole owner of my play titled, “Loving a Married Man.”

My is to have my play performed at the 4000 seat Saenger Theater in New Orleans first then sprout out to other cities and theaters in America and abroad.

My Product

 It is a two-hour play.

Statistics show that approximately 35.9 million of the population visit theaters each year. The age proximity is 18 to 39, of which 51 % of the population that attends theater is female, while 49 % is male, with a median income level of 53,889, and a theater revenue of 1373.25 million. 

Pricing Strategy: My plan is to have my first production at the Saenger Theater in New Orleans, LA. The Saenger Theater consist of 4000 seats. The first ten rows of orchestra seats (total 750) selling at $40 each (with approximately 25 seats per row, per three sections) has an earning potential of $30,000 and 96 balcony seats selling at $50 per seat has an income potential of $4,800, with the remaining 3,154 seats selling at $25 each could gross $78,850 for a total earning potential of $113, 650.00 for my first night’s production and a 7-day outlook is $795,550.

The Competitors: My play is original, erotic, humorous, and has drama and suspense. There is no other play out there like mine.

Company Management Structure: I K. Thomas will oversee the entire play with the assistance of a director and producer.

Organizational Timeline: Once I receive enough funds I will immediately begin interviewing actors and acquiring a venue and insurance. My goal is to start rehearsal by mid-June of 2017 and the play will be ready for the public’s view in September.

Advertising: Advertising will begin three months before actual production date. With radio reaching 93% of the population I will advertise on the Steve Harvey morning show three months in advance (to broadcast twice a week during mornings commute) before the actual play date. Then three weeks before the play date, I will purchase the Steve Harvey morning show (radio) crew to announce once per day about ticket sales and venue, all done on morning commutes. Rent billboards and place a newspaper ad one week before curtains.  I will post ads on Facebook, Twitter, Myspace, LinkedIn, etc. for social media. I will have an associate to hand out flyers two weeks before curtains.

Staffing: Myself, producer, director, actors and actresses, set designer, light and sound technicians, stage hands, and costume help.

story:
My name is Kelly Bartnik and I’m NY-based choreographer and performer with a recent background in the realm of Immersive Theatre.  I am in the midst of developing a new long-term work entitled Here.     The premise is that Here will run in an episodic format, similar to a television series but live performance, so that audiences can witness the series unfold over time.  Each new episode expands on the previously crafted narrative so there is an ever expanding storyline with new characters and the continuation of existing characters’ trajectories over time.   We are currently developing Episode 1, which we’re calling our Pilot episode.

Our narrative, which we are devising from scratch with generous contributions from the performers, introduces our first characters, played by Donna Costello, and Zach Martens .     We are devising the Pilot in a space beautifully designed and crafted by Wildrence, LLC  called The Mist.  I am heading up the Choreography and Directing department, with Art Direction by Tori Sparks.   

The purpose of this campaign is to help fund the initial launch of the Pilot Episode.    Eventually we hope this series will support itself, but in the meantime we are asking for contributions to help get our first Episode produced.   I’ve set an initial funding goal of $10,000.   The components of this budget include:

  • Performers Rehearsal and Performance Pay
  • Space Rental
  • Videography and Editing
  • Music Rights
  • Costumes and Props
  • Choreography and Direction
  • Website Design and Marketing

Eventually we will add a Dramaturge, Sound Designer, and Costume Designer to our team as well.   Should we not reach our full goal of $10,000, any funds raised will be distributed to the performers, cinematographer, and space rental for time and space already put forth and used in the last two months.

The final major element of this project is that we will be highly documenting everything from creation so that when the project is over, we will compile a physical, graphic novel style representation of the story that we’ve created.   This element is in collaboration with photographer and cinematographer Tyler Sparks.

If you are unable to donate at this time but would still like to support the project, please share the campaign on social media or forward to your friends and family.   Please also sign up on our mailing list at www.hereny.com for future updates on the progress of this creation.   Any exposure is greatly appreciated and we hope you can help us make this project a reality.

story:
Short Summary

We are an emerging Art Collective hailing from The Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program.

A handful of young and hungry artistic people.

Trying to integrate themselves into the Minneapolis community to provide hands on theatrical experiences that surprise and delight.

We hope to emerge by creating an immersive production of Martin McDonaugh's A Behanding in Spokane, however money needed for rights to perform and create does not grow on trees for us, which is where we need a hand!

You can help us set up shop!

 Expect a celebration on Valentines Day!


What's A Behanding in Spokane? 

A play about passion, pursuit, confusion and missing hands. Martin Mcdonagh's dark comedy (and one of his only American plays) tells the story of four characters in a hotel room encountering each other under highly unusual circumstances concerning a mummy, a Yoda t-shirt, boredom, and one man's undying quest to find his missing hand. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our pockets are those of students. Our ambitions are of giants. Help us raise money to attain the rights to do this play and the results will be an incredible party with fried chicken, music, entertainment, and a performance that we want you to be a part of. Trust us, you will be. 


Anything and everything helps! Our rehearsal space is open to all who want to join in on the fun (we mean it!).

Trust us, you will be.

story:
WHO ARE YOU GUYS?

Nerdaissance is a Grand Rapids-based comedy and entertainment group, with a focus on pop culture and geekery. Simply put, we're the people you put in lockers in high school, but we grew a sense of humor about it. We're built entirely of local comedians, and we want to make comedy even bigger and more accessible in GR. You can see an entire show for free, just by clicking here, and you can follow us on Facebook for future content, too.

SO WHY SHOULD YOU GET MY MONEY?

Do you like laughing? Perhaps more than once per year? Then let us turn your hard earned dollars into hearty chuckles! Meeting our fundraising goal will allow us to afford theater space, promotion, and printing for an entire season of shows. We're looking at doing three types of shows in 2016:

-FANFICTION SHOWS: Our classic fan favorite. We put endless thought and creativity into lampooning, skewering, and otherwise ruining your favorite things, in ways you never knew you wanted, but you definitely do.

-FANTASY/SCI-FI SHOWS: Original stories with a focus on comedy! We build wonderful little universes and work with new concepts, crafting a unique base for innovative storytelling, and then we throw it all away on dick jokes. The highest quality dick jokes.

-THEME SHOWS: We select a theme for each of our stories to follow. We don't mean themes like “ill-fated romances” or “the hero's journey”. Themes like “Nicholas Cage”. Do you want a comedy show about Nic Cage? Of course you do. Why would we even have to ask.

BUT WHAT DO I GET?

Dazzling array of shows not enough for you? It's cool, it's cool, we get it. You want something for your money. Something real, something tangible. Well, let us tell you something, buddy: have we got the rewards for you. Throw us a little bit of cash, and you can get...

$10: A neato Nerdaissance sticker! Put it anywhere that you want people to know you're cool. We hear that visibly supporting independent artists can increase your opportunity for sexual encounters by 3000 percent.

$20: Two free tickets to a Nerdaissance show of your choosing, and a shout-out at the show you attend, so that everyone present can hear just how kind and giving and generous you are, you bighearted so-and-so. Impress your date! You might get to 2nd!

$50: A season pass to every Nerdaissance show in 2016! Never miss a joke or a chance to stare at our stunningly passable cast, AND you get a show for free, you money-smart dog!

$75: We write YOU into one of OUR stories, and a free ticket to the show! You'll be famous and considered hilarious without ever having to tell a funny joke. Just like Dane Cook!

$150: A custom story and ticket to its show! Want to hear a tale about aliens getting high? Do you want to know how hilariously gross it would be if She-Ra and Snarf banged? The answer is “very”, but we can tell you exactly how if you donate enough money to make it happen!


WHAT IF YOU GET TOO MUCH MONEY?

Don't be silly. This is America. There is no such thing.

However, if we meet our main goal, we've certainly got plans to go even further!

$4000: Not only can we fund a full season of Nerdaissance shows, we can also build a studio! Building a studio will allow us to make even more content all year round, and make it all available online, so you can laugh at us any time you like! Our families already do!

$10,000: This is the big leagues. A full season of shows, a new studio, AND all new equipment! With your generous help, we can get high quality equipment, making production even easier, and eliminating all possibility of sounding like we shout jokes in a wind tunnel.


ARE YOU DONE TALKING YET?

Yes! Just remember, every little bit helps, and if you can't donate, spread the word! Every time you share our campaign, our Facebook, or our YouTube channel with someone, it adds 4.2 seconds to each Nerdaissance member's lifespan and briefly warms our cold, charred little hearts.


92.4% of all unfunded comedy troupes remain stuck in sitcom poses. Won't you please help?

story:
Short Summary

The Players' Society (that's us!) is a fiercely independent theater club at Chapman University. Every aspect of TPS' operation is run entirely by students - from production to direction to performance - and it's all run on a limited budget. Past highlights include our annual Rocky Horror Picture Show shadow cast, William Shakespeare's Land of the Dead (2013), Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog (2014), Almost, Maine (2014), The Room (2015), The Complete Works of William Shakespeare, Abridged (2015), and A Brain, An Athlete, A Basket Case, A Princess, and A Criminal (2016). TPS will also be producing a full-scale production of High School Musical On Stage in April of 2016. 

Our upcoming production is Rhinoceros, written by French playwright Eugene Ionesco in 1959, is an absurdist comedy about a small provincial town in France in which many of its residents turn into rhinoceroses, without any explanation. The show focuses on Berenger, a drunk and slovenly bachelor who grows increasingly afraid of and paranoid towards the encroaching rhinoceros threat. 

What We Need & What You Get

TPS has five productions under way this school year. In the past, we've rarely done more than two. While most productions are funded by a combination of ticket sales, donations, and assistance from Chapman's Student Government Association, the increase in productivity, combined with the growing scale of TPS productions, creates a need for additional funding.  We are asking for $500 from the community, which will go towards the purchase of makeup and prosthetic equipment, set building, costumes, and the purchase of a new, TPS-owned PA system, which will be used in future TPS productions as well as this one.

TPS prides itself on the personal touch that we put on our productions, and our perks include free admission to the show itself and several opportunities to get to know the cast and crew personally. We value collaboration over nearly everything else, and your contribution makes you a part of the family.

The Impact

Donating to our campaign allows you to show your support for independent student artists. Every member of our team is doing this in their own spare time while also attending college full-time, and Rhinoceros will be fully independently financed. Despite the obstacles of time that we face, TPS has successfully produced five productions in the last twelve months (nine months if you skip Chapman's summer vacation), and has established itself  as a place for student artists to expand their horizons and find lifelong collaborators and friends. 

Risks & Challenges

Our primary challenges lie in our lack of available funding and technology, and your contributions will help to alleviate this challenge. We also lack consistent rehearsal spaces, as well as a traditional theater performance space. However, TPS shows have almost always faced these exact challenges, and we are always able to find success despite them and adapt to our surroundings. We regularly perform in classrooms without additional sound or lighting, and though this production will be a step forward technologically for TPS, we are still required to perform in less than ideal conditions. But, as they say, the show must go on, and go on it will!

Cast & Crew

BERENGER: Cecilia Soghikian, Freshman
JEAN: Mitchell Pratt, Junior, B.F.A. Film Production - Directing
DAISY: Kenzee Donham, Junior, B.F.A. Theatre Performance
DUDARD: Drew Petriello, Senior, B.F.A. Theatre Performance
BOTARD: Cameron Barrett Stewart, Junior, B.A. Communication Studies
LOGICIAN: Skye Braband, Sophomore, B.F.A. Television Writing and Production
LOGICIAN: Tyler Wincott, Freshman, B.F.A  Theatre Performance
WAITRESS: Julie Brown, Junior, B.F.A. Television and Broadcast Journalism
HOUSEWIFE: Gabriella Bruno, Sophomore, B.S. Health Sciences
OLD GENTLEMAN: Blake Garnsey, Junior, B.F.A Digital Arts
MRS. BOEUF: Atty McLellan, Sophomore
MR. PAPILLON: Roman Marotte, Post-Graduate, M.A.T. Secondary Education
GROCER: Tyler Corbisez, Senior, B.A. Psychology
GROCER: William Ochoa, Sophomore
CAFE PROPRIETOR: Jillian Strong, Senior, B.A. Psychology
CAFE PROPRIETOR: Ellen Webre, Senior, B.A. Screenwriting
FIREMAN: Evan McConaughy, Junior, B.A. Screenwriting

story_txt:
Short Summary The Players' Society (that's us!) is a fiercely independent theater club at Chapman University. Every aspect of TPS' operation is run entirely by students - from production to direction to performance - and it's all run on a limited budget. Past highlights include our annual Rocky Horror Picture Show shadow cast, William Shakespeare's Land of the Dead (2013), Dr. Horrible's Sing-Along Blog (2014), Almost, Maine (2014), The Room (2015), The Complete Works of William Shakespeare, Abridged (2015), and A Brain, An Athlete, A Basket Case, A Princess, and A Criminal (2016). TPS will also be producing a full-scale production of High School Musical On Stage in April of 2016. Our upcoming production is Rhinoceros, written by French playwright Eugene Ionesco in 1959, is an absurdist comedy about a small provincial town in France in which many of its residents turn into rhinoceroses, without any explanation. The show focuses on Berenger, a drunk and slovenly bachelor who grows increasingly afraid of and paranoid towards the encroaching rhinoceros threat.    What We Need & What You Get TPS has five productions under way this school year. In the past, we've rarely done more than two. While most productions are funded by a combination of ticket sales, donations, and assistance from Chapman's Student Government Association, the increase in productivity, combined with the growing scale of TPS productions, creates a need for additional funding.  We are asking for $500 from the community, which will go towards the purchase of makeup and prosthetic equipment, set building, costumes, and the purchase of a new, TPS-owned PA system, which will be used in future TPS productions as well as this one.
TPS prides itself on the personal touch that we put on our productions, and our perks include free admission to the show itself and several opportunities to get to know the cast and crew personally. We value collaboration over nearly everything else, and your contribution makes you a part of the family. 
The Impact
 Donating to our campaign allows you to show your support for independent student artists. Every member of our team is doing this in their own spare time while also attending college full-time, and Rhinoceros will be fully independently financed. Despite the obstacles of time that we face, TPS has successfully produced five productions in the last twelve months (nine months if you skip Chapman's summer vacation), and has established itself  as a place for student artists to expand their horizons and find lifelong collaborators and friends. 
Risks & Challenges
  Our primary challenges lie in our lack of available funding and technology, and your contributions will help to alleviate this challenge. We also lack consistent rehearsal spaces, as well as a traditional theater performance space. However, TPS shows have almost always faced these exact challenges, and we are always able to find success despite them and adapt to our surroundings. We regularly perform in classrooms without additional sound or lighting, and though this production will be a step forward technologically for TPS, we are still required to perform in less than ideal conditions. But, as they say, the show must go on, and go on it will!   Cast & Crew

story:
WHAT'S IT ALL ABOUT?

CHERCHEZ LA FEMME is a musical extravaganza that tells the story of one man's loss and another man's gain and the powerful women who make it all possible. It explores dark themes (abandonment, sibling rivalry, unrequited love) and light themes (sexual healing, the pursuit of happiness,  the smell of success) but never without inviting you to shake your head and tap your toes to the infectious neo-urban-jungle grooves. The play is set in New York City and the Caribbean in the 1980's. It's reckless. It's rhythmic. It's romantic. 

BACK TO THE FUTURE

30 years ago Vivien Goldman interviewed me in London for a magazine called NME. My alter ego, KID CREOLE, had just released an album entitled TROPICAL GANGSTERS on the Island Records label. It was a hit. The interview lasted 3 hours and 35 minutes. A friendship was formed. 7 years ago Vivien visited me in my home in the idyllic Swedish countryside. We joked about writing a musical. The joke became a reality. The first draft of the play was written in 6 days. At first it was called I'M A WONDERFUL THING, BABY. 


1 year ago Vivien met an actor named Julius Hollingsworth. She spoke to him about the musical. Julius said "Hey, I have done some work with the La Mama group in downtown Manhattan. Perhaps they would be interested in this!" Behold! Fate rears its magnificent head out of the wilderness. In the Spring of last year, a staged reading of that play (in its 7th re-write) was presented at the LaMama rehearsal space. It was now called CHERCHEZ LA FEMME. The room was packed with fans of KID CREOLE AND THE COCONUTS and DR BUZZARD'S ORIGINAL SAVANNAH BAND and with music lovers of all ages.

The staged readings were very successful. They led directly to yet another re-write and an invitation to entertain the masses at the Ellen Stewart Theatre! Pow! A dream deferred becomes a dream deferred no longer. 

HERE AND NOW

We are now in the process of raising funds to present CHERCHEZ LA FEMME for a limited run  (May 20th - June 12th, 2016) at the La Mama theatre in downtown Manhattan. We have managed to secure some outside funding which is wonderful but if we raise another 16,000 dollars we can have 15 cast members and some real sets and some dynamic lighting and some remarkable choreography. Yes, I am a fan of Cecil B. DeMille and Busby Berkley! 


THE A TEAM

Once we have secured our goal (hopefully) we will begin our extensive audition process and we will keep you involved every step of the way. 

We are indeed lucky to have a commitment from the La Mama Theatre Company to showcase the musical in the Spring. This is fortune personified. But even though the La Mama Foundation is contributing a whole lot of dough and rehearsal space and manpower it's just not enough to complete the giant picture. You see, mounting a musical is a huge, expensive undertaking. We still need to raise funds to assemble the Dream Team: the right director and stage manager and lighting and set designers and musical director and vocal coach and choreographer and musicians and crew members …. etc., etc., etc. So, the ball is now in the court of our dedicated fans, followers and believers! That's you.

With your help we can achieve the impossible dream. It's only an arm's length away. Thank you.

What happens after this limited run? Well ... we bring the wacky ways of CHERCHEZ LA FEMME to the rest of the world, of course.

Why not?

Excelsior,

August Darnell aka KID CREOLE

"We may be through with the past but the past isn't through with us."

One of a kind, indeed.

Learning my craft; thanks Gilbert, thanks Sullivan.

 Coast to coast.

 Paradise lost? Paradise regained!


Man's best friend!

story:
Our Story

I recently did some work with this studio that was such an integral part in my development as a professional hip hop dancer. I was shocked and heartbroken to hear that it was on the brink of closure. After talking with the director, I quickly realized where some of the problems were, and I know a company that could help fix these problems. I have some experience in the dance community, and if there is anything I know, its that we dancers have each others backs! Lets save this studio and their programs!

The Impact

Dance has changed and saved so many lives. For me, without dance I would be lost in gangs and I would have no focus or discipline. Personally dance saved my life. This studio has done this for so many people over the last 6 years. The dedication to its students has helped pushed those with the talent, to succeed and exceed expectations. Dance is also a way for some of these students to further their education into higher learning. The positive outcomes from dance are infinite!


What We Need & What You Get

Some of the problems stem from lack of marketing materials and distribution of materials. Enrollments are steady, but increasing costs are negating the steady enrollment rate. The studio needs a new growth of enrollment in order to continue to succeed and excel. The first step in doing this is upgrading the website. Designing new marketing materials, postcards, brochures, and to begin an advertising campaign. But money is short, so funding such a campaign is impossible without YOU!


This is just the first step. There is so much more that needs to be done as well. Such as minor re-modelling, upgrading equipment, and creating new streams of revenue for this studio. Every dime donated will be used to further the growth of this project. Each thing that needs to be done is a single step. But all it took was one small step for man-kind to change the world!

Other Ways You Can Help

Follow @prodigydance on twitter or email prodigydancefestival@gmail.com to see how you can help besides donating!

story:
(English below)

 

NOTICIAS DEL SILENCIO. EL MONO

Espectáculo multidisciplinar: teatro-danza-música experimental (coral a capella).

 

INTEGRANTES:
Dramaturgia y dirección escénica: Eva Guillamón
Música y dirección musical: Sonia Megías

-Hemisferio (coro) izquierdo:
*Sopranos: Sonia Megías, Maite Rodríguez
*Contralto: Reyes Arranz
*Tenora: Inés G. Viana

-Hemisferio (coro) derecho:
*Soprano: Tania Arbizu
*Contralto: Marta Vicent
*Tenoras: Eva Guillamón, Julia Vicario

 -Bailarina:
*Elena Murcia

SUPLENTES: Raquel Barrio, Ingrid Hernández, Carmen Diéguez

 

DECLARACIÓN: El arte desarrolla el pensamiento abstracto. El arte no tiene precio, algo muy raro hoy en día, donde todo es factible de ser comprado. Pero hay otras caras de la moneda, otras capas ocultas en el establishment cotidiano. ¿Cuántas vidas caben en un solo nombre, en un solo ser? El arte es la llave que abre las puertas bloqueadas por el miedo. El miedo a ser sólo yo. El arte dibuja nuevas fronteras constantemente; un artista es alguien que acepta el reto de ampliar los límites de la posibilidad. Creemos en el teatro, sobre todo en el teatro, como una herramienta para despertar. Una herramienta accesible que muestra abiertamente su misterio. En el escenario no hay magia, sino error, la posibilidad de fracasar; es decir: vida. Este trabajo, 'El mono', es un intento de comprender más capas de vida; y esperamos que esta reflexión sea significativa para el público que nos acompañe en esta ruta sin fin.
 

HISTORIA DE LA PIEZA: 'Noticias de silencio. El Mono' comienza con un relato que Eva Guillamón escribió en Dharamsala (India) en junio de 2010, tras colaborar con algunas compañías de teatro locales. En 2011 la obra resultó finalista en el Festival de Ópera Contemporánea de Houston. En abril de 2012 se estrenó en Nueva York, en colaboración con la Universidad de Nueva York.


SINOPSIS: Un héroe trágico contemporáneo se enfrenta a una rutina diaria en lo que terminará siendo su última noche. Él no habla, sólo se mueve al ritmo de su pensamiento. La palabra recae en los dos coros que dan voz a su cerebro, y realizan las actividades típicas de cada hemisferio, derecho e izquierdo respectivamente. El protagonista de 'El Mono' esta perdido en un mundo sordo, y ha renunciado a la palabra como forma de acción, con la esperanza inconsciente de alcanzar así el punto de la claridad necesaria para encontrar una pequeña grieta en una realidad tan hostil como insoportable.


DESCRIPCIÓN: 'El Mono' es una combinación de música experimental y danza contemporánea en una revisión de la tragedia griega, con la intención de reflexionar sobre el concepto "ciudad" ("Ciudad: es el nombre dado a una enfermedad nerviosa muy grave", dijo el sociólogo argentino Ezequiel Martínez Estrada). Si en la tragedia griega el concepto 'polis' era inevitable para comprender al héroe clásico, hoy la ciudad es también esencial para el estudio de las características del ser humano contemporáneo: alguien con la incesante necesidad de mantener el obligado requisito que satisfaga las demandas de una sociedad que lo contiene y limita. 'El Mono' es la primera parte de la trilogía 'Noticias de silencio', un acercamiento a la locura diferentes estadios: parte uno ('El mono'), locura individual; parte dos, asunción de la locura colectiva; parte tres, la locura colectiva llevada al exceso en el marco de la estructura social.

 

¿EN QUÉ SE GASTARÁ EL DINERO?:

AltoFest es uno de los festivales de artes escénicas y performances más interesantes de Europa. En su III edición 'Noticias del silencio. El mono' ha sido una de las doce obras seleccionadas, así que allí nos vamos del 29 de junio al 7 de julio:

-Billetes de avión de Madrid a Nápoles
-Vestuario y escenografía

 

--------------------------

 

NOTICIAS DEL SILENCIO. EL MONO (NEWS FROM SILENCE. THE MONKEY)

Multidisciplinary Performance: theater-dancing-experimental music (choral a capella).

 

CAST:
Playwright and direction: Eva Guillamón
Composer and musical direction: Sonia Megías

-Left hemisphere (choir):
*Sopranos: Sonia Megías, Maite Rodríguez
*Alto: Reyes Arranz
*Tenor: Inés G. Viana

-Right hemisphere (choir):
*Soprano: Tania Arbizu
*Alto: Marta Vicent
*Tenors: Eva Guillamón, Julia Vicario

 -Dancer:
*Elena Murcia

 SUBSTITUTES: Raquel Barrio, Ingrid Hernández, Carmen Diéguez.


STATEMENT: Art developpes the abstract thought. Art is priceless, something very weird nowadays, where everything is able to be got by money. But there are other faces in the coin, other hidden layers among the imposed establishment. How many lives fit in a single name, in a single being? Art is the key which opens the doors buried by fear. The fear of being just me, the infinite one. Art is drawing new borders constantly; an artist, somebody who accepts the challenge of widening the limits of the possibility. We believe in theater, especially in theater, as a tool to wake us up. A cheap tool which shows its mystery openly. On the stage there's no magic but the error, the possibility of failing. It means: life. Through our work, we try to understand what life is, what it can also be; and we hope this reflection will be meaningful for the audience who come with us in this never-ending route.

 

HISTORY OF THE PIECE: 'News from silence. The Monkey' begins with a short story by Eva Guillamón written in Dharamsala (India) in June 2010, where she collaborated with some indian theater companies. In 2011 the play reached the final in The Houston Contemporary Opera Festival. In April 2012 it was premiered in NY, in collaboration with the New York University.

 

SYNOPSIS: A contemporary tragic hero faces an apparently daily routine which will end up to be his last day. He does not speak, just move to the rhythm of his thought. The word rests in two choirs who give voice to his brain and do the typical activities of each hemisphere, right and left. The hero of 'The Monkey' is lost in a deaf world, and he has renounced the word as a way of action; hoping for the necessary point of clarity to find a tiny crack in a reality as hostile as unbearable.

 

DESCRIPTION: 'The Monkey' mixes thoroughly experimental music and contemporary dance in a review of the greek tragedy, to reflect on the concept 'city' ("City: it is the name given to a very serious nervous disorder", said the argentinian sociologist Ezequiel Martínez Estrada). If in the greek tragedy the concept 'polis' was inevitable to understand the classic hero, today the city is also essential to study the characteristics of the contemporary human being: someone with the relentless need to keep up the common requirement to meet the demands of a society which contains and constrains them. 'The Monkey' is the first part of the trilogy 'News from Silence', a rapprochement to madness in different stages: I, individual madness; II, collective madness; III: the current social structure.

 

WHAT DO WE NEED MONEY FOR?:

AltoFest is one of the more interesting Performing Art Festivals all around Europe. 'News from Silence. The Monkey' has been selected in its 3rd edition. And there we go from june 29th to july 3rd.

-Plane tickets from Madrid to Naples
-Wardrobe and stage design

A cheap tool which shows its mystery openly. On the stage there's no magic but the error, the possibility of failing. It means: life. Through our work, we try to understand what life is, what it can also be; and we hope this reflection will be meaningful for the audience who come with us in this never-ending route.
 
HISTORY OF THE PIECE: 'News from silence. The Monkey' begins with a short story by Eva Guillamón written in Dharamsala (India) in June 2010, where she collaborated with some indian theater companies. In 2011 the play reached the final in The Houston Contemporary Opera Festival. In April 2012 it was premiered in NY, in collaboration with the New York University.
 
SYNOPSIS: A contemporary tragic hero faces an apparently daily routine which will end up to be his last day. He does not speak, just move to the rhythm of his thought. The word rests in two choirs who give voice to his brain and do the typical activities of each hemisphere, right and left. The hero of 'The Monkey' is lost in a deaf world, and he has renounced the word as a way of action; hoping for the necessary point of clarity to find a tiny crack in a reality as hostile as unbearable.
 
DESCRIPTION: 'The Monkey' mixes thoroughly experimental music and contemporary dance in a review of the greek tragedy, to reflect on the concept 'city' ("City: it is the name given to a very serious nervous disorder", said the argentinian sociologist Ezequiel Martínez Estrada). If in the greek tragedy the concept 'polis' was inevitable to understand the classic hero, today the city is also essential to study the characteristics of the contemporary human being: someone with the relentless need to keep up the common requirement to meet the demands of a society which contains and constrains them. 'The Monkey' is the first part of the trilogy 'News from Silence', a rapprochement to madness in different stages: I, individual madness; II, collective madness; III: the current social structure.
 
WHAT DO WE NEED MONEY FOR?:
AltoFest is one of the more interesting Performing Art Festivals all around Europe. 'News from Silence. The Monkey' has been selected in its 3rd edition. And there we go from june 29th to july 3rd.
-Plane tickets from Madrid to Naples-Wardrobe and stage design

story:
For the past 20-or-so years I've put together an eight-play series called "Tales From the American Street" which deals with the American zeitgeist and the stories that lie underneath its cherished myths. Tales, in the form of full-length plays, that explore America's very particular issues of race and ethnicity, class and homelessness, war and culture. All have had staged readings around the New York area, with one - "The Carcass" - given full production in 2002-03 in Krakow, Poland (called "Padlina" in Polish) at the 200-seat STU Theatre, directed by Polish-American film-maker Hannah Sawka and ran for five sold-out performances before being forced to close by the then-Polish government for being "subversive". It's not, unless you call a play concerning race, class, war and homelessness during 1980's America subversive. It concerns a suburban White family who's brand-new shiny gold-car breaks down outside Yankee Stadium in the South Bronx and what happens to "it' - the car.

The other plays in the series are "Ba-Ba, the Car", about a boyhood friend, a Black male deaf-mute who thought he was an automobile; "The Stoop", based on the murder of a young Black male, Yusef Hawkins, by a group of Italian punks, its retaliation by a group of Black punks, and a subsequent redemption; "The Breadman", about a man giving away bread on a Manhattan street corner and its ramifications; "Indian", where an elderly couple find their long lost middle-aged son on a Manhattan street; "The Echo", based on the true story of a Poughkeepsie, New York school-teacher who cannibalized a student; "O Beautiful For Spacious Skies...", a tragic-farce conjured from my response to the debacle that was post-Hurricane Katrina; and "The Artist Confronts His Materials", the split between Art and art - as a painter (also) it could be thought of as my "manifesto" of sorts.

So, what am I trying to do here you may ask? Get to the point, right? I'm interested, no, more than interested, "rabid" about trying to get at least one of these plays finally produced in New York. There have been some close calls over the years, but the lament from most of the commercial theaters has been..."Great, powerful work, but I don't think this would put people in the seats." Granted, they are difficult themes and the plays themselves are edgy and perhaps controversial, but so what? I've always thought of theater as more than just entertainment, but as a venue to meander through our cultural landscape. So...I'm determined to get them out there to theater-land. The problem? Lack of funding. I have a director, Susan Einhorn, with a long career in directing Off-Broadway and Off-off Broadway productions, who has access to a well-known 100-seat theater in Lower Manhattan, but we would need funds to stage any one of these "Tales From the American Street" (at present we're discussing reprising "The Carcass" for an American audience, but are staying flexible). The cost to stage any of them would approximate $35,000 (to pay the actors, lighting designer, set designer, theater fee, stage manager, sound person, publicity for the production, etc.) for a three-week showcase run and a couple weeks of rehearsals.

So, I'm hoping that those of you out there who might be interested in these ideas would consider funding them.

story:
Short Summary

Shakespeare BASH'd went into the 2012 Toronto Fringe not knowing what to expect, and we were floored by the support and love we received from our friends, family and theatre lovers in this wonderful city we call home. Voted Best of the Fringe in 2012, we're at it again, this time bringing Shakespeares' Much Ado About Nothing to the Toronto Fringe with our signature mixture of  fun, whimsy, beer consumption and serious attention to the text. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our 2012 Indiegogo campaign raised over $2000 to support our production, which quite literally allowed us to put on a play. Your support bought costumes, paid for rehearsal space, purchased props, and paid for promotional materials.  You are all amazing. We owe you, big.

And now we want to owe you bigger. Support our campaign and help us put on another award winning show. We want to see you out at the Victory Cafe again this year, and giving to this campaign will help us put together the best show possible. Plus, you'll be able to see exactly what your contribution helped when you watch Much Ado About Nothing. You're basically a producer now.  

Plus we'll give you perks for donating! Everything from Opening Night Tickets to a beer with our Founder, James Waliis.  It really doesn't get any better than that. 

The Impact

We were Best of the Fringe last year and would really like a repeat (and then a three-peat, but we're getting ahead of ourselves). Your support gives us the means to put on a killer show, which you then get to enjoy. You're investing in your own entertainment! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our campaign with your friends, family, coworkers, or even your rivals. Start a bidding war. Let's get serious with it.  We'll be updating you on our progress, so you can check back here and at www.shakespearebashd.com for details on upcoming events as we lead up to the Toronto Fringe.

story:
Colorguard is a competitive group of performers that work alongside the marching band in the summer/fall, spinning and throwing a variety of flags, rifles, sabres, and much more. The performers dance versions of ballet, hip hop, and jazz, as they execute shows that can last up to ten minutes. In the winter, the colorguard competes in a season traditionally known as "winterguard" where the colorguard is alone, performing in an indoor setting to previously recorded music. Each show has at least 4+ months of individual and ensemble practice going into the final product. In Foothill High School's colorguard, each girl puts in around twenty hours a week of their own time into the program, while attending to academics and other extracurricular activities. The 2013 Foothill Colorguard is made up of some of the best, most hardworking girls this program has seen yet. A person learning about colorguard for the first time often severely underestimates the sheer amount of passion and love these girls have for what they do, and the emerging amount of effort and determination. In addition, the skills of leadership, teamwork, and dedication acquired in colorguard not only apply to the program itself, but to real world situations these girls will encounter later on in life. Colorguard is a learning experience in itself and a place for any young girl or boy to belong, grow, and enjoy. It is every young, dedicated "guard girl's" or "guard guy's" dream to see and participate in the Winterguard International (WGI) championship competition, the highest level of the world, that takes place every April in Dayton, Ohio, and this has now become the dream of the Foothill Colorguard. The performances executed during this event are astonishing and breathtaking, like nothing anybody has ever seen before. They touch the hearts of the thousands watching from their arena seats. Nevertheless, simply getting to such a competition is a feat in itself, and not a cheap one. This project was created to raise money to fulfill the long-held dreams of seventeen girls who give several years of their lives to the challenging, yet incredibly rewarding experience that is colorguard.

The money raised here is put towards the trip fees for girls whose families cannot afford to go. These fees include plane tickets (as we are around two thousand miles away), hotel fees, registration, equipment, food, etc. Any donation over $50 will warrant a thank you card from all of the girls (seventeen in total) and a picture of our happy and incredibly thankful selves. Donations over $85 will receive in turn their very own mini flag: a Foothill colorguard trademark souvenir! Thank you for all of your support, and be sure to use the Indiegogo tools in order to spread the word of this dream-fufilling campaign.

story:
Hi There my name is Samantha and Im here to tell you alittle about me!

I have the strongest passion and commitment for dance, teaching, and enhancing society in todays youth and I thought whats a better way to continue living my dreams then spreading this love throughout the world?

Im here because I have been accepted into several amazing international dance programs starting September, 2013 and I need your help and support to attend. The programs consist of extensive dance training in London and volunteering my services to those in Africa, Costa Rica, and the Philippines. 

The overall cost for these trips is estimated to be at $15,000.00 including all living expenses and travel. I am asking for donations to help me accomplish these goals and to invest in my future.  I realize that the economy has many of you watching your spending but any amount that you can spare can make a difference and will be truly appreciated.

Your support in this endeavor would mean so much to me. Your contribution will help give back to those less fortunate and open doors for me in my future as I strive towards excellence. 

 

I thank you in advance for your donation!

story:
"Gym Shorts: The Show" is a new comedy that's opening Off-Broadway in May 2013!

At its core, “Gym Shorts: The Show” is about relationships. The kind of relationships we’ve all experienced in our own life, and can all identify with. The ecstasy of finding that new companion. The agony of betrayal. The struggle to be accepted for who you are.

All the great dramas and comedies of the ages have hinged on these profound human experiences. So, what is it that makes this rendition new and unique? And, of course, hilarious? It's set in the one place that can hold this amount of human triumph and tragedy, the blood, sweat and tears that make up the human experience (particularly the sweat):

THE GYM!!!

Who's Who in the Shorts?

"Gym Shorts: The Show" is the brainchild of Eric S. Robertson, a NY-based writer and director, with a unique take on love, life, and lifting.

It is produced by Kermit Raphael and Lynda Sing, both NY-based fitness professionals and entrepreneurs, who are very excited to bring this unique blend of comedy and fitness to the health-conscious community of New York City!

What goes into the Shorts?

Producing a new off-Broadway play is expensive - as much as $50,000.  As a contributor, your support will help pay for things like theater rental, studio rental, costumes, props, playbills, and more.  Most importantly, the salaries of the people working so hard to make this happen with us, like the set, lighting, sound and costume designers, the stage manager, and of course, the actors.

To say thank you for your generosity and support, we've put together series of very cool rewards.  Each one is something we think you'll like, and something we're very proud of.  Everything from signed posters to tickets to the show can be yours, just for helping us out!

Help spread the Shorts!

Every little bit helps, even if it's not money!

Please help us spread the word about our campaign, through Facebook, Twitter, word of mouth, between sets at the gyms, any way you can.
Use the IndieGoGo Share Tools right here on the site.


And lastly, let us just say:

Thanks for spotting us!

story:
Friends, Family, Colleagues and Teachers:

I'm Chris Bober and I'm directing the play "As Bees in Honey Drown" by Douglas Carter Beane. It's always been a dream of mine to direct a full length play in Manhattan and I'm tired of dreaming, so it's time to do some work and make it happen! 

This script means so much to me and has become increasingly relevant throughout the years (if you're unfamiliar with it, take a look at the synopsis below). I've been living and working in NYC now for just over a year and I've learned a lot in my time here. Often times in this profession, young artists are looking to become the next big thing and fast. We want everything yesterday and are looking for a fast track to success without ever wanting to go on the journey. It's easy to get caught up in all the hype and commotion and often times we get so distracted by our own illusions, we wake up one day and realize we've been drowning, (here it comes) almost "as bees in honey drown". 

I came across the work by accident during my time in college while attending the Kennedy Center American College Theatre Festival. (KCACTF) I watched it performed as one of five audience members and was blown away, not only by how intelligently written it was, but by how relevant it still was. I looked around the rest of the audience shocked and angry that more people hadn't witnessed what I did. I started to ask around and was shocked to find many of my theater friends and colleagues had never even heard of it. I decided at that point this script needed to be seen, read and performed more. People needed to hear Douglas Carter Beane's words and listen to his story. 

I've put a lot of thought into how I can make this happen. I've assembled a team of passionate and intelligent artists. I've done my research as a director. And most importantly, I've put my faith in my network of people. (YOU!) To make this dream a reality, my team and I need your help to finance the show. As you can imagine rehearsal spaces, rights, performance venues, lights, props, costumes, etc. are all very expensive. We are on a short timeline and need to reach our goal if this is going to happen. Any and all donations, no matter how big or small are greatly appreciated! Let's do this!

Sincerely,

Chris Bober


*The following synopsis was extracted from the play's web listing by Dramatists Play Service.

THE STORY: Evan Wyler has just finished a photo session with his shirt off. No, he's not a supermodel; he's a twenty-something New York writer savoring the success of his debut novel. Defined by the media as the "hot-young" thing-of-the-moment, Evan captures the attention of Alexa Vere de Vere, a black-clad woman of mystery who's made the world of celebrity her home. In fact, it's her religion. Maybe she's a record producer, maybe she's a film agent; what is clear is that she wants Evan to write the screenplay of her life story. Just spend time with me, she says, and you'll learn all you need to know. To Evan, who is gay, it's like an invitation into the world of Auntie Mame, Sally Bowles and Holly Golightly all rolled into one. But once Evan fools himself into believing he loves Alexa, she vanishes, leaving him to foot the bill for all the dinners and Armani suits they've gone through. Trying to find Alexa, Evan discovers a chain of people who have fallen under her spell and acted as her meal ticket. For Alexa has no money, no job, no life of her own—only the one she's created for herself. As Alexa puts it: "You're not the person you were born—who wonderful is?"

story:
The Prague Quadrennial
The Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space takes place every four years all over the city of Prague in the Czech Republic. This year it will be taking place from June 18-28. The PQ is the world's largest event dedicated to scenography and over 70 countries participate. There are three divisions to explore; the professional exhibition and competition, the student exhibition and the architecture exhibition. We will have the opportunity to learn from and view the work of top industry professionals as well as submit our own work for display. Along with the exhibitions, hundreds of workshops, lectures and performances take place all over the city. For ten days we will be immersed in the best of our industry and our personal growth as artists will be extensive. To compliment our time at the PQ, we will spend our time in the streets of Prague sketching and learning about the architecture and history of this great city. 
http://www.pq.cz/en/

The Theatre Designers
We are 12 Bachelor of Fine Arts and Master of Fine Arts in Theatre Design students training at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. Our unique program provides us with an extensive education in set, costume and lighting design through theoretical and realized work. We are taught hands on practical skills that are applicable to the industry and exposed to professional level productions through our own design projects, practicum work and through assistant assignments. Our studio projects are diverse and challenging ranging from surrealist plays to ballets to operas. Each project is critiqued by a panel allowing us to constantly take a deeper look at our own work. It is an extremely important part of our education to attend the PQ as a way to be exposed to the theatre that is happening outside of our community and all over the world. 
To learn more about our program, visit:
http://www.drama.ualberta.ca/Undergraduate_Programs/BFA_Theatre_Design.aspx

Our Goal
We are determined to cover the cost of the plane ticket for all 12 students. Flying from Canada to Europe isn't cheap. It will be about $1200 per student making our goal a grand total of $14,400. This campaign isn't our only effort. We have been fundraising for three years now and we are about a third of the way there. We will be applying for grants, collecting bottles and of course, baking a lot of cupcakes. This campaign is a contribution to a larger goal. 

Your Donation
Any size donation would mean the world to us. It is so important for us as designers to travel and be exposed to the work of the best in the industry. We are excited to bring these experiences back to the Edmonton theatre community and apply new inspiration to our education and future professional work. If we surpass our goal through all our fundraising efforts, the remaining funds will be applied to workshop fees in Prague to allow us to further enrich our experience. Thank you for your contirbution and for supporting us as young emerging artists.
story_txt:
The Prague Quadrennial
The Prague Quadrennial of Performance Design and Space takes place every four years all over the city of Prague in the Czech Republic. This year it will be taking place from June 18-28. The PQ is the world's largest event dedicated to scenography and over 70 countries participate. There are three divisions to explore; the professional exhibition and competition, the student exhibition and the architecture exhibition. We will have the opportunity to learn from and view the work of top industry professionals as well as submit our own work for display. Along with the exhibitions, hundreds of workshops, lectures and performances take place all over the city. For ten days we will be immersed in the best of our industry and our personal growth as artists will be extensive. To compliment our time at the PQ, we will spend our time in the streets of Prague sketching and learning about the architecture and history of this great city. 

http://www.pq.cz/en/





The Theatre Designers

We are 12 Bachelor of Fine Arts and Master of Fine Arts in Theatre Design students training at the University of Alberta in Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. Our unique program provides us with an extensive education in set, costume and lighting design through theoretical and realized work. We are taught hands on practical skills that are applicable to the industry and exposed to professional level productions through our own design projects, practicum work and through assistant assignments. Our studio projects are diverse and challenging ranging from surrealist plays to ballets to operas. Each project is critiqued by a panel allowing us to constantly take a deeper look at our own work. It is an extremely important part of our education to attend the PQ as a way to be exposed to the theatre that is happening outside of our community and all over the world. 
To learn more about our program, visit:
http://www.drama.ualberta.ca/Undergraduate_Programs/BFA_Theatre_Design.aspx

Our Goal
We are determined to cover the cost of the plane ticket for all 12 students. Flying from Canada to Europe isn't cheap. It will be about $1200 per student making our goal a grand total of $14,400. This campaign isn't our only effort. We have been fundraising for three years now and we are about a third of the way there. We will be applying for grants, collecting bottles and of course, baking a lot of cupcakes. This campaign is a contribution to a larger goal. 

Your Donation
Any size donation would mean the world to us. It is so important for us as designers to travel and be exposed to the work of the best in the industry. We are excited to bring these experiences back to the Edmonton theatre community and apply new inspiration to our education and future professional work. If we surpass our goal through all our fundraising efforts, the remaining funds will be applied to workshop fees in Prague to allow us to further enrich our experience. Thank you for your contirbution and for supporting us as young emerging artists.

story:
The Witches of Eastwick need you!

Featuring a cast of 41 young talents, an exciting musical score and an ambitious flying sequence, The Witches of Eastwick presents a real challenge to our experienced production team who are fully focused on producing most spectacular show that York has ever seen in both student and professional circles. 

However, none of what we aspire to do is possible without sufficient funds. Having already raised close to £5000, in the final weeks leading up to the show The Witches of Eastwick team aim to raise another £4000 to cover the costs of the production and your support in helping us reach this target would be greatly appreciated. 

About Us

Established at the University of York in 2003, Central Hall Musical Society boasts a rich history of brilliant musical productions, including West Side Story, Into the Woods and most recently an acclaimed run of Jesus Christ Superstar which cemented its status as a company of students wholly dedicated to producing a truly outstanding theatrical experience both for audience members and performers alike. 

Fundraising ventures so far have included Krispy Kreme doughnut sales, live music events, sing-along film screenings, christmas caroling and daily bake sales, with quizzes, open mic nights and flash mobs all in the pipeline!

Making the Magic Happen

The Witches of Eastwick combines West-End sparkle with a witty black comedy perfect for musical theatre lovers and virgins alike. Its libretto calls for comic prowess, show-stopping dance numbers and brilliant musical talent which CHMS are sure to deliver in droves, but to truly enchant our audiences we need just a little bit of fairy dust, and that's where you come in.

Money raised for the production will go towards ensuring that our show reaches the professional standard that we aspire to. Bespoke costumes and larger-than-life set structures don't come cheap and our combined set, costume and prop budgets exceed £2000.

In addition to the standard theatrical magic - no show about modern day witches would be complete without real illusions and some of the special effects we've prepared include self-playing cellos, disappearing tennis balls and of course the infamous flying sequence that closes the first act - we won't give away any secrets but enchantments like these as well as spectacular sound and lighting effects are set to cost in the region of £6,800.

After the final curtain...

Any revenue will be reinvested in the development of the society which organises workshops for students from visiting professionals, as well as all-inclusive showcases, outreach projects and community busking trips.

Central Hall Musical Society provides aspiring young professionals with an incomparable chance to manage all aspects of a high calibre production and with your help we can make The Witches of Eastwick  a creative and financial triumph ensuring that this legacy can continue in future years.

story:
Now Boarding...

There once was a company, called Turn to Flesh
Who thought that the theatre could use something fresh.
"What shall we do?  It's been done before!"
And then they realized: What we need is MORE.
More rhyming, more heartache, more drama, more verse
More everything better - not "everything's worse."

Elsewhere uptown, Jenny Lyn Bader (playwright)
Had a new show in couplets, titled IN FLIGHT.
She'd brought it to England - it had a good reading;
But a full-fledged production was what she was needing.
What then to do?  The show could play where?
Who wanted "Gal Friday" by way of Molière?

Imagine, therefore, the squeals of delight
When Turn to Flesh learned of this new play, IN FLIGHT!
We'd tackled blank verse this past Valentine's Day -
But a whole play in couplets?  Well!  What could we say!
"Let's put on a show!  But who's got a place?"
And that, dear friend, is where you enter the space...

Luggage Check

Here's what we're looking for:

  • $6,000 Rents Two Weeks of Performance Space
  • $1,500 Provides Four Weeks of Rehearsal
  • $2,000 Provides Stipends for Crew (Playwright, Director, SM, etc.)
  • $600 Covers Actors' Stipend
  • $200 Covers Script Printing
  • $100 Covers Postcard and Poster Printing
  • And then any additional will help us hire up-and-coming lighting, set, costume, and prop designers - and provide them with a budget!
  • Oh...and don't forget that Indiegogo and Fractured Atlas take their cut, too.

Fasten Your Seatbelts

In the past 18 months, Turn to Flesh Productions has worked with:

  • 13 New Plays
  • 7 Plays in Verse
  • 2 Fully Staged Productions
  • To Sold-Out Houses
To give you an idea, our Cupid and Psyche ~ A New Play in Blank Verse, which ran this past Valentine's Weekend 2014 at The Barrow Group Theatre had despite:
  • 1 Week of Performance;
  • 2 Minor Blizzards; and a
  • 3 Hour Run-Time...
  • Sold out AND paid back our loan and turned a small profit
Which then financed our 2014 Playreading Series, which included IN FLIGHT.

Liftoff!

While we're looking for a moderate budget for a small two-week run - every penny up and over that $12,000 will allow us to do the following.  

Every additional:

  • $3,000 Gives us another week of theatre space (we'd like to put on a 4-6 week run in total)
  • $1,000 Gives us a boost towards top-notch sets, lights, costumes and props. 
  • $500 Rehearsal space - until we are able to call a space our home, we'll need space to loan.
Meet Us At The Gate

Can't join us IN FLIGHT?  No fear!  You can still meet us at the gate.

  • Take a moment to spread the word on Facebook and Twitter
  • Volunteer to help with the production.  Want to lend a helping hand?  Email us at turntoflesh (at) gmail and let us know how you'd like to get involved!

Frequent Fliers

Your donations don't just support one project - they help us the whole year round!

  • Spring 2015 - IN FLIGHT - to perform Off-Off-Broadway in a Midtown Venue
  • Summer 2015 - Week long residency of new play development, matching playwrights, directors, and performers to create new works in heightened text
  • Fall 2015 - Begin educational initiative and outreach, specializing in writing new verse (middle and high school outreach), and business and strategy seminars for Independent Theatre practitioners.
  • Spring 2016 - Launching, in repertory, the full Love and Death Trilogy: Persephone Rises, The Seduction of Adonis and Cupid and Psyche - all three plays in five act iambic pentameter 

Thank you for choosing Turn to Flesh Productions...

...and make sure you put your seat back in the full upright position!
